summary: [/INST] This study aims to assess whether specific clusters of psychosocial factors characterize women with fibromyalgia, chronic migraine, vulvodynia, or women without chronic pain conditions. Psychosocial factors include trauma, alexithymia, personality traits, depression, quality of life, and social support. To examine this, they will collect data from a convenience sample of women who meet eligibility criteria through questionnaires on the above psychosocial factors, the Central Sensitivity Inventory, Traumatic Experiences Scales, Mental Pain Questionnaire, Highly Sensitive Person Scales, Defense Mechanisms Rating Scales, Environment Sensitivity Inventory, Short Form for the Perception of Body Pain, Brief Symptom Inventory, Social Support Questionnaire, Sexual Satisfaction Scale, Female Sexual Functioning Index.

[/INST] The study compares the effectiveness of a massage mattress with a cube/block system as a pressure ulcer prevention device in bedridden patients undergoing long-term care to prevent bed sores. A lower incidence of pressure ulcers is expected in the group treated with the massage mattress than in the control group.

[/INST] This study concerns a clinical trial comparing a group that performs exercise with augmented reality glasses to a control group. The purpose of the study is to evaluate whether exercise using augmented reality glasses makes a difference in metabolic parameters such as HbA1c, BMI, and quality of life in children aged 10–12 with type 1 diabetes. 60 children will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group, with both groups receiving the standard treatment for diabetes during the 12-week study period. The primary outcome measure is the change in average HbA1c levels during the study period, while the secondary outcome measures include change in average BMI levels and average quality of life rating. All primary and secondary outcome measures will be assessed by a nurse and the researcher during intervention visits, which will occur at the hospital every two weeks. The 12-week intervention consists of two days of exercise, each lasting 60 minutes, where the children will use augmented reality glasses to perform the exercises while being monitored by staff. The exercise classes will be designed by a physiotherapist, which will include stretching exercises, resistance training, and aerobic training. The study is expected to be completed by October of 2023.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on preoperative anxiety levels using a preoperative anxiety scale and a smart wristband that can measure stress levels in patients who will undergo abdominal surgery. The study included 128 patients, of which 32, 32, and 32 were assigned to the intervention, comparison, and control groups. The intervention group watched a video with virtual glasses, the comparison group watched a video using the same video in the intervention group but without the virtual glasses, and the control group did not receive any intervention. The study concluded that virtual reality is effective in reducing preoperative anxiety levels. All experiments on this type of intervention have been approved through necessary ethical and safety procedures and were completed successfully within the scope of preoperative anxiety, the results of which may be shared with the public.

[/INST] This study, named "Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL," aimed to evaluate the clinical performance and safety of a surgical method using a suture-TOOL device during laparotomy closure. The study compared the use of this device with conventional procedures. The study involved 73 participants who underwent open abdominal surgery for various reasons. The primary outcome assessed in this study was the proportion of patients with a suture length/wound length (SL/WL) ratio of 4 or higher. The study found that the SL/WL ratio was 4 or higher in 27 patients (90%) using the suture-TOOL device and 31 patients (82%) using conventional suture techniques. There were no adverse events associated with the use of the suture-TOOL in any of the patients. The device was determined as a safe, time- and motion-efficient procedure alternative for the closure of open abdominal wounds. All studies from the same group that used this device had positive results, the suture-TOOL device was a reliable alternative to traditional laparotomy closure techniques.

[/INST] Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Cancer [clinicaltrials.gov] is an observational, single-arm study that aims to determine the immunological profile of patients with salivary gland carcinomas, benign salivary gland tumors, and patients undergoing functional ear surgery or rhinoplasty. The primary outcome includes the observation of changes in an established immune matrix, the longitudinal immunophenotyping of patients, the analysis of cytokines in peripheral blood, the analysis of patient’s metabolic state, and the analysis of patient’s microbiomic state. The latter is conducted by examining saliva, tumor, and stool samples to assess the presence and relative distribution of microbiomes using 16S rRNA deep sequencing. The study is ongoing with no publication yet.

[/INST] The objective of the study is to examine the relationship between the Mediterranean diet, health of individuals with MS, and walking and quality of life. The study is a longitudinal observation and the questionnaires will be done at 1, 3, and 12 months. The sample group will be evaluated using the multiple sclerosis international quality of life scale, PREDIMED (Mediterranean diet adaptation survey), the MS walking scale, and the extended disability status scale.

[/INST] The SIIT-CD Study is a phase III, multicenter, randomized controlled study. It evaluates the safety and efficacy of a treatment, a selective intensive induction therapy based on the Ustekinumab Selective Induction Treatment (UST)-Crohn Disease Score Tool (CDST) in patients with Crohn's disease. The study includes participants diagnosed with Crohn's disease who have met UST-CDST criteria for moderate to low response rates. The study uses intensive induction therapy and a non-intensive induction therapy arm. The intensive induction therapy arm involves induction with ustekinumab, while the non-intensive induction therapy arm received non-ustekinumab treatments. The study aims to compare the clinical response rate as well as differences in patient outcomes between the two arms at 24 weeks.

[/INST] This study is a Discrete Choice Experiment with overactive bladder adult patients as participants. Fictive therapies with options between treatments such as “botox” and “SNM” (Sacral Neuromodulation) are presented to participants to choose the best treatment as per their preference.

[/INST] Diabetes is one of the most common chronic diseases worldwide. Self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) is recommended by various guidelines as an essential part of diabetes self-management. Due to the significant importance of improving blood glucose control, the value of CGM to the overall benefit for T1DM patients is clear. To assist in decision making for healthcare providers on the choice of CGM, there is a need to conduct studies comparing CGM to SMBG in clinical practice.

[/INST] SBRT with focal dose escalation (increasing the dose to a specific area) in dominant intraprostatic lesions (DILs). SBRT is a technique that delivers a high dose of radiation to the cancer cells while minimizing the damage to the surrounding healthy cells. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this approach in localized prostate cancer patients.

[/INST] This trial's objective is to use a serious game intervention for controlling asthma in children between the ages of 12 to 17 years old. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in the quality of life of children with asthma, as assessed by the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL). The secondary outcome measure is the improvement in the emotional and behavioral problems of children with asthma, as assessed by the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita). This trial is randomized in two groups: intervention group (which will use the serious game on a projector with a kinect to motivate them to do physical exercises that help to manage asthma) and control group (which will not use the serious game and will have a conventional treatment plan). The trial will have two arms and take six months. The results will give information about the effectiveness of the serious game in the improvement of quality of life and emotional and behavioral issues of children with asthma and also its acceptability to children.

[/INST] Objective: The trial focused on the role of acute stress and chronic alcohol use disorder in developing individual differences in the motivational effect of alcohol-associated cues on instrumental behavior. Participants were either non-addicted, daily-smoking controls, or patients with alcohol use disorder and either daily smokers or non-smokers. Specific predictions about stress effects were compared with the ones induced by other experimental or clinical conditions (e.g., depression), and individual differences in stress sensitivity were examined using questionnaires. Participants underwent two experimental sessions consisting of assessments using magnetic resonance imaging, behavioral tasks, hair and saliva cortisol samples, and an fMRI scan with two successive testing conditions: a Pavlovian conditioning phase and a Go/No-Go task.

[/INST] Flow&Grow - A CPAP management strategy for preterm infants to support lung growth. A multicenter, randomized controlled trial. (015236-0.1) is a study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new approach for using CPAP to support lung growth in premature infants. The study uses an algorithm-based, CPAP weaning approach, where infants are kept on CPAP for longer periods, to promote lung growth. CPAP is a treatment that supplies continuous positive pressure to help keep an infant's airways open and protect the lungs from collapsing. The study's main outcome measure is the number of infants who require subsequent interventions after study completion (e.g., repeat endotracheal intubation, prolonged mechanical ventilation, NEC, and BPD). Another outcome is the number of infants who require supplemental oxygen at discharge by study completion. The study also looks at the number of infants who show lung damage due to multiple airway infections or other reasons during the first 36 weeks of life. The study is a multicenter study, meaning the research involves different places or institutions working together to perform the research.

[/INST] The Frexalimab Trial is a phase 3 clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the monoclonal autoantibody Frexalimab in the treatment of non-relapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SP-MS) as compared to Placebo using the EDSS score and MRI. Participants must have an EDSS score at screening from 3.0 to 6.5 points, inclusive. Inclusion criteria include a previous diagnosis of relapsing-remitting MS for at least 24 months without relapses, a diagnosis of SPMS for at least 12 months prior to screening and absence of clinical relapses for at least 24 months. The study comprises a screening period, a 3-month up-titration phase, a maintenance phase from weeks 13-204 where participants receive either 1200 mg of Frexalimab or a Placebo infusion every four weeks, a safety follow-up period of 52 weeks, and an optional open-label extension period up to 4 years, during which all participants will receive Frexalimab. The primary objective of the Frexalimab Trial is to test its efficacy in treating non-relapsing, secondary progressive multiple sclerosis patients in slowing and minimizing additional disability progression defined as a composite of EDSS, the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW), and the nine-hole peg test (9HPT). The first secondary objective is to test Frexalimab's efficacy in treating non-relapsing, secondary progressive multiple sclerosis patients in slowing and minimizing additional disability progression within three months of starting treatment. The second secondary objective is to determine the number and percentage of participants experiencing adverse events, serious adverse events, and adverse events leading to discontinuation.

[/INST] CLEFT LIP REPAIR BY MILLOGER MODIFIED MISHRA TECHNIQUE - RCT is a study that aims to compare the effectiveness of two techniques of unilateral cleft lip repairs on babies: the Millgor Mishra modification and the Mishra technique. Infants and babies who are born with an upper lip split into two parts and reach the age of two to six months are eligible to participate in the trial. They will be randomly assigned to either the control or experimental group. The primary outcomes are the measurements taken after the surgery, such as vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtrum length, which will be taken at three months after the surgery.

[/INST] This is a randomized controlled trial to compare the efficacy of endoscopic management of sigmoid perforation with colo-cutaneous fistula due to acute diverticulitis with colorectal surgery. The outcome measures are recurrence of fistula and incidence of postoperative complications. The endoscopic closure of the fistula is done with endoscopic OTSC™ closure system. The closure of the fistula is done after proper colonic preparation the day after admission of the patient with the help of endoscopic stent insertion and/or biopsy. If the endoscopic stent is inserted, it is removed the very next day. After fistula closure, the patients are assessed with clinical examination and abdominal ultrasound, CT, as well as biomarkers such as CRP and leucocytes.

[/INST] The study titled "Multidisciplinary Approach for High-Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure" is a multisite randomized clinical trial that tests the impact of a screening and surveillance program for early detection of coronary heart failure on the number of heart failure diagnoses and the number of heart failure events among patients with at least two risk factors for coronary heart failure. The study is being conducted in Canada and is being led by the Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Saint-François. The study involves 677 patients who are randomized to receive either a heart failure screening and surveillance program or standard care. The primary outcome measures of the study are the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, the number of outpatient heart failure visits, the number of urgent heart failure visits, and the number of heart failure hospitalization. The secondary outcome measures of the study are the number of patients diagnosed with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) within 6 months, the number of patients diagnosed with HFrEF who receive Guideline-directed medical therapy within 6 months, and the number of HF events in HFrEF.

[/INST] In this clinical trial, the aim of the study is to evaluate the effects of propofol dose according to lean body weight (LBW) by assessing patients with BMI below 35. The study will include patients aged over 18 years with BMI of 18.5-24.9, 25-29.9 and 30-34.9 who will undergo general anesthesia for 2-6 hours. Propofol dose will be applied according to total bodyweight, ideal body weight and lean body weight. The infusion will be done gradually until a BIS value of 50-40 is achieved. Routine anesthesia applications will be performed with neuromuscular blocker applied. The relationships between the doses given and the body mass index will be evaluated. The sample size is not mentioned. The data of all study participants will be analyzed using ANOVA, Chi-square, t-test and Fisher's Exact Test. The study was approved by the Ethic Committee of Afyon Kocatepe University, Faculty of Medicine [IRB: 98, approval date: 04.09.2018].

[/INST] Letermovir is being studied for the prevention of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections in adult patients who receive a lung or heart transplant. CMV is a virus that can commonly cause infections after an organ transplant. Valganciclovir is the current medicine used to prevent CMV infections in these patients. Studies have shown that letermovir may have a possible benefit on the prevention of CMV infection when given to these patients. The primary outcome being studied in this trial is a combination of CMV infection, CMV disease, or CMV syndrome. The trial is being conducted through the Center Hospitalier Val-de-Travers in Switzerland and is expected to take two years.

[/INST] The study aimed to develop the Physical Therapy Score (PHYSIOSCORE) to assess the complexity level and physical therapy care in hospitalized patients. The PHYSIOSCORE consisted of three domains, respiratory, neurological, and imaging. The authors performed a multi-phase study to validate the PHYSIOSCORE. In phase one, the PHYSIOSCORE was developed with a committee that composed of ten specialized physical therapists with more than ten years of experience. In phase two, the reliability of the PHYSIOSCORE was assessed using the Spearman correlation with the other scales. In phase three, the clinical validity of the PHYSIOSCORE was assessed by comparing it with the EuroScore, Simplified Acute Physiological Scores II and III, and the Assessment Respiratory Risk in Surgical Patients in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery classification. Finally, the authors confirmed the PHYSIOSCORE's feasibility and efficacy by reducing the time spent evaluating respiratory and neuromuscular physical therapy care.

[/INST] The goal study is to evaluate if 30 patients who fit specific criteria: pathological T1-3 N1-2 with negative surgical margins, absent extracapsular extension ≤ 1 mm on pathology, ctDNA negative after TORS, post-treatment will be safe to not get adjuvant treatment. The aim is to reduce treatment toxicity and increase quality of life of patients who would have otherwise received adjuvant radiation.

[/INST] Ultra-Hypofractionated for whole breast radiotherapy comparted to partial radiotherapy: A single-institution prospective phase 2 trial study of breast cancer which aims to compare ultra-hypofractionated whole breast radiotherapy to ultra-hypofractionated partial breast radiotherapy in patients with breast cancer after breast conservation surgery. They will measure the acute and late toxicity of the two radiotherapy regimens and assess the local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, and cosmetic outcomes. They will also measure quality of life using the EORTC QLQ-BR23 questionnaire. The study will be conducted in Valida hospital in Serbia. The primary outcome will be measured 1–6 months after radiotherapy. The secondary outcome will be measured at 3, 5 and 10 years after radiotherapy. The study is approved by the Ethics Committee of the Clinical Center of Serbia, Ministry of Health of the Republic of Serbia, and the National Institute of Health Innovation and Medical Research, Government of the Republic Serbia.

[/INST] This article outlines a clinical trial titled "PRO and Wearable Data Insights From Individuals With R/R Multiple Myeloma" (PROMotOR Study). The trial's purpose is to evaluate the use of symptom monitoring and digital life coaching (DLC) in gathering a more complete understanding of the impact of multiple myeloma on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being in a diverse population of U.S.-based, contemporary individuals with relapsed/refractory (R/R) multiple myeloma. The PROMotOR study will be conducted as a single group, open-label study over a period of 6 months. The study's key objectives include evaluating the feasibility and patient retention in the 3 months following the start of digital health coaching, changes in the Cancer Behavior Inventory-Brief Form, and correlations between objective activity scores as measured by the Fitbit wearable activity tracker and patient-reported scores on multiple outcomes. The PROMotOR Study has the potential to contribute to the improvement of care delivery and the enhancement of overall quality of life for R/R multiple myeloma patients.

[/INST] The document describes a multicentered, randomized clinical trial for the treatment of localized gingival recessions with the use of a porcine acellular dermal matrix in combination with a coronal advanced flap, where the intervention group will receive a porcine acellular dermal matrix in addition to a coronal advanced flap. In both study arms, the coronal advanced flap alone will serve as active comparator. The trial aims to assess the effectiveness in terms of gingival recession height reduction and a complete regeneration of the keratinized tissue over the course of six and twelve months. Patients will be randomly assigned to each of the treatment groups. Both groups will follow the same follow-up schedule and data will be collected at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Both eligibility criteria and exclusion criteria have been precisely defined. The study was designed to run for a total of 69 months in total, including time for participant recruitment, study procedures, and follow-up.

[/INST] The main goal of this study is to compare changes in heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients undergoing conventional physical exercise and virtual reality exercise during hemodialysis sessions. The study will compare each group to the other, with and without physical exercise, to determine which form of exercise is the most effective. Patients ages 18 to 70 years old will be eligible for participation. The study will run for a total of 40 sessions and will last 20 days in total. During each session, the patients will receive intervention with or without virtual reality on tuesdays, thursdays, and fridays of each week. On other days, patients will play the game, which is referred to as "VRG", or ride the stationary bicycle, which is referred to as "SB". Every week, patients will be randomly assigned a new treatment. Patients will play a virtual reality game on VRG, which will have them riding on a roller coaster, avoiding obstacles. They will have to control the roller coaster using their hand movements only. On SB, patients will ride a stationary bicycle while they watch a short movie on a television in front of them. A heart rate variability (HRV) monitor and sensors will capture their heart rate at all times while they play or ride the stationary bike. The study will use heart rate variability as an indicator of how effective the exercise is, as it allows the researchers to measure their autonomic nervous system activity. The results of this study will determine whether physical exercise in the form of virtual reality can be a beneficial addition to hemodialysis to increase HRV.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to identify patients at high risk of weaning failure using dyspnea and respiratory variability. By including a population of adult patients unable to be extubated after two days of MV, the authors will compare the efficacy of a dyspnea visual analog scale and a non-invasive measurement of respiratory variability to predict weaning outcome. The study has an observational design and will collect multiple physiological measurements during the weaning process. The results will be discussed in the context of an upcoming publication that validates the correlation of ventilatory parameters to a dyspnea scale observed during a spontaneous breathing trial. The project has been reviewed twice and determined to be a non-interventional project by the Ethical Committee of the University Hospital La Pitié-Salpêtrière, Paris, France and the CNIL.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of action observation therapy (AOT) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). AOT involves observing a motor action (e.g., lifting an object) and then replicating the same action. The trial compares AOT delivered by a trained therapist to AOT delivered by non-medical personnel and usual care. The trial has three study arms: an experimental group that receives AOT from trained therapists, another experimental group that receives AOT from non-therapists, and a control group that receives standard care. The primary outcome measures are changes in cognition, activities of daily living, functionality, upper limb dexterity, balance, and gait after AOT over five weeks. The results of this study could contribute to more effective treatment methods for patients with MCI.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial is a randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of ultraportable ultrasound devices (UUS) with conventional method for central venous line (CVL) placement. The study was designed to assess the length of procedure while utilizing these methods for CVL placement in the adult population. The trial was conducted in the intervention arm by applying US-guided CVL under ultraportable US, while the conventional US methods were used to guide placement of the CVL in the control group. Eligible participants were those scheduled to have a central venous line placed either preoperatively or in the ICU, with the age greater than or equal to 18 years old. However, pregnant women, patients with free, informed, and express consent, those with suspicious or proven jugular thrombosis at the insertion site as well as operators without experience in central venous line placement under US were excluded from the study. Allocation of the participants varied with alternative allocation based on odd or even study numbers. Patients were masked throughout the study and were not informed of the intervention they would be receiving. The participants received central venous catheter under ultraportable US devices to insert a central venous line as the intervention. The conventional US-guided placement of the same venous line was utilized as the control arm of the study. The trial lasted 1 day and the primary outcome measures evaluated was the length of the procedure. The study found that the ultraportable US-guided placement of the central venous lines was successful and efficient in terms of time required with no major complications associated with the procedure as compared to the conventional US method. The study concluded that UUS devices provide an efficient means of CVL positioning over the conventional method.

[/INST] Summary: This is a randomized controlled trial in which the authors investigate the impact of early skin-to-skin contact upon maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth. [/INST] We are only one year away from ending the war on drugs and beginning a new era of harm reduction that is steeped in science and guided by robust clinical evidence. The new era will lead to significant reductions in premature morbidity and mortality associated with the use of drugs, with important associated reductions in drug-related criminality. As a result, we'll see reductions in the use of precious healthcare system resources for the diagnosis and treatment of morbid conditions arising from the use of drugs. A new era of drug use will free up the time of our various healthcare professions so they can focus on providing evidence-based care to all of those who need it, without the confounding influence of a war on drugs interfering with the best use of their educational and professional training.

[/INST] The proposed study aims to use ultrasound imaging techniques to develop and validate a multimodal biomarker for myofascial pain, which is a frequent contributing factor to chronic low back pain (cLBP). Through echosensitivity, dynamic spatial-temporal tissue deformation, and viscoelastic properties measurements, the study intends to identify a predictive and diagnostic biomarker. The multimodal biomarker has the potential to distinguish patients with and without lumbar myofascial pain. In phase 1 (R61), the multimodal biomarker will be analyzed using machine learning models and statistical analyses to validate its ability to differentiate patients with cLBP-related myofascial pain from normal participants. Phase 2 (R33) aims to determine the sensitivity and specificity of the multimodal ultrasound biomarker using larger clinical trials. If successful, this study has the potential to develop a new biomarker for diagnosing and predicting response to treatments in patients with cLBP-related myofascial pain.

[/INST] The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial (PIVOT) is a randomized controlled trial conducted on 200 adults with musculoskeletal (MSK) pain presenting to an emergency room or urgent care department. The intervention consists of an educational video covering topics such as musculoskeletal pain, over-the-counter medications, and self-care strategies, which the participant is encouraged to share with their healthcare provider. The video will be sent to the participant's email, and they will also be required to answer multiple-choice questions and confirm watching the video at a later date. Control patients will receive usual care. The primary outcome is the combined scores of pain severity and interference from the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) on the three follow-up visits. Secondary outcomes include pain scores and pain interference combined from the BPI, opioid use during the past week, ability to perform PROMIS physical function-4, ability to use stairs, capacity to walk, and the ability to handle chores, PROMIS Global Health-Physical 2a, number of ED/urgent care visits, and the number of non-ED or urgent care physician visits for MSK pain. The purpose of the PIVOT trial is to analyze the effect of a telehealth pain management intervention on pain recovery and opioid use among patients with MSK pain.

[/INST] * The SPAC trial is the SParing major lymPH node dissection to increase QoL in the elderly treated for frail by Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) in Early stage Colon Cancer.

[/INST] This is an open-label study on the use of nebulised hypertonic saline (6%) to reduce respiratory exacerbations in participants ages 5 years and above with neuromuscular disease or neurodisability. Respiratory exacerbations are defined as full courses of antibiotics prescribed for respiratory infections, which may be oral or intravenous, excluding prophylactic antibiotic prescriptions. These courses of antibiotics will be recorded before and after the administration of nebulised hypertonic saline. Additionally, other outcomes including the lung clearance index (LCI) measured by multiple breath washout, lung function tests using forced oscillation technique, such as respiratory resistance (Rrs) and respiratory reactance (Xrs), global lung ultrasound score, and electrical impedance tomography (EIT)-based global inhomogeneity index (GI), as well as airway inflammation measured through levels of interleukin-6, 8, 1b, and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-a) in sputum or throat swab, as well as operational taxonomic unit (OTU) richness and Pielou’s eveness index in sputum or throat swab will be assessed to determine the effect of nebulised hypertonic saline on other secondary measures. Additionally, patient ease of airway clearance and quality of life will be measured using a 0-10 visual analogue scale and Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL). Questionnaires administered to patients and carers about the level of satisfaction of the treatment will also be analysed to analyse their perception and opinion of the therapy. Lastly, a health economic analysis will be conducted to analyse quality-adjusted life years (QALYs).

[/INST] Risk for Sexual Violence Paraphilic Disorders and Other Conditions With. Study aims to investigate the progress and consequences of paraphilic disorders. The clinical cohort will be assessed with DSM-5 criteria for paraphilic disorders including pedophilia, compulsive sexual behavior disorder, and sexsomnia. Hypersexual behavior disorder assessments are used based on DSM-11 criteria. Assessments will be repeated after 3, 6, and 12 months. The study hypothesizes that paraphilic disorders without comorbidities will have better functioning, more satisfaction in relationships, and fewer sexual compulsions over time. However, it hypothesizes that those with comorbidities may worsen, develop more psychosexual dysfunction, sexual traumatization, loneliness, and worsened sleep quality over time.

[/INST] The clinical trial is "Developing a New Metabolic Imaging Approach (aMRI) for Evaluating Neurological Disease in Patients With Gliomas", and the overarching objective is to characterize a new metabolic imaging method. The method, referred to as "activity-mediated relaxation imaging" (amri), was developed to detect and characterize tumor lesions. The main objective of the trial is to determine if this new metabolic imaging approach can be directly compared to the standard metabolic imaging method, 18F-FDG PET. The secondary objective is to characterize the metabolically active tumor periphery and necrotic core regions. The trial uses MRI and PET imaging to assess the metabolic parameter, kᵢₒ, in tumor periphery regions, tumor normal-appearing regions, and normal-appearing brain regions that do not have any tumors.

[/INST] The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving guideline-directed medical therapy in patients with heart failure. The study is a cluster randomized trial designed to compare the effectiveness of three different approaches: usual care, CDS with patient reminder and clinical advice, and CDS with patient reminder, clinical advice, and integrated clinical pharmacist co-management. The study will also evaluate the different approaches to determining the effect of education on the outcomes. The intervention includes educational materials, interactive education sessions, reminders, and decision support. The outcomes will be the proportion of patients with HFrEF receiving guideline-directed medical therapy within 30, 60, or 90 days of an office or telemedicine visit. The study has implications for healthcare providers and professionals seeking to improve management of HFrEF and implementation of evidence-based guidelines.

[/INST] "The study titled 'Stone clearance in patients with upper ureteric stones using extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy compared with extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy combined with tamsulosin therapy.’ aimed to compare the efficiency of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone and with tamsulosin therapy in patients with upper ureteric stones. The study is a randomized parallel controlled trial with a follow-up of 28 days. The inclusion criteria were patients with a single upper ureteric stone measuring 6-15 mm in diameter and without any history of ureteric stone treatment for more than six months. The exclusion criteria included patients with a urinary tract infection, multiple ureteric stones, and abnormal coagulation profile. The study also excluded patients using calcium channel blockers or alpha-adrenergic antagonists. The active control was the patients who were treated with ESWL (one session of ESWL) alone. The active comparator group received 0.4 mg and 0.25-0.5 mg tamsulosin for eight weeks (with ESWL) and seven weeks (without ESWL) after baseline, and a follow-up was done four weeks after the intervention. The primary endpoint was complete clearance measured by axial CTKUB (four weeks) after the intervention."

[/INST] This is a clinical trial that aims to study the effect of community-based psychiatric interventions in reducing the risk of suicide ideation and behavior in people who are HIV positive and inject drug users. The study will be conducted among 600 participants who are HIV positive and inject drug users in Vietnam. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive community-based psychiatric interventions or the control group, which will receive standard of care treatment services. The primary outcomes will include the incidence of suicidal ideations and behaviors, severity of substance use, and quality of life scores. The interventions will be conducted by trained health workers in the community, which will help to make these psychiatric services more accessible to people who might not otherwise seek care. The results of this study could have important implications for the treatment of mental health disorders in people who are living with HIV and engage in drug use behaviors. The study will provide important new insights into the effectiveness of community-based psychiatric interventions for this population, and will also contribute to the general knowledge about the effectiveness of these interventions.

[/INST] The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment combined with photodynamic therapy (PDT) at 10 s and 20 s in patients with apical lesion, compared to conventional endodontic treatment using methylene blue. The clinical and radiographic examinations were carried out to obtain baseline values and after 6 months. The treatment success rate was assessed 6 months post-treatment by clinical signs and symptoms, and radiographic results (diminution of the lesion or absence of root resorption). The results showed good results in the 3 groups, but without statistically significant differences, in any variable among them and with respect to the control group; therefore, they concluded that the application of conventional endodontic treatment is a safe treatment option in patients with apical lesions.

[/INST] The provided summary describes a multicentric, rater-blinded, 18-months study that aims to develop a multidimensional, personalized therapeutic approach for individuals with MSA. [/INST] A Study of the Genetic Basis of Response to Growth Hormone Treatment in Children with Idiopathic Short Stature. This is a study on genetic factors that affect the response to growth hormone therapy in children with short stature and its co-morbidities. The purpose of this study is to identify genetic variants associated with response to growth hormone therapy from 206 children with idiopathic short stature who are undergoing treatment for a 24-month period. These variables include weight, height, insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), and growth hormone (GH) concentration. Height is measured using standing height at each visit and the average of all standing heights measurements is used to calculate the Standard Deviation Score (SDS) at the end of therapy. Insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is a hormone that promotes bone and tissue growth. Growth hormone (GH) stimulation test is done to check if growth hormone deficiency is present. The study findings will contribute to our understanding of the genetic basis of response to growth hormone therapy and identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of short stature.

[/INST] The study "Impact of Neurochecks on Sleep in Critically Ill Adults" is a randomized clinical trial with two arms comparing the effects of hourly or every-other-hour neurological examinations on sleep efficiency, wakefulness, and other sleep parameters in critically ill adult patients. Patients underwent transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasonography to assess cerebral blood flow velocity (CBFV) during the study to ensure that neurological assessments did not trigger deleterious cerebral ischemia or hemodynamic changes. The study included adult patients >18 years and <75 years of age during the 24 hours following elective non-ruptured cerebral aneurysm coiling surgeries, who were undergoing ventilator-supported sleep. Participants were excluded if they had past or current intracranial injury or disease or a history or diagnosis of cognitive impairment or lack of decision-making capacity. A total of 180 patients were randomly assigned to hourly or every-other-hour examinations. The primary outcome, sleep efficiency, was assessed by comparing the percentage of time spent asleep to the percentage of time spent in bed. A secondary outcome, arousals, was measured based on the number of arousals per hour. Other sleep outcomes included wakefulness, sleep quality (measured by a 15-item questionnaire), REM sleep, and deep sleep.

[/INST] The iENE study aimed to determine if extranodal extension (ENE) on imaging could help predict outcomes in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and whether or not there was a correlation between ENE on imaging and extranodal extension (ENE) on histopathology. The study utilized data from patients who were treated for HNSCC at five different centers. A total of 1,050 patients were included in the study, 449 radiologists from 16 different countries reviewed the case images in an attempt to discern the presence of ENE and whether extranodal extension on imaging could help predict outcomes in patients with HNSCC. The results showed that radiologists who scored extranodal extension on imaging well enough to classify disease with high accuracy, overall survival outcomes were independent of ENE on imaging in the presence of HPV. This study shows that radiologists can accurately predict HNSCC prognosis and treatment success without the need for invasive biopsies or nodal surgery. The study also points to the importance of incorporating PET/CT into the imaging workup, particularly for advanced staged disease. Overall, the study demonstrated the importance of incorporating standardized diagnostic classification systems to identify ENE on imaging, and that radiologists can reliably determine HNSCC prognosis through the use of such systems.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that compares the efficacy and safety of bedside bone biopsy (BSP) with conventional (surgical or radiologic) bone biopsy (CBB) for diagnosing patients with diabetes and diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) who are suspected to have DFO. The hypothesis is that BSP is non-inferior to CBB in terms of DFO outcomes and can be used as a simpler alternative procedure to document DFO. The primary outcome is the detection of bacteria on bone histopathology or microbiological culture, and the secondary outcomes include safety outcomes (infection, recurrence of ulcers, or hospitalizations), DFO remission, healing of diabetic ulcers, length and costs of hospital stays, and microbiological results (number of isolated bacteria and resistance). The study will be conducted following the CONSORT guidelines and is expected to be completed in mid-2024.

[/INST] Effect of Preoperative Prone Position Training on Pulmonary Complications in Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery was the title of a clinical trial. Participants included individuals over 18 years old who were diagnosed with colorectal cancer and underwent elective laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study is randomized with two groups: the intervention group received prone position training before surgery, while the control group received standard preoperative care. Prone position training was performed for at least 3 days before surgery and included three sessions per day lasting about 1 hour each. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications within 7 days of surgery. The study found a protective effect of prone position training on postoperative pulmonary complications.

[/INST] BLEX404 is a product obtained by the fractionation, ultrafiltration and sterilization of human plasma using the Amicon process. BAp acts on the biological immune response regulating cell proliferation, growth rate, and the number of B lymphocytes, neutrophils, and eosinophils.

[/INST] The Prevention REaSONable COVID-19 VACcine Trial (PREPARE-iVAC Trial) is a study that aims to investigate whether replacing MMF/MPA with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients results in superior immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period and will include 122 kidney transplant recipients. The recruitment status of the trial is currently unavailable as the clinical trial registry is not updated in real-time, however, the registration date is listed on the registry as April 20, 2022. The ethics approval status is not indicated on the clinical trial registry. The PREPARE-iVAC Trial was registered in the NLM's clinical registry system on April 20, 2022. The trial number is NCT05267911.

[/INST] The investigators conducted a prospective observational study to examine the use of contrast-based scans in children diagnosed with intestinal obstruction due to adhesions (IOA). The study was conducted at 9 children's hospitals in the Western Pediatric Surgery Research Consortium. The study included a total of 314 children, 110 of whom received enteral contrast, while 110 children did not receive contrast, and 94 children were diagnosed with a contrast examination after initial negative X-rays. The study found that there was no significant difference in failure rates for bowel obstruction between children who received contrast and those who did not. However, there was a lower median time to resolution and a shorter median hospital stay for children who received contrast compared to those who did not. The authors concluded that administering contrast-based scans to children with IOA could contribute to earlier resolution of bowel obstruction and shorter hospital stays.

The primary outcome is the PK parameters of itepekimab, which are assessed using the following parameters: Cmax (maximum plasma concentration of itepekimab), AUClast (area under the plasma concentration versus time curve calculated using the trapezoidal method from time zero to the real time tlast), and AUC (area under the plasma concentration versus time curve extrapolated to infinity). The study excludes participants who are not in good health, cannot read and understand the informed consent, and have a health condition that may interfere with the study's safety or results. The study also excludes participants who have taken part in any other medical study or taken any investigational drug during the past six months. The study will monitor the safety parameters, including pre-specified adverse events, serious adverse events, and AESI (adverse event of special interest). The safety of the study participants will be monitored throughout the study through predefined safety parameters and the appropriate medical management of any adverse effects.

Both groups had similar rates of response to IFX at 12 weeks, but for maintained remission, the combination group did better than monotherapy.

[/INST] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects neurons in the motor cortex, spinal cord, and brain stem. This results in progressive weakness and paralysis of muscles involved in respiration, swallowing, walking, and speech. Dyspnea, or difficulty in breathing, is a common symptom of ALS, often leading to respiratory failure and death. Nonspecific therapies such as non-invasive ventilation (NIV), which involves using a ventilator to assist patients with breathing during sleep and other times, can help alleviate dyspnea. The proposed study aims to evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on dyspnea in patients with ALS and NIV.

[/INST] This study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial comparing two interventions for urinary tract infections caused by the bacteria E. coli. Group A will receive reports from LabOuest, a microbiology laboratory in Loire Atlantique and Maine et Loire, France, with a list of narrow-spectrum antibiotics. Group B will receive standard antibiotic susceptibility testing reports from LabOuest, which will include a list of all antibiotics. The primary measure will be the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing in relation to the total number of urine cultures, defined as the number of urine cultures associated with broad-spectrum antibiotic prescriptions prescribed by the same GP, divided by the total number of urine cultures prescribed by the GP. The secondary measures include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing (defined as within five days after reporting antibiotic susceptibility testing results), the antibiotic de-escalation rate, the number of antibiotics received for each urine culture, the characteristics of the GP, the number of urine cultures per year per patient, and the characteristics of patients receiving the antibiotics.

[/INST] OLYMPIA-5 study is a phase 3 clinical trial that aims to compare the efficacy and safety of odronextamab combined with lenalidomide with rituximab and lenalidomide in treating relapsed or refractory follicular lymphoma (R/R FL) and other follicular B-cell lymphomas, including marginal zone lymphoma (R/R MZL), after at least 2 lines of previous systemic therapy. The trial will enroll patients who aged 18 years and above with an advanced type of lymphoma, either FL or MZL. These patients must have received at least one anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody and should meet the indication for treatment. Patients with active infection as defined in the protocol, primary central nervous system lymphoma or known involvement (either current or prior history of CNS NHL), primary diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, or any histology other than FL or MZL would not be eligible for this trial. Patients with any malignancy other than NHL, unless the malignancy is adequately and definitively treated and is cancer free for at least 3 years, will also be excluded from this trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either odronextamab and lenalidomide or R2 in part 2. Part 1 will be a separate phase to assess safety and dose-limiting toxicities. The treatment cycle will last for 28 days, and patients may receive up to 8 cycles of the study drug. The primary objective is to assess the safety and tolerability of odronextamab. The secondary objective is to assess the efficacy of odronextamab, including progression-free survival (PFS) and overall response rate (ORR). Patients will be evaluated for safety and efficacy of the study drugs, including tumor response, adverse events (AEs), pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic effects, and immunogenicity.

The patients who were already diagnosed with pneumothorax, pleural effusion, cardiac tamponade, or thoracic aortic dissection were excluded from participating in this study. Dyspneic patients referred to the ED who were included in the study would be evaluated by experienced emergency physicians according to the local care routines. After assessing the patient, the investigators would ask for the written consent to conduct this study. Patients who consent to the study would undergo a structured heart, lung, and inferior vena cava ultrasound exam by one of the emergency physicians or residents certified in the POCUS dyspnea protocol. The diagnostic value of the POCUS assessment of patients (heart, lung, IVC) would be evaluated and compared to the final diagnosis. Study results were published in 2021. [/INST] This study aimed to better understand the relationship between gut microbiota composition and prostate cancer. Prostate microbiota plays a critical role in prostate health status. The researchers collected over 300 stool samples from 100 patients with prostate cancer and compared their gut microbiota before and after treatment with androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and prostate cancer medication (5-alpha reductase inhibitors). The study found that long-term ADT therapy had significant associations with microbiome dysbiosis and that prior medication use was associated with specific taxonomic changes, suggesting that prior medication may affect the effectiveness of ADT. The results of this study provide a clearer understanding of the potential role of gut microbiota dysbiosis in prostate cancer etiology, which may lead to the development of more effective therapies for prostate cancer in the future. This study is also essential to gain insight into the possible implications of prior prostate medication on the effectiveness of ADT. Therefore, it is crucial to assess whether the use of prior medication influences the response to ADT and to determine whether this response can be used to guide clinical decision making.

The study will also explore the feasibility of utilizing diffusion MRI metrics (specifically apparent diffusion coefficient [ADC]) and amide proton transfer signal as quantitative MRI parameters, which may correlate with changes in metabolism measured by PME. The study will analyze 200 patients who are diagnosed with ACLF within a year after obtaining Institutional Ethics Committee approval. [/INST] In this clinical trial, investigators will assess the efficacy of onabotulinum toxin A, i.e., Botox, for the treatment of glabellar lines. They will compare the outcomes of treatment when the depth of injection of this neurotoxin is 2 mm vs 4 mm. Glabellar lines appear with repeated muscle activity of the glabellar complex and are a common sign of facial aging. While Botox is currently the standard of care for facial lines, the optimal depth of injection has not yet been established. Based on previous studies, investigators hypothesize that there will be no significant difference in efficacy when Botox is injected at a depth of 2 mm vs 4 mm. This study will help determine the best depth of injection for Botox and other neurotoxins.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a randomized control study with the primary goal of evaluating the impact of music therapy on breast cancer patients who experience anxiety. Patients included in the trial have localized breast cancer indicating adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy and who are over 18 years old. Patients are excluded from the trial if they have already received chemotherapy, are triple negative, or are unable to complete questionnaires due to cognitive or communication deficits. The music therapy will consist of providing calming music to patients before their chemotherapy session for a total of three music therapy sessions. The primary outcome measure is the change in state-trait anxiety in patients before the first and third chemotherapy sessions measured by the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) score. The trial is a proof-of-concept study that aims to provide a better understanding of the potential benefits of music therapy to reduce anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. There was no mention in the summary of how music therapy is implemented by the clinical trial.

[/INST] The study is “To Evaluate Different Conditioning Regimens for HLA Matched HSCT in SAA”. Severe aplastic anemia (SAA) and very severe aplastic anemia (vSAA) are blood diseases in which the bone marrow fails to produce healthy blood cells. This study is designed as a randomized controlled trial, comparing two types of conditioning regimens for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT): 1) Busulfan-fludarabine/cyclophosphamide/anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG) or 2) Cyclophosphamide/anti-thymocyte globulin (Cy/ATG). The intervention of Busulfan was excluded from the control group, while Fludarabine was substituted. The primary end point of this trial is failure-free survival. This is defined as surviving with a response to the HSCT. Failure-free survival is measured over a period of 1 year post HSCT. The secondary end points being analyzed are mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, acute and chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD), CMV and EBV reactivation, transplantation-related mortality, overall survival, and the incidence of these outcomes.

[/INST] This is a study on the effectiveness of the prophylactic drug fitusiran (a subcutaneous injection) for the prevention of bleeding in people with severe hemophilia. The study includes participants aged 18 years or older with severe hemophilia A who have previously used emicizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody for the prevention of bleeding. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with adverse events during the fitusiran treatment period. The study will also evaluate the peak thrombin generation, peak antithrombin levels, and emicizumab concentrations in plasma. Other secondary measures will be the change in participant's overall treatment satisfaction during the fitusiran treatment period, preference for fitusiran or emicizumab, pain intensity, physical functioning, physical activity, joint health, annualized bleeding rate, and annualized joint bleed rate while receiving fitusiran prophylaxis. The study will include 48 participants who will undergo 18 months of treatment with fitusiran prophylaxis. The study is expected to be completed in May 2026.

[/INST] The study translates and tests the validity and reliability of the painDETECT Questionnaire in Malay. PainDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ) is a reliable diagnostic tool for pain types such as neuropathic or nociceptive pain and also evaluates its intensity, frequency, association with pain modulation factors. PDQ was an early painDETECT Questionnaire for identifying neuropathic pain. This study will translate and evaluate the validity and reliability of the final Malay version of painDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ-M) in Malay by using painDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ) in German. The sample size was divided into two groups, those who have Neuropathic Pain and those who have Nociceptive Pain, and filled out PDQ-M, Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) and SF-36 questionnaires. The data collected are analysed using Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS) by using a reliability analysis test (parametric tests) to test reliability, Content Validity Index (CVI) for content validity, and Pearson correlation test and Spearman correlation test to test validity. The results of this study can be used as a guide in the use of painDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ) as a screening diagnostic tool for neuropathic or nociceptive pain in Malaysia. It will contribute to the knowledge of neuropathic pain in the health of the population.

[/INST] The trial aims to investigate the effect of community rehabilitation exercise on the function, fall resistance, and quality of life of stroke patients. The study is conducted through a randomized control trial in which one group receives a 6-week community rehabilitation exercise program and a control group who receive a regular exercise program. Primary outcomes include walking endurance as assessed by the 6-minute walk test. Secondary outcomes include fall risk and balance as assessed by Berg Balance Scale, walking function and disability as assessed by the modified Rankin Scale, walking speed and endurance as assessed by the functional ambulations category and a timed up and go test, lower limb muscle function as assessed by the manual muscle test, quality of life as assessed by EQ-5D, depressive symptoms as assessed by the geriatric depression scale.

[/INST] A Phase III trial examined ABBV-552 in the treatment of mild AD (Alzheimer's disease) in older adults, and to compare the safety and tolerability of ABBV-552 with the placebo. ABBV-552 was taken in a variety of doses: A-50 mg, B-100 mg, or C-150 mg, one capsule a day, over 12 weeks. The Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog) was used to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the therapy and to compare ABBV-552 to the placebo.

[/INST] The study is a case-control study on the outcomes in liver failure patients that presented in the ICU. The purpose of the study is to assess the causes, complications, and prognosis of patients with liver failure. The criteria for inclusion in the study are reduced consciousness level, jaundice, abnormal liver function tests, coagulopathy, and multiple organ failure. The inclusion criteria are age between 18 to 75 and they were admitted to the ICU due to acute liver failure (ALF) and acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF). They will be examined clinically and undergo abdominal ultrasound, chest X-ray, and echocardiography. Laboratory tests such as biochemical analysis will also be done to measure the levels of ALT, AST, GGT, bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time. Patients with known cardiac cirrhosis and pre-existing renal disease are not included in the study.

[/INST] The study investigates the relationship between impulsivity and coping skills with the quality of life (QoL) in bipolar disorder (BD). The study is descriptive with a cross-sectional approach. This study is important because it evaluates the effect of impulsivity and coping skills on QoL in bipolar patients. The study intends to develop an intervention that will increase the QoL of bipolar patients by increasing the coping skills and decreasing the impulsivity.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to compare the clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions with the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), which is a multi-color composite resin material, using modified USPHS and FDI criteria. This is a double-blind, parallel-group, prospective randomized controlled clinical trial. The primary outcomes are the clinical performance of restorations according to the modified United States Public Health Service criteria and World Dental Organization criteria. The secondary outcomes are retention, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, and postoperative sensitivity. The study duration is 24 months with 6-month intervals. The null hypotheses of this study are 1) It is concluded that there is no difference between 2 different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in terms of clinical performance in restorations of non-carious cervical lesions and 2) it is assumed that universal composite resin materials are not different from the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), in terms of clinical performance in restorations of non-carious cervical lesions. The main strength of the study is that it is double-blind and randomized.
[/INST] Title: Effect of Neuromuscular Reversal Agents on Time for Neurological Assessment After Endotracheal Intubation in Critically Ill Patients

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a behavioral intervention, namely a telemedicine-based cognitive-behavioral weight loss intervention. The intervention will be compared to standard supportive care (i.e., a health plan provided to the study participants based on the standard of care provided in the participating centers) for reducing the recurrence of endometrial hyperplasia or progression of endometrial cancer in women with obesity and diagnosed with grade 1 endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer. The study is a phase IV, randomized controlled crossover trial with a sample size of 72 participants. The primary outcome measure for the study is a measure of adenocarcinoma and AEH-free disease. The study is ongoing, and the primary completion date is November 2023.

[/INST] In this study, the authors describe a new technique called the “coconut technique” for cholecystectomy in patients with stage II acute cholecystitis according to the Tokyo guidelines. The technique involves making an incision in a safe zone at the junction of the infundibulum and the body of the gallbladder, identifying the confluence between the cystic duct and the body of the gallbladder, clipping the cystic duct, and then performing the cholecystectomy. They report a success rate of 3/3.

[/INST] The study explores the effect of cognitive behavioral therapy and virtual reality use in inured athletes. The study is a randomized controlled trial with four arms: 1) cognitive behavioral therapy and virtual reality (CBT+VR), 2) cognitive behavioral therapy with no VR (CBT), 3) VR with no CBT (VR), and 4) control (no CBT or VR). The study enrolled 60 athletes who have undergone ACL surgery. The primary outcome measures are re-injury anxiety, adherence, self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia. The primary outcomes will be measured every 3 months after ACL surgery. The results show that CBT+VR can help reduce psychosocial issues experienced by athletes after injuries and support the recovery process. However, more well-designed clinical trials are needed to confirm the potential effect of this intervention.

[/INST] The analysis of a stepless experiment of the PT-PENCIL device involves the integration of a PT-PENCIL device into EHR, which is a device that aids in discharging individuals. This tool incorporates a predictive model to measure home-related discharge status and recommends the frequency of physical therapy. The purpose of this study was to assess the use of PT-PENCIL to improve the percentage of patients who could be discharged, and to assess the reach of the PT-PENCIL device, and adoption using RE-AIM. The effectiveness of the evaluation on the percentage of discharges was measured and the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness and feasibility.

[/INST] The aim of this clinical trial is to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of 7-Form of Taijiquan Exercise Healing in treating mCRC patients. The study is a single-arm, exploratory, uncontrolled clinical trial with an eight-week intervention. The trial will be conducted with 40 mCRC patients receiving Taijiquan instruction three times a week for eight weeks. The efficacy of the intervention will be assessed using questionnaires to evaluate the quality of life, depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, fatigue, and sleep quality of the participants. The study will focus on exploring the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of Taijiquan intervention in treating mCRC patients and promoting their life quality. The trial is expected to provide preliminary data for future large multi-center studies and provide valuable evidence to complement or substitute for conventional treatment for mCRC patients.

[/INST] The Survivorship ECHO project is a clinical trial that evaluates the effectiveness and implementation of an educational program on cancer survivorship best practices to improve provider's knowledge, clinical care, and accessibility. Participants include health providers, such as registered nurses, radiation oncologists, and oncologists, from The James Cancer Network in Ohio. The one-hour, six-session educational intervention is conducted through The Survivorship Network and offers weekly didactic rounds with multi-disciplinary experts on the topics of survivorship. The project aims to assess the effect of the intervention on provider knowledge through pre- and post-surveys and interviews. The primary outcome is a change in providers' levels of understanding of key survivorship knowledge areas using a Likert survey. The study lasts for one year with baseline testing at the start. The content, participants' needs, and aspects of delivering the Survivorship ECHO program will be analyzed for future improvements.

[/INST] The study "Comparison of Post Facilitation Stretch and Maitland Mobilization in Post-traumatic Stiff Elbow" is a single-center, randomized controlled trial (RCT). The study was conducted with participants who presented with a limited range of elbow joint motion due to trauma. The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch (PFS) and Maitland mobilization (MM) in improving elbow ROM and reducing self-reported pain at 4 weeks post-intervention. The sample size was determined to be 32, calculated using G-Power software. Participants were randomized into two groups: the PFS group and the MM group. The intervention comprised six sessions of 4-weeks (three sessions per week) of PFS or MM. The researchers applied PFS for 6-10 s, whereas MM applied oscillations per second for the duration of 1 min, followed by 5 sets per day for 4 weeks. The ROM and self-reported pain on a numerical rating scale (NRS) were the primary outcome measures. The secondary measure was the DASH (Disability of the arm, shoulder and hand) questionnaire at 4 weeks. The study was double-blinded and conducted in a parallel group design. The results indicated that Maitland mobilization has superior results in ROM, pain, and DASH scores at 4 weeks, making it a more promising treatment for post-traumatic stiff elbow.

[/INST] The study evaluates the effects of a multidisciplinary approach using a combination of the NT-proBNP test and Us2.ai (AI-enabled report) handheld echocardiogram to diagnose heart failure. The trial is designed to assess the effectiveness of the intervention in detecting heart failure and subsequently prescribing appropriate treatment within 6 months. The primary endpoint is a heart failure diagnosis within 6 months of the initial presentation. The secondary endpoint is receiving correct guideline-directed medical therapy within 6 months of the initial presentation.

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and implications of internet-based cognitive-behavioral treatment (ICBT) for panic disorder, social phobia, and major depression over two years. The study examines a Guided Internet-Delivered Cognitive Therapy (eMeistring) program, which is based on the principle of cognitive functional therapy for anxiety and depression. The study will compare this intervention to standard healthcare treatments. The study will involve multiple assessments and questionnaires to examine various variables such as health-related quality of life, symptom reduction, socioeconomic status, and usability of the internet-based treatment. The study will also examine the cost-effectiveness of the program. Multiple follow-ups will be conducted to assess the long-term effectiveness of the program. The protocol provides information on the sample and procedures, interventions, outcomes, terms, and background. The study may provide valuable information on a cost-effective treatment method that is easily accessible to patients.

[/INST] The following study measures the ability of the novel pulse oximeters to accurately measure blood oxygen saturation levels and adjust for skin tone in patients of color. The study will enroll patients between the ages of 18-65 who are healthy and willing to be exposed to the pulse oximeter devices for 90 minutes. Participants will answer questions about their comfort with the device after the study period. Researchers will ask participants to remove the device so they can measure their skin tones, after which they will begin calibration with the pulse device oximeter (MABOS and Nonin PureSat). The 90-minute period will consist of a 20-minute rest, followed by light exercise for 10 minutes to mimic exercise tolerance, and then 20 minutes to allow participants to relax and resume normal activity. After participants are calibrated, the pulse oximeters will be utilized for 90 minutes while the participants perform light exercise and relax. The device will then be removed, and the participants will follow up with a survey to assess their comfort and safety with the device. Then, the novel pulse oximeter will be compared to FDA-approved pulse oximeters to assess its accuracy in skin tone and oxygen saturation. The results of the study will indicate whether the novel pulse oximeter is more accurate in obtaining oxygen saturation levels in patients with darker skin tones than the current pulse oximeters. Thus, the study will demonstrate the necessity of pulse oximeters that are designed to address the differences in skin tone and accuracy of oxygen saturation levels.

[/INST] The title of this document is "Interferon-Beta-1a (FP-1201) to Prevent Toxicities After CD19-Directed CAR T-Cell Therapy." The study is a phase 1/2 study with the primary objective of evaluating the safety and tolerability of interferon-beta-1a (FP-1201) in preventing CAR T-cell therapy-induced neurotoxicity. The study will investigate the safety and efficacy of FP-1201 when administered alone or with lymphodepletion chemotherapy. The secondary objective of the study is to evaluate the anti-tumor efficacy of FP-1201 and CAR T-cell therapy. The study will enroll patients with recurrent B acute lymphoblastic leukemia, recurrent B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, refractory B acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or refractory B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

[/INST] This clinical trial involves the use of two targeted breast cancer therapies: camrelizumab, a monoclonal antibody that blocks the PD-1 pathway, and famitinib, a small-molecule inhibitor of tyrosine kinase . The objective of the study is to determine the safety and efficacy of camrelizumab in combination with chemotherapy and famitinib versus chemotherapy in patients with triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). The study is double-blinded. Patients with TNBC (absence of hormone receptors and HER2) at an early or locally advanced stage will be enrolled in the trial. The primary endpoint is the pathological complete response rate. The trial will assess the response rate, safety, progression-free survival, and overall survival of the patients. The trial will enroll 770 patients across China and will randomize them into a control group or a treatment group. Participants in the control group will receive chemotherapy consisting of albumin-paclitaxel and carboplatin. Participants in the treatment group will receive the same chemotherapy regimen plus camrelizumab and famitinib. Famitinib and camrelizumab will be administered once weekly for 6 weeks followed by 1-week break for 1 week, up to the maximum 9 cycles. The study is planned to end in June 2027.

[/INST] This is a case-control study that aim's to investigate the relationship between risk factors present at 24-28 weeks gestational age (GA) and postpartum glucose intolerance, as measured by the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). To do this, the authors collected data through questionnaires and blood samples, and measured maternal and fetal placental levels of lipids and metabolites. They then used machine learning algorithms to develop a prediction model to predict postpartum glucose intolerance based on these data. They found that metabolic molecules in the mother's blood and placental fatty acids could be predictors of postpartum glucose intolerance, and that these factors could potentially be used to identify high-risk cases during pregnancy for targeted management and to reduce the incidence of postpartum glucose metabolism disorders.

[/INST] The study investigates the impact of a device that provides EEG-guided sleep protection procedures on sleep quality in critically ill hospitalized patients treated in the intensive care unit. The device aims to prioritize sleep and provide a comfortable environment and reduce noise and other interruptions. Sleep was assessed using polysomnography (PSG), and sleep quality was defined as continuous sleep of at least 30 cycles in a 30-second epoch. Sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and light, and interruptions from the healthcare team were also measured. The study's secondary measures include workloads, ICU and hospital LOS, and patient agitation and anxiety. The study will recruit 106 patients who will undergo PSG for one hour on day two of their ICU stay. The results showed that the device significantly improved sleep quality. The improvements were particularly significant in patients who were mechanically ventilated and/or sedated and non-intubated. The devices also allowed a reduction in interruptions from the healthcare team and an improvement in sleep continuity.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a phase II, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging study that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 in combination with methotrexate (MTX) compared to MTX or placebo in adults with moderate-to-severely active rheumatoid arthritis (RA) over a 14-week treatment period. Participants will be randomized into one of five groups to receive either a dose of SAR441566 or placebo in combination with MTX, or to receive a single agent: MTX, SAR441566, or placebo.

[/INST] The study "Prospective Clinical Performance Evaluation of the In-Vitro Diagnostics Medical Device MaGIA IBC for the ComIned screENing of HIV, Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C " is a Single-arm clinical trial with an aim to evaluate the performance and convenience at the POC of the test MagIA IBC for the diagnosis of HIV, HCV, and HVB. The test performance will be evaluated by the ROC AUC for diagnosis of HIV, HCV, and HVB. Also, the sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of HIV, HCV, and HVB will be measured based on a reference standard. For analysis of concordance of diagnostic results, Kappa Cohen Coefficient will be used. The study related adverse events will be assessed as safety outcome.

[/INST] The study will recruit patients with chronic HF to examine the effects of Endocalyx® supplementation on glycocalyx restoration and other cardiovascular markers. The primary endpoint is the difference in NT-proBNP levels between the Endocalyx® group and the placebo group at 8 weeks of supplementation. The secondary endpoints include change in total body water and body weight, and change in heart rate, cardiac output, and total peripheral resistance measured by Nexfin. The study will also assess biomarkers of cardiovascular outcomes such as monocyte subsets, inflammatory mediators, chemokines, scavenger pathways and surface proteins. The study also aims to determine the differential treatment effect of Endocalyx® in male and female patients.

The study included 120 participants who met the eligibility criteria, with 60 allocated to the intervention group and 60 allocated to the control group. Participants in the intervention group were given oral antibiotic prophylaxis preoperatively, while participants in the control group underwent mechanical bowel preparation only. The main outcome of the study is suture failure or anastomotic leak. [/INST] This is a single-center, cross sectional clinical trial that aims to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel for diagnosing CTS. The study encompasses patients referred to the Department of Neurology of the Jagiellonian University Medical College in Cracow, Poland with symptoms suggestive of CTS and CTS confirmed in NCS or US. Subjects will be allocated into two parallel groups: patients with CTS.and healthy controls. The diagnosis of CTS will be confirmed with US and NCS in patients. The measurements to be performed at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel include the diameter and echogenicity of the median nerve, and the cross-sectional area of the median nerve. The data concerning the diameters and echogenicity of the median nerve at the point of the maximal stenosis will be presented as the mean value and standard deviation. The cross-sectional area of the median nerve will be presented as mean value and standard deviation as well as 95% confidence intervals.
