[/INST] The aim of this study was to examine the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at cervical, lumbar, and scapular levels in archery athletes. The study was conducted among the athletes, where they were assessed with Craniocervical Flexion Test, Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, Lateral Scapular Slide Test, Sahrmann's Core Stability Test, Abdominal Drawing-in Test, Isokinetic Contraction Strength Test, and Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test. The shooting performance of the athletes was measured via seven 72 arrows. It was found that archery athletes with good shooting performance had better scores for stabilization and stabilization-related parameters compared to the archery athletes with bad shooting performance. This is the first study that examined the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance in archery athletes. The findings of this study can have an important contribution to archery athletes to improve shooting performance.

[/INST] This study aims to develop and evaluate the efficacy of an artificial intelligence (AI)-based communication training tool for pediatricians. The study will be conducted in three stages. In the first stage of the study, the investigators will analyze 50 clinical encounters between adolescents, parent, and physicians to determine a comprehensive evaluation framework using self-administered post-visit surveys. In the second stage, the qualitative data obtained from focus groups, group interactions, and feedback from physicians will serve as inputs to refine the AI communication training tool. The third stage will evaluate whether implementation of the AI communication training tool improves pediatrician communication skills and experiences within a real-life clinical setting. This study contributes to training programs to enhance pediatricians' confidence and effective communication skills and can be applied to other areas.

In addition, it seeks to identify health disparities across different groups, including the association between vitiligo and mental health conditions, healthcare utilization, and the impact on work (time off work and unemployment).

[/INST] The Clinical Trial title is "[The Effect of Self-efficacy and Relationship Through Behavior Modification by Hybrid Mode (RCT)]". The authors aimed to investigate the effects of the intervention on mental health and parenting effectiveness. Specifically, the trial focuses on caregivers of children with developmental delay. The study was randomized into a self-learning group and a hybrid group. The Self-learning group was designed to provide a description of the course's goal and a reading of the book "Atomic Habit" by James Clear. In contrast, the Hybrid group used Atomic Habits as the main intervention, role structure and game-based learning, online schedule reminders, and individual consultation sessions. The primary outcome measures included intervention fidelity and caregiver involvement. The secondary outcome measures include parenting stress index short form, Conflict Tactics Scales Parent Version, and the satisfaction questionnaire.

[/INST] Trotabresib is a selective, potent small-molecule inhibitor of MLL family histone methyltransferases. Participants will undergo weekly ECOG assessments, MRI scans at baseline and prior to cycle 5, and tumor biopsies prior and following treatment. For intracranial disease, the objective is to achieve sterilization in at least one lesion not treated with radiotherapy.

Both groups were set to meet for 6 months, with each intended to receive 2-hour meetings per week of treatment, where both groups received 10 sessions of tele-health sessions, which included discussion on binge eating, diet, and physical activity.

[/INST] The Clinical Trial named Pregnancy Women and Individual Oral Prophylaxis in the Control of Gingival Inflammation (PRE-IOP) aims to investigate the effect of different manual and electric toothbrushes on the control of the Gingival Inflammation during pregnancy in a randomized study. From selected pregnant women (15-18 weeks pregnant, aged 18 to 40 years, not taking medication affecting the gums, without interdental brushes and/or dental floss and/or mouthwash, systemic disorder such as blood disorders, diabetes, and risk of endocarditis infections), 4 groups will be formed, each group using a specific type of toothbrush: manual Curaprox 5460, another manual toothbrush, a sonic toothbrush (Sonicare DiamondClean 9000) and a hydrosonic toothbrush. The participants will use the toothbrush provided daily during 3 months. During a 60-day interval between the recruitment of the last patient and the end of the study, every participant will be assessed based on incidence of gingival bleeding from baseline, Change of gingival inflammation, PPD, GI, CAL and Plaque Index and Customer Satisfaction by oral examination and interview to assess the answers to standardized questionnaires with a structured interview regarding the participants' satisfaction with each kind of toothbrush tested. The primary outcome of this study, which is scheduled visit at 3 months, will also include an analysis of Bleeding on Probing, clinical attachment loss and loss of probing depth.

[/INST] This is a two-week observational clinical trial that aims to determine if controlled nasal breathing can improve memory. Participants were randomly assigned to a control, mouth-breathing, or nose-breathing group. Baseline memory was assessed with a computer-based task, followed by a two-week intervention period. During the intervention, the nose-breathing group performed controlled nostril breathing, each group took a memory test, and the control group did not receive any intervention. Two weeks later, all groups repeated the computer-based task to determine if any training had a lasting effect on memory. The breathing intervention consisted of controlled slow and deep breathing practiced under supervision for two weeks at predetermined times. The study found no effect of nostril breathing on memory when compared to mouth breathing control group and no control group.

[/INST] This study evaluates the effectiveness of a calisthenics exercises program and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function following burn injuries. Patients with burns of any part of the body who have a BMI between 30 and 45 and are aged between 20 and 45 years of age will be included in the study. The calisthenics exercises program includes exercises with medium intensity and medium-long duration, performed for 3 days a week over a period of 3 months. Dynamic calisthenic exercises, including lunges, shoulder taps, Russian twists, plank, upper limb crunches, push-ups, dips, hip elevations, and legs elevations were included. The electromagnetic field applied in the PEMF device was induced through two sets of electromagnet coils located below the base of the patient's head and shoulder area. Each group will be instructed to visit the research centre at the end of the third month of the study. The results of the study will be based on liver function tests, such as aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels, which will be used as the study parameters to determine liver damage. All groups will receive conventional burn treatment.

[/INST] The “NutriCim” study is a clinical trial examining the effects of a nutritional intervention on patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and lung cancer being treated with immunotherapy, including clinical outcomes, immune response, and microbiome parameters. The dietary supplement to be used is an oral nutritional supplement consisting of high protein, high energy and specific nutrients that are believed to have immune-modulatory properties. The aim of the study is to investigate whether the nutritional intervention can contribute to improving the efficacy of immunotherapy, potentially resulting in improved clinical outcomes. The trial is currently enrolling participants. Participants are required to meet the following inclusion criteria: being between the ages of 18 and 75 and having a diagnosis of stage IV or recurrent NSCLC and an ECOG performance status of 0-2. Major exclusion criteria include allergies to cow's milk protein, soy or fish, intolerance to galactose or other specific sugars, major renal or liver impairment, and active concomitant systemic disorders. This information helps to define the specific inclusion and exclusion criteria for subjects who may be enrolled in this study based on a high-level overview, it is important to note that this information is limited and for informational purpose only and there may be further details missing.

[/INST] The study is a part of the Innovative Medicine Initiative (IMI) consortium named “Integrins and Protocadherins in Glutamatergic Circuits: Identification of Common Signaling Pathways and Molecular Targets in Anxiety and Depressive Disorders (GAPsy). The study will involve 20 participants, 10 healthy participants and 10 participants with anxiety-depressive disorder. The aim of the study is to understand the role of integrin β3 and protocadherin 9 in glutamatergic neurotransmission. The study will use a 7T MRI scanner in the study. The outcomes of the study are not known.

[/INST] The purpose of the study was to investigate the correlations between cardiovascular diseases, neurological diseases and intestinal microbiota. The study used multi-omics sequencing methods to collect and analyze fecal and blood samples from patients with various cardiovascular and neurological diseases. The main outcome of interest is a description of the intestinal microbiota and characterization of its potential role in the development and progression of cardiovascular and neurological diseases.

[/INST] The goal of this phase II trial is to evaluate whether combining radiomic analysis, KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations, and imaging data will improve the accuracy of identifying advanced NSCLC patients with PDL1 TPS ≥ 50% who will benefit from 1st line pembrolizumab therapy. The trial is split into two parts: Stage I will involve 10 patients to determine the best parameters for radiomic analysis and identification of the KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutation. Stage II of the trial, which is a non-randomised observational trial, will use the data acquired from Stage I to determine the prognostic value of radiomic analysis and the KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutation and to evaluate the predictive value of pre-therapeutic FDG-FDG PET/CT scans.

[/INST] Sacituzumab govitecan with or without atezolizumab therapy for patients with genitourinary carcinomas. The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of sacituzumab govitecan with or without atezolizumab in patients with metastatic genitourinary cancer (including small cell, urothelial, and penile cancer). The primary endpoints are the objective response rate in the treatment groups and best overall response rate after at least 1 dose. The study will enroll patients with histologically confirmed small cell carcinoma of the bladder or urinary tract, squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder or urinary tract, primary adenocarcinoma of the bladder or urinary tract (urachal or non-urachal), renal medullary carcinoma, or squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. Participation in the study is restricted to individuals aged at least 18 years, with measurable disease per RECIST v1.1, with or without progressive disease outside of the central nervous system. Exclusion criteria for the study include participants that have received prior immunotherapy or are currently receiving systemic hormonal therapy, participants with prior history of severe hypersensitivity or allergic reactions to compounds of similar chemical or biologic composition to SN-38, patients with an ongoing immune-mediated disease, and active infections.

[/INST] The study entitled "Effectiveness of a Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation" is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of two types of exercises, i.e., proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation and eccentric exercises with electrical stimulation, in improving ankle dorsiflexion in professional padel players. The study will use two tests to evaluate the effectiveness of the exercises performed, namely, the lunge test, which measures ankle dorsiflexion range, and the drop jump test, which measures the range of knee valgus in vertical jumps. The outcomes of this study will provide information about the effectiveness of the exercises used to improve ankle dorsiflexion and consequently prevent padel-related injuries in professionals involved in this sport. The study design details, eligibility criteria, study measures, and other relevant information have been described in an unbiased and concise manner. The study summary is suitable for readers who may come across the study's clinical trial registry database.

[/INST] This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a participatory refugee parenting curriculum in improving parenting knowledge, child behavior, and parental efficacy among refugee families in Tijuana, Mexico. The study will be conducted as a community-based, participatory research with a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. Refugee parents who participate in the study will be randomly assigned to either a parenting group (intervention group), which receives a culturally adapted parenting curriculum, or a waitlist control group, which receives the same parenting curriculum after a 4-week delay. The proposed parenting curriculum is adapted from a variety of existing curricula, including COMPASS, Generation PMTO, Happy Families, and Family Strengthening Intervention for Refugees (FSI-R). Key outcome measures include parenting knowledge, child behavior and parental efficacy, observed parent child interaction, parental stress, and qualitative feedback from both intervention and waitlist control groups. The study will also collect sociodemographic and background information to better understand the context and needs of the participants. The duration of the intervention is 4 weeks, and both intervention and control groups will receive the same parenting curriculum following the study baseline assessment. The follow-up time points are two months post-intervention. The study aims to address a critical gap in research and service delivery efforts for refugee families. This study intends to identify the most appropriate parenting curriculum to meet the unique needs of refugee families in Tijuana, Mexico, and it will also contribute to enhancing existing mental health support services for these communities.

[/INST] This study will use various types of qualitative research to identify areas for improvement and to facilitate local solutions for better care experiences for people with incurable head and neck cancer, through co-design.

[/INST] The title of the paper is Clinical application of indocyanine green fluorescence imaging in assisted localization of nerve roots under endoscopy in spinal surgery.. The aim of this study is to compare the effect of ICG intravenous injection on ICG fluorescence and nerve root identification in endoscopy spinal surgery. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment. 80 patients with degenerative disc herniation will be included in this study. Each patient will be randomized into a no intervention (control), 0.5mg/kg ICG, 1mg/kg ICG or 2mg/kg ICG group. The outcomes will be measured intra-operatively and post-operatively. The intraoperative outcomes are fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, fluorescence signal ratio of the nerve root to background fluorescence and time taken to find the nerve root under endoscopic procedures, while the postoperative outcomes are ICG-related adverse reactions, visual analogue scale (VAS) pain, Oswestry disability index (ODI) and surgical complications.

[/INST] This study examined the effectiveness of a home-based parenting support program called "Parenting Young Children" in increasing parenting competence and satisfying goals set by parents with intellectual or developmental disabilities. The program included up to six sessions that lasted between 30 to 90 min, over a minimum of six months. The study found the program to have positive effects on parenting satisfaction and parental sense of competence. However, its effects on occupational and goal attainment were not significant. The study found that the intervention was not superior to treatment as usual concerning all the dependent measures. The study has implications for parents with intellectual or developmental disabilities. However, it also had limitations, such as high group attrition, which may have affected the results.

[/INST] The "Observational Study for Patients Undergoing Surgery for Male Stress Urinary Incontinence" is a study conducted in Italy that aims to evaluate the efficacy of two surgical treatments for male stress urinary incontinence (SUI): 1) artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) and 2) sling. The study includes patients who have given informed consent, are men, and are undergoing surgery for SUI using one of the two devices. The evaluation of the outcomes of both the AUS and sling groups will continue for 5 years post-surgery and the study will collect information about patient characteristics, preoperative and postoperative examinations, complications and reoperation, urinary continence based on a 24-hour pad test, and patient-reported outcomes. The primary outcome of the study is the success rate, which is defined as being urinary continent with no need for pad use or using just once a day. Overall time being continent will be presented using the Kaplan-Meier curve from 12 weeks to 5 years post-surgery, and the overall revision-free time will also be presented with the Kaplan-Meier curve from 12 weeks to 5 years post-surgery. Secondary outcomes are time being continent, time being revision-free, revision-free rate, patient-reported quality of life, and general and specific adverse events. The study concludes that both AUS and sling procedures are efficient in treating male SUI. However, it also states that both techniques lack definitive evidence of cost-effectiveness and require more research to explore the safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of these treatments.

[/INST] The study is a test of a radioactive substance (68Ga-NOTA-H006) injected intravenously before imaging. The main purpose of this test is to evaluate the relationship between the uptake of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 and 5T4 immune factors in cancer patients. The main measurement used is SUV. The sample size is unknown as it mentions "all".

[/INST] This study involves heart failure (HF) patients eligible for cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) who will receive a CRT implant. A control group comprising of HF patients on medical therapy who do not meet CRT indication criteria will also be recruited. Blood samples, clinical data (echocardiography, ECG, medical records), and a heart biopsy will be collected before implantation. CRT responder status, LVEF, and biomarkers to differentiate CRT responders from non-responders in blood will be assessed at 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year. Endothelial function and RBC tests using EndoPAT and RBC will be conducted at baseline and 1-year follow-up. The study plans to complete enrollment in 2024 and the total duration of the trial is expected to be 5 years.

[/INST] The ESC Team at University College London Hospital (UCLH) is a new initiative that implements early supportive care for cancer patients. The study "Prognostic Understanding in Patients Receiving ESC" aims to evaluate this initiative by assessing patients' prognostic understanding of their illness and the associated psychological distress, health-related quality of life, trust in the medical team, and perceived quality of care. Participants included are advanced cancer patients who are referred to the UCLH ESC Team. Patients will be asked to complete a questionnaire which will cover their prognostic awareness, sociodemographic and clinical data, as well as their psychological symptoms, including anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. The investigators will then analyze the data to assess the associations between prognostic awareness, psychological symptoms, and other aspects of perceived quality of care. The target population is advanced cancer patients referred to the ESC Team at UCLH. The inclusion criteria for the study were that participants must be at least 18 years of age, have enough English proficiency to complete the questionnaires, and be referred to the ESC Team at UCLH. The exclusion criteria were participants who were younger than 18 years, had insufficient English proficiency to complete the questionnaires, and the participants who, in the opinion of the member of the ESC team, were not appropriate to participate due to any other reason not stated in the study plan. The prognostic understanding was measured through the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. Patients also rated their symptoms of anxiety and depression using the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 (PHQ-2) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder 2-item (GAD-2) scales. Health-related quality of life and other aspects of perceived quality of care were assessed on a visual analogue scale (NRS) from 0-10. Data are analyzed using univariable and multivariable regression analyses.

[/INST] As a concise summary, this clinical trial, titled "Effect of Direct-from-Blood Bacterial Testing on Antibiotic Administration and Clinical Outcomes," aims to compare the use of direct-from-blood bacterial testing using T2 Bacteria panels and conventional care in patients with bloodstream infections, sepsis, MRSA bacteremia, or vancomycin-related bacteremia.

[/INST] The study "The Effect of Temperature-elevating Armbaths (Hauffe-Schwenniger-Batterie) as a Therapeutic Option to Regulate the Blood Pressure in People With Arterial Hypertension - a Randomized-controlled Trial" is a randomized controlled trial that evaluates the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths in people with arterial hypertension. The study is a randomized-controlled trial with two arms: an intervention group that performs temperature-elevating armbaths and a waitlist control group that continues their treatment as usual but will receive instructions on how to perform the armtub bath after the study is completed. The primary outcome measure is the blood pressure, which will be measured at baseline and after 8 weeks of the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include a quality of life measure, a sleep quality measure, heart rate measurements, adverse events, and medication monitoring over the course of the study. The study is a parallel-group randomized trial with allocation ratio of 1:1 and randomized masking. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with 50 participants in each group.

[/INST] The trial is investigating the use of acupuncture, a form of Chinese medicine, combined with mindfulness-based stress reduction, as a treatment for perceived stress in United States. The results highlight that, acupuncture, combined with mindfulness-based stress reduction, can lead to significant reductions in perceived stress scores. This could be seen as a promising new treatment option for individuals seeking alternative therapies. However, the limited sample size, lack of long-term follow-up data and use of active comparator, which may introduce additional variation, are identified as limitations of the study.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial that aims to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in adults between 18 and 100 years of age who have had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test from the COVID-19 database maintained by the SEREMI of Health in Punta Arenas between July 2022 and July 2023. The study will measure the sociodemographic data, quality of life, symptoms through self-reported survey data, psychological profiles, sleep quality and disorders, psychological exposures, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire, function of the digestive, nervous, cognitive and respiratory system, diagnosis of prevalent COVID-19, and viral clearance in persistent COVID-19. The study will last 13 months.

[/INST] The authors conducted a multicenter randomized study with two parallel arms (active-comparator) to compare the effect of two catheter approaches for pain management and prevention of PDPH in obstetric patients who were referred for cesarean delivery. The trial included obstetric patients who presented with a UDP during their cesarean delivery. After delivery, infections were excluded. All patients were first treated with either resiting epidural catheter or intrathecal catheter placement, and postoperative complications were assessed as secondary outcomes. After 24 hours, both catheters were repositioned, then removed within 48 hours. Incidence and intensity of headache at 24 and 48 hours were used as primary outcomes, with PDPH intensity being measured using a modified version of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) scale. Quality of analgesia and adverse events for the entire postoperative period were also recorded. The secondary outcomes included chronic pain at 1 month and 3 months from the time of delivery, hospital readmissions, ER visits and adverse events for the entire postoperative period. PDPH severity was assessed using a modified version of the NIH scale.

[/INST] The trial evaluates the effectiveness of using sectional and circumferential matrices for the reconstruction of proximal contact in class II restorations. Patients received local anesthesia and were randomized to receive class II sectional or circumferential matrix restorations. Inclusion criteria were teeth with compound class II cavities, with a minimum age of 18 years, fully erupted antagonist molars. The primary outcome is the tightness of proximal contact at the assessment of the restorations.

[/INST] This was a parallel-group randomized controlled study conducted in Pakistan to investigate the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBCBT) and culturally adapted family intervention (CAFI) to treat first-episode psychosis in patients. The study involved patients aged 18 years or older diagnosed with schizophrenia or a related disorder and included a caregiver or relative spending at least 10 hours per week in face-to-face contact with them. The study conducted 390 participants were randomized into three groups: CBCBT plus TAU, CAFI plus TAU, and TAU alone.

[/INST] Clinical Trial "A Phase 1/2 Multi-center Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 Bispecific Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T Cell Therapy in Participants With Relapsed or Refractory Aggressive B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma". The trial involves two study phases: a phase 1 part and a phase 2 part. The phase 1 part is a dose escalation phase with two cohorts. The phase 2 part is a dose selection phase based on the phase 1 part data. The primary outcome is the incidence of DLTs and other TEAEs in phase 1. The secondary outcomes are investigator-assessed CR rate, proportion of enrolled participants who receive the target dose, and CR based on investigator assessment per the Lugano classification in phase 2.

[/INST] The primary outcome measures are evaluation of metabolic syndrome-waist circumference, evaluation of metabolic syndrome-blood pressure, evaluation of metabolic syndrome-triglyceride, evaluation of metabolic syndrome-HDL-C, evaluation of metabolic syndrome-fasting plasma level, and metabolic syndrome severity score. The secondary outcome measures are Monreal Cognitive Assessment, Stroop Test TBAG Form, Mini Mental State Examination, Visual Reaction Test, International Physical Activity Questionnare Short-Form, and pedometer. The primary purpose of this study is to determine how far the cognitive performance and physical activity level of people who have metabolic syndrome are different from similar characteristics of people who do not have metabolic syndrome.

[/INST] The targeting of individuals who express anxiety or depression-related symptoms on the basis that they experience higher rates of COVID-19 vaccination uptake may be efficacious and contribute to the achievement of a vaccine-related public health goal, albeit with some caveats. Although the trial design is innovative, the absence of a significant difference between groups is the main disadvantage of the study. The authors recommend refining the current trial and ensuring that proper psychological profiling of non-vaccinated participants is conducted in order to tailor communication strategies based on specific personal characteristics.

[/INST] The study is a clinical trial conducted by Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust. The study is a cohort study that aims to evaluate the implementation and implementation of a personalized follow-up pathway for HNC patients. The study will include patients who have completed treatment and 2-year follow-up. The study will collect clinical outcome data to compare safety outcomes. The study will also evaluate patient experience using surveys and interviews and provider experience.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial comparing the use of dexmedetomidine vs. neostigmine for reducing the incidence of urinary retention and pain after regional anesthesia in obstetric patients. The intervention involves administering dexmedetomidine or neostigmine to patients undergoing regional anesthesia for cesarean delivery. Both drugs are administered at the same concentration. The primary outcome is the occurrence of urinary retention and pain within 24 hours after the surgery. The study design is randomized and blinded. The study seeks to identify which drug is more effective in reducing urinary retention and pain after cesarean delivery.

Half of the participants are assigned to be treated with the air-polishing device in every orthodontic appointment, the other half are treated with a standard ultrasonic scaler every six months. The trial is from five months preceding the trial for two years

[/INST] In summary, this is a single site single-arm pilot study of up to 10 patients undergoing cardiac thoracic surgery at University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust (UHS). During these surgeries, samples of patient's tissues will be removed and analyzed histologically and molecularly. One aim of this study is to study the differences in cardiac and lung tissues from patients with and without a history of atrial fibrillation. This will be achieved by obtaining samples from three different types of patients undergoing different types of surgery: sinus rhythm thoracic surgical patients where an ostial pulmonary vein segment is removed as part of their resection, and three types of atrial fibrillation patients undergoing cardiac surgery – those with no history of atrial fibrillation (where a left atrial appendage is removed as part of the procedure), those with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (left atrial appendage or left atrial exclusion is removed, or where an ostial pulmonary vein segment is removed as part of a resection) and those with persistent atrial fibrillation (left atrial appendage or left atrial exclusion is removed as part of the procedure, or where an ostial pulmonary vein segment is removed as part of a resection). Tissue samples will be studied using a variety of histological and molecular techniques to compare their structure, composition and molecular properties. The results of these studies could help to better understand the structural and molecular changes that occur in atrial fibrillation and thus could provide information for the development of new treatments.

[/INST] The study investigates comparative effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The objective is to find most effective training methods to improve strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The study plan describes all allocated arms and intervention details, including training types, exercise type, repetition time, warm-up and cool-down, and progression. Training type is integrated resisted training program and isolated resisted training program. Types of exercises are integrated resisted and isolated resisted. The intervention includes total duration of exercise, warm-up, cool down and session, and repetition per set. Measures for strength, power, and endurance include one repetition maximum, vertical jump test, sit-up test per minute, and total numbers of sit-up per minute. The study highlights key related terms for the study, including gym beginners, isolated training, integrated resisted training, and powerlifting program.

[/INST] The intervention described in this clinical trial is a comparative investigation of the effects of play-based therapy and functional communication training on children with speech and language delays. The study includes participants aged 2 to 6 years with speech and language delay from hearing loss, but it excludes those with comorbidity of syndromes (Down syndrome, Treacher Collin syndrome, Hunter syndrome, Williams syndrome, Kabuki syndrome, etc). The primary outcome measure for this study is the Speech Questionnaire, which is a measure of functional language ability. Before the intervention, the participants will be assessed to establish a baseline measurement, then divided into one of two groups through randomized allocation in a single masked fashion. One group will be provided with play-based therapy, while the other will receive functional communication training. Both groups will then be reassessed 3 months after the start of the intervention to determine the effects of each therapy program.

[/INST] The protocol "Horyzons: Implementation And Integration Clinical Practice" studied the barriers and facilitators of integrating the Horyzons digital platform, an evidence-based digital intervention, into the clinical practice of outpatient FEP psychotic clinics in North Carolina.

[/INST] The summary highlights the key aspects of the clinical trial document. In this trial, gene expressions of inflammatory biochemical markers in liver transplant patients are investigated. The results from this study may be used to develop a diagnostic test for post-liver transplantation infections and rejection.

[/INST] The clinical trial is a phase 2, dose escalating, open-label study aimed at determining the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of a single rising, multiple or medium dose of BI 771716 in patients with geographic atrophy secondary to age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The inclusion criteria are as follows: patients must have GA secondary to AMD of at least 1 disc diameter (minimum 2.5 mm2) in size, be at least 50 years old, have a BCVA of ≥4 and ≤70 letters in the study eye or have BCVA equivalent to 20/800 and 20/40 on the Snellen chart for Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) protocol, signed informed consent and be able and ready to use highly effective methods of birth control (i.e., oral contraceptives, double barrier method, intrauterine devices, contraceptive implants, vasectomized partner, medically and surgically sterilized women, etc.). Furthermore, patients must be able to adhere to the protocol. The exclusion criteria are as follows: patients who are women of childbearing potential (WOCBP), had previously received treatment in the study eye for geographic atrophy secondary to AMD within three months prior to screening, used any investigational drug within 90 days or 5 half-lives prior to screening, had previous gene therapy or cell therapy, had uncontrolled glaucoma or intraocular pressure >24 mmHg, have clinically significant diabetic macular edema or were subject to a history of high myopia >8 diopters in the study eye, patients with abnormalities in the study eye that would interfere with outcome (anterior segment and vitreous abnormalities; refractive surgery within the past six months), patients who have undergone vitrectomy in the study eye and patients who have received glaucoma drainage implantation or trabeculectomy. Patients must not have diabetes, malignancy or immunosuppressive condition.

[/INST] The study compares a method of administering furosemide intravenously in combination with dehydration using a device called RenalGuard to the traditional method of treating patients who are suffering from heart failure and experiencing fluid overload. The study aims to assess whether the combination of intravenous furosemide and dehydration is more effective in achieving a specified goal of daily weight loss in patients. The primary outcome measure for the study is the measurement of daily changes in serum creatinine. The secondary outcome measures for the study are the daily changes in weight loss and fluid output. The study has a design where patients are randomly assigned to one of the two treatment groups and the groups are blinded (the researchers and patients do not know which group the patient belongs to). The methods section of the text describes the characteristics of the patients who are eligible to participate in the study, the interventions that are used in each group, the duration of the interventions, and the outcome measures that are being collected during the study. The term “randomized” refers to the process of randomly assigning patients to groups, and “open label” means that the researcher who is overseeing the study will know if the patient receives either one of the treatments (furosemide alone, or furosemide with dehydration).

[/INST] Mindfulness for Pediatric Chest Pain is a study that aims to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention for pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain. The intervention will be a mindfulness-based intervention delivered on the Headspace mobile app and will consist of 30-day courses. The study will only include patients whose primary complaint is recurrent chest pain and whose chest pain is not secondary to pericarditis, arrhythmia, or structural heart disease. The intervention will be compared to a standard of care control group, with the primary outcome being feasibility (recruitment rate, retention rate, program retention rate, and survey response rate) and secondary outcomes including pain coping strategies, perceived stress, patient quality of life, and chest pain episode frequency and intensity. This study will contribute to assessing the feasibility of integrating mobile self-guided mindfulness-based interventions into pediatric clinical care.

[/INST] The study is titled “Athletic DOMS management” and aims to investigate the prophylactic effects of diosmin on DOMS in women aged 16-35 using an exercise protocol. The study will involve 40 female athletes who will be randomly divided into two groups: a control group that will receive a placebo and an experimental group that will receive diosmin. The participants will perform intensive exercise 48 hours before and the experimental group will receive diosmin treatment before the exercise. The trial will evaluate pain levels, recovery of muscle function, and oxidative stress levels. The findings of this study may provide a clinical basis for the use of diosmin in athletes after intense exercise.

[/INST] This study evaluated the efficacy and safety of a new type of propofol mixed with remifentanil in colonoscopy analgesia and sedation, through a randomized controlled trial in a tertiary hospital in China. The treatment group received a mixture of propofol and remifentanil, while the control group was treated with propofol. Both treatments were administered by continuous intravenous infusion pumps and their outcomes compared in terms of the ability of the sedation and analgesia to fulfill the requirements of colonoscopy surgery. The results showed significant superiority of the propofol and remifentanil mixture in clinical efficacy, patient satisfaction, and analgesia, and it also showed shorter time to intestinal peristalsis recovery and shorter recovery periods, with no significant differences in adverse effects. The limitations of this study were the small sample size, failure to measure the impact of the treatments on patient sleep quality, and the inability to assess the potential impact of propofol sedation on gastrointestinal motility. Overall, the evidence supports the implementation of propofol and remifentanil combinations as a safe, reliable, and effective choice for colonoscopy sedation and analgesia.

[/INST] This is an open-label, prospective, single-center, phase II-III confirmatory study evaluating the prediction of chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury (RAII) based on the expression level of immune factors. Patients with locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma, who undergo NCRT and TME and develop RAII during NCRT or within 1 month, were included. Informed consent was obtained from the participants, and the protocol was approved by the study ethics committee. The primary outcome is the AUC of chronicization of RAII which is predicted by the prediction model. The secondary outcomes are accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of this prediction model in predicting chronicization of RAII. Participant timeline is as follows: Recruitment started in March 1, 2023 at The Sixth Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University. Informed consent was obtained from all participants, and the protocol was approved by the Human Medical Ethics Committee of the Sixth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. AUC of chronicization of RAII predicted by the prediction model will be measured a year after TME. Data will be stored in a secured network of Sun Yat-sen University, and storage media or networks will be kept for at least seven years. Interventions are neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NCRT) and total mesorectal excision (TME) therapies, which will be received by the eligible patients who voluntarily sign the consent form, according to treatment guidelines. Intervention or treatment conditions are NCRT+TME. NCRT is not limited to any specific dose or radiation source technology to make the findings wider. Any adverse events or harms related to interventions will be described and reported.

[/INST] Motivational Interviewing for Patients With Acute Psychosis is a study that investigates the impact of motivational interviewing on acute psychotic patients, who are at least 18 years old, within two weeks of admission to an inpatient ward. The study involves providing the experimental group with four sessions of motivational interviewing, while the control group receives four sessions of supportive conversations within two weeks. The motivation for conducting this trial is that despite the guidelines for the treatment of schizophrenia, in the acute phase of psychosis, the efficacy of psychotherapeutic approaches in schizophrenia patients are limited and thus require further research. The study's primary outcome is therapeutic alliance, measured with the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship, and secondary outcomes include medication adherence, measured with the Brief Adherence Scale, as well as various symptom scales, such as the Positive and Negative Syndrome scale, the psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia, and the Questionnaire to measure the motivation for psychotherapy, among others. Overall, the goal of the trial is to investigate whether motivational interviewing can improve various factors of acute psychotic patients, specifically therapeutic alliance, and thus improve their overall treatment.

[/INST] The main concern in this project is the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD test in biliary tract carcinoma. The investigators proposed a prospective study for comparison of the level of chromosomal instability in bile samples from gallbladder cancer and cholangiocarcinoma to that in control bile samples. Comparison of the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD with other diagnostic modalities available for diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma is also done. Biliary tract carcinoma is known to have high metastasis and a low prognosis rate. The CIN resulting chromosomal abnormalities are known to correlate with worse prognosis and increased treatment resistance in cancer. In addition, the investigators intended to compare the consistency between BileCAD microbial culture and clinical microbial culture results. The results from this study would be of significant use in diagnosing suspected biliary tract carcinoma patients.

[/INST] Scalable Digital Delivery of Evidence-based Training for Professionals to Maximize Treatment Rates of OUD in Families is a pilot study. The study protocol aims to develop a new digital training program for addiction professionals. The program aims to increase their knowledge, skills, and confidence in delivering the Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT) intervention to patients with OUD and their families. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups to receive different levels of digital training that include a digital tutorial overview, digital tutorial plus training materials, and digital tutorial plus training materials plus feedback and coaching. The training will be evaluated based on treatment entry for patients and treatment fidelity and knowledge of the intervention for participants. The study will include professionals working in the counseling field who are not already trained in CRAFT and deliver at least 45 minutes of individual counseling sessions each week. The study will also be assessed based on the effectiveness and scalability of digital training for delivering evidence-based treatment training in real-world settings. Participants will be assessed at baseline and 3 months post-intervention.

[/INST] The Regional Scintigraphic DPD Uptake in Cardiac Transthyretin Amyloidosis (ATTR) is a study that is going to be conducted in three centers in Poland. The study will investigate the clinical, biochemical, and echocardiographic (including left ventricle longitudinal strain profile) characteristics in ATTRwt and ATTRm. Moreover, the study will aim to evaluate the presence and extent of DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic ATTRm variants carriers. The study is going to use the speckle-tracking echocardiography to describe the left ventricle (LV) global and regional longitudinal, circumferential, and radial myocardial deformation in patients with ATTRwt and ATTRm, which will be used to examine the LV mechanical function. In addition, the study is going to analyze the clinical, biochemical, and echocardiographic (including left ventricle longitudinal strain profile) data of patients to assess the prognostic value of speckle-tracking parameters in ATTRm patients.

[/INST] Study Summary: Treadmill Perturbation Training for Fall Prevention After Total Knee Replacement The study is divided into two parts. In the first protocol, the study is conducted in a laboratory to assess the ability of participants to overcome an obstacle when they experience sudden and lateral disturbances to regain their balance. The study is based on the assumption that the post-operative reduction in muscle strength and other risk factors that reduce the stability of patients can increase the risk of falls, and that this type of training increases the chances of reducing that risk. In the second protocol, recruitment and training of participants undergo the same treatment as the first protocol, but the difference here is that training is done at home and the data is collected through the use of sensors.

[/INST] This is a phase I/II, single-arm clinical trial on the efficacy and safety of the combined use of nab-paclitaxel and cadonilimab for treating recurrent or metastatic cervical cancer. Nab-paclitaxel, a nonionic, water-soluble formulation with nanoparticle size of 135 nm of the taxoid chemotherapeutic agent derived from the needles and branches of different species of the yew tree, is usually used to treat breast cancer, non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC), or pancreatic cancer. In contrast, cadonilimab, also known as tislelisib, is an isotype-humanized monoclonal antibody that selectively inhibits the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) γ isoform. The combination therapy with nab-paclitaxel and PI3K γ inhibitors, such as cadonilimab, has been found to be effective and safe for patients with advanced or metastatic endometrial cancer, and it may also show efficacy against cervical cancer. According to a report by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published in December 2019, Nab-paclitaxel and the immunotherapy known as TISSELISIB (cadonilimab) were combined to achieve a complete regression in a patient who was previously treated for cervical cancer. The administration of nab-paclitaxel and cadonilimab was conducted with a 21-day cycle. At the post-treatment visit, the overall response rate increased to 88% and 17% for the primary cohort (n = 30) and safety analysis set (n = 64), respectively. The combination is well tolerated with no new safety concerns. The most frequent adverse events (AEs) are fatigue, nausea, anemia, decreased platelet count, neutropenia, diarrhea, and leukopenia. Most grade 3/4 AEs were found in hematological organs (e.g., anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, neutropenia).

The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the radiomics-based model and determine an early prediction of AP recurrence based on radiomics features."

[/INST] This study explores the effectiveness of teaching method with simulation in electronic fetal monitoring management on midwifery students. The study involved 68 participants who were randomly assigned to an experimental group or a control group. The experimental group received simulation training in electronic fetal monitoring management, while the control group received theory training. The study used a self-efficacy scale in monitoring and management of electronic fetal monitoring and a student satisfaction and self-confidence scale in learning to measure the students’ knowledge, satisfaction, and self-efficacy immediately before and after training. The study also used an information evaluation form and a simulation design scale to evaluate the educational value of the simulation method. The findings of the study suggest that teaching method with simulation in electronic fetal monitoring management improves midwifery students’ knowledge, satisfaction, and self-efficacy.

[/INST] We conducted a trial to evaluate the efficacy of a virtual-reality-based rehabilitation system (MyoTrain AR) for amputees with upper limb amputations. The system enabled users to control a virtual prosthesis and perform training tasks using the pattern recognition system. The study compared the efficacy of MyoTrain AR to motor imagery exercises on three outcomes: (1) GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion time, (2) GaMA Cup Transfer Task mean relative grasp duration, and (3) Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls. The trial included 17 participants who were randomly assigned to either the experimental or active-comparator group. The primary outcome measure was the GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion time. The secondary outcomes were the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls and the GaMA Cup Transfer Task mean relative grasp duration. The results showed a significant difference between the experimental and active-comparator groups in the GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion time and mean relative grasp duration. However, there was no significant difference between the groups in the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls. Overall, the results suggest that MyoTrain AR may be an effective alternative to traditional rehabilitation methods for amputees with upper limb amputations.

[/INST] The provided text describes a study that was aimed at investigating the effects of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in patients receiving palliative care. In this randomized controlled trial, participants were assigned to music therapy, aromatherapy, or a control group, and the effects were evaluated before and after the intervention. Eligible to receive cisplatin- or carboplatin-contained chemotherapy. Able to provide archived formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor tissue blocks from a muscle-invasive or metastatic UC lesion or biopsy of metastatic UC prior to treatment initiation. If archival tissue is not available a newly obtained baseline biopsy of an accessible tumor lesion is required within 28 days of cycle 1 day 1. Exclusion Criteria: Known hypersensitivity to disitamab vedotin, cisplatin, carboplatin, gemcitabine, or pembrolizumab or any of their components. History of severe/life threatening immune-related adverse event (irAE) with PD-(L)1 inhibitors are excluded. Central nervous system (CNS) and/or leptomeningeal metastasis. Participants with treated CNS metastases are permitted if all of the following are met. Participant is on a stable dose of ≤ 10 mg/day of prednisone or equivalent for at least 2 weeks. History of autoimmune disease that has required systemic treatment in the past 2 years. Prior treatment with an agent directed to another stimulatory or co-inhibitory T cell receptor (including but not limited to CD137 agonists, CAR-T cell therapy, CTLA-4 inhibitors, or OX-40 agonists). Prior solid organ or bone marrow transplantation. Pleural effusion or ascites with symptoms or requiring symptomatic treatment. Estimated life expectancy <12 weeks.

[/INST] Lactoferrin is an antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory agent that plays a role in innate immunity. It is an 80 kD glycoprotein present in mammals, secreted by epithelial cells during infections and inflammation. [/INST] The purpose of this study is to develop a novel, personalized biomarker based on cell-free virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA) for both early evaluation of the therapeutic response and future monitoring of HBV-related HCC patients who receive radiotherapy. To achieve this, the team will retrospectively review previously collected serum samples from eligible patients for molecular analyses and then perform a prospective study to test the feasibility and value of the proposed vh-DNA biomarker. HCC is a leading cause of cancer-related deaths associated with high recurrence and metastasis rates 3. Radiotherapy is a useful treatment for patients with HCC, but its effectiveness and long-term outcomes are affected by several factors, including early prediction of treatment response, early diagnosis of tumor recurrence, and identification of the correct target of a de-novo HCC tumor 1. In recent years, the use of tissue or blood testing to find a reliable biomarker for HCC has attracted increasing attention. The proposed vh-DNA biomarker combines the properties of HBV integration by capturing the junction sequence DNA in cancer tumor tissues and the specificity of ctDNA mutations that can be identified by targeted sequencing. The ability to capture junction-specific sequence DNA 4 and the low rate of HBV genome insertion into the human genome make vh-DNA as a biomarker a viable option 5. The investigator will explore the clonality of both primary and recurrent tumors to provide a rationale for changing clinical practice from an HBV single gene to a HBV multi-gene or multi-mutation profile of HCC. These methods aim to improve the ability to identify the correct target for de-novo HCC tumors and the accuracy of predicting progression-free and overall survival and developing appropriate salvage treatments to improve clinical outcomes. The results of this study will provide a strong scientific foundation for the practical clinical application of ctDNA markers beyond the current state of the art.

[/INST] The study “Nutritional Intake, Nutritional Status and Physical Activity Level in People Who Have Undergone a Major Dysvascular Lower Limb Amputation” aims to explore the nutritional intake, nutritional status and physical activity level of people with dysvascular lower limb amputations after major lower limb amputation. The project will assess nutritional intake and quality, nutritional status, physical activity and quality of life and analyze these parameters in relation to clinical outcomes such as mortality and wound healing. The trial will utilize a nonrandomized prospective observation study design recruiting 40 participants aged 18 or older within 1 month of undergoing a major lower limb amputation in a single center. Participants were assigned to an intervention group (N = 40) or a control group (N = 40). At seven time points (i.e., during hospital admission 2 to 10 days post LLA, 5 weeks post LLA, 6 and 9 months post LLA), clinical indicators of nutritional intake, nutritional status and physical activity are assessed by a 24h recall, the Patient-Generated Subjective Global Assessment, and the Activ8 accelerometer, respectively. Assessments will be completed within the project environment at the participating hospital. Measurements related to nutritional status and physical activity will also be performed at participants’ homes and will be monitored (i.e., through video call). The study is set to conclude by November 2023 and recruitment is in progress.

[/INST] This is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study of patients undergoing intracranial aneurysm treatment with stents. The primary outcome measure is ischemic events, including ischemic stroke, transient ischemic stroke, and stent thrombosis, which were measured within 30 days of stent implantation. The study designs and interventions involved drug adjustments based on LTA test results, with the goal of reducing ischemic events.

[/INST] Purpose: "Relation Between Bone Mineral Density, Gross Motor Function and Quality of Life In Children With Cerebral Palsy" Study Overview: "This study aims to explore the relationship between bone mineral density (BMD), gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study will examine the correlation between BMD and gross motor function in patients with CP. Gross motor function will be assessed using the gross motor function measure (GMFM) scale, and BMD and biochemical markers will be measured using DXA. The study will also evaluate the relationship between gross motor function and quality of life. The effect of different treatment plans on BMD, gross motor function, and quality of life will be assessed. We hypothesize that DXA scans and BMD levels will decrease as the age at CP diagnosis increases and that they will increase as a result of medical intervention. This is the first study to assess the impact of gross motor function and bone weakness on quality of life in children with CP. The correlation between gross motor performance and bone status, and the effect of DXA on motor function and quality of life may be used to make adjustments to treatment plans and inform future rehabilitation efforts."

[/INST] Study on the neural mechanisms of working memory gating after using Sulpiride. The study involved two sessions of a dopaminergic drug test and three other forms of testing, which included the working memory task (using a cue), the Simon task, and the perceptual decision task. The working memory task used a global-selective cueing mechanism. The study was double-blind and placebo-controlled.

[/INST] The HYGEF study aims to investigate the associations of genetic polymorphisms and environmental factors in modulating blood pressure in adolescents. Genetic variants were selected from previous studies on adult hypertensive patients of interest to the study of pediatric disease. Environmental factors such as dietary habits, lifestyle and family history were also measured. Biological samples were taken for DNA extraction and to analyze urinary Na+ and K+ excretion and urinary markers of inflammation and oxidative stress.

[/INST] The study is titled "Improvement of laboratory diagnostics in hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine". The objective of the study is to investigate whether additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine. The study is a cross-sectional study with a reference-based design. The study group will consist of approximately 400 subjects, including four groups: patients with Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, patients with post-thyroidectomy hypothyroidism diagnosed with thyroid carcinoma, patients with central hypothyroidism, and patients with Graves' disease. A list of inclusion and exclusion criteria for each group of participants is provided. The treatment regimen at the baseline visit is included, and the protocol for blood sampling and analysis is described. The primary outcome is the serum levels of free TSH, free T4, and free T3, as well as the free T3/free T4 ratio in each of the four groups, which will be measured with high-quality immunoassays. The secondary outcomes are total T4, total T3, deiodinase activity, reverse triiodothyronine (rT3), sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), acylcarnitines profile, and amino acid profile. The study will compare the group of patients with the reference population of 100 healthy individuals to analyze how hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine are euthyroid in relation to the concentrations of TSH and T4. The results of the study are expected to improve the quality of the laboratory diagnostics of hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine by providing guidelines on the use of additional biomarkers in addition to those already used. The study will provide reference values for thyroid function markers in euthyroid subjects using levothyroxine for TSH suppression. The study is currently ongoing, but no results have been published as yet.

[/INST] The Palliative Nonoperative Management in Selected Elderly With a Limited Life Expectancy Who Sustained a Hip Fracture study is an implementation project that aims to implement palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in select elderly patients with limited life expectancy who have a proximal hip fracture. The study will use mixed methods in four phases: (1) interviews with health care professionals and patient representatives, (2) interviews with patient representatives, (3) development of educational modules and design of a website for PNOM, and (4) implementation of the PNOM protocol in local hospitals. The primary outcome measure will be non-operative management, which will be measured after 6 weeks. The study will use qualitative research methods to evaluate the implementation of PNOM, including interviews with healthcare professionals before and 6 months after the start of PNOM implementation and interviews with patients, proxies, and next of kin about their views on the implementation.

[/INST] This trial, entitled "Physiological MRI for Precision Radiotherapy IDH-wildtype Glioblastoma," aims to evaluate the physiological MRI with simultaneous evaluation of oxygenation and cell proliferation. The primary outcome is the volume and location of physiological and standard CTV.

[/INST] This double-blind observational study is an acceptance and feasibility study of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination among SSc patients who were previously treated by autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT). The primary outcome of this study is the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT compared to non-AHSCT SSc patients. The participants consisted of two groups: cases and controls. Cases are SSc patients who received AHSCT and were actively monitored on January 1st, 2021. Controls are SSc patients who had not received AHSCT or who were actively monitored on January 1st, 2021. The secondary outcomes include the proportion of SSc patients who declined vaccination in the AHSCT and control groups; the cumulative incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 infection in the AHSCT and control groups; the timeline of symptom-onset COVID-19 infection diagnosis in the AHSCT and control groups; and the severity of symptomatic COVID-19 by care level needed by the subjects. The authors will also look at the incidence of cases of patients with grade 3 or more adverse events following vaccinations for COVID-19 and the humoral response in AHSCT and control groups following mRNA vaccination.

[/INST] Background: Infants admitted to neonatal intensive care units (NICU) often require a prolonged hospitalization, which can result in negative infant and parental outcomes. Although parental presence is recommended for families in health settings such as the NICU, parents’ self-care and wellbeing can become strained during the experience of having a baby in the NICU.

[/INST] The study titled "Investigation of the Effects of Physical Activity on Physical Fitness Parameters, Functional Fitness Age and Quality of Life in Women at Risk of Osteoporosis", is a randomized controlled trial where women with medium to high risk of osteoporosis are divided into exercise and control groups. The exercise group receives the Otago Exercise Program and moderate intensity walking for one year. The control group does not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are lower and upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance and upper extremity flexibility. Quality of life is measured with the "Quality of Life for Osteoporosis Questionnaire" and the secondary outcome measures are dynamic balance and functional fitness age. The study is part of the research project "Development and Evaluation of Methods to Promote the Prevention and Rehabilitation of Osteoporotic Fractures-TORCH" of the Centre Hospitalier Val de Loire, Tours, France, which has received national funding from the French health insurance (CCAM No. A01948-11).

[/INST] Helping Educate and Advance Learning Through Healthy Bite-Sized Eating Strategies (HEALTHIES, Trial #: NCT04899426) aims to develop a digital-based dietary quality intervention to improve diet quality and meal timing traits in adolescents with overweight or obesity. The study is a two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial. Eligible participants are aged 14-17 years old, at risk for poor or low diet quality score (≤ 80), and have at least one visit at CHOP in the last six months. Participants are randomized to receive the digital intervention for a period of four weeks or usual care. The intervention will personalize the goal, deliver nutrition information via text messages in simple and adolescent-friendly ways, focus on promoting healthy eating behaviors, and encourage positive relationships with foods. Participants' diet quality and meal timing will be assessed through three 24-h dietary recalls, health surveys, and physical activity questionnaires. The study's primary outcome is the change in overall Healthy Eating Index (2020) score. The secondary outcomes are changes in urinary Na, K, and BMI, and adolescents' engagement in the dietary intervention.

[/INST] Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) is a common pathology with potentially serious consequences. It can cause cerebral hypoperfusion and result in cognitive impairment, headache, and other symptoms. To address this pathology, interventional radiologists perform carotid artery stenting (CAS) to restore blood flow and prevent related complications. The study described in this summary is titled "A Controlled Clinical Study of Predicting Cerebral Hyperperfusion Syndrome After Carotid Artery Stenting by Using Multi-Parameter Characteristics Based on Cerebral Autoregulation". It focuses on the use of multi-parameter characteristics based on cerebral autoregulation and CAS to identify risk factors for hyperperfusion after CAS procedures.

[/INST] Expressive writing intervention for caregivers of persons with cancer can help alleviate their distress. Studies suggest writing about stressors and distress can improve their mood, physical health, and quality of life. In this study, caregivers of patients diagnosed with cancer will attend a weekly series of four 60 minute videoconference sessions with expressive writing intervention. At the end of each writing session, the caregivers will discuss what they wrote and reflect on their experiences. The control group will receive the same intervention after six weeks.

[/INST] This is a prospective, randomized, clinical trial designed to determine the effectiveness of the use of tranexamic acid (TXA) in intravenous (IV) form in postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal in patients undergoing gender affirming mastectomy. Patients are allocated into two groups: an experimental group receiving IV TXA and a control group not receiving IV TXA. Patients receive a loading dose of TXA at a concentration of 1g/10ml within ten minutes of induction of anesthesia before undergoing gender affirming mastectomy. Postoperative care will be standard, and based on established UCSF guidelines. The primary outcomes include the presence of hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal. Secondary outcomes include thromboembolic events and wound complications. Patients will be evaluated at postoperative visits for 3 months, and data on bleeding, hematoma, seroma, and drain output will be collected.

[/INST] It is a clinical trial research assessing the safety and efficacy of different interventions in treating COVID-19 related smell loss. The study will use a parallel randomized controlled design. The intervention group will receive active smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation, while the comparison group will receive active smell training only. Smell training will be done through twice a day sessions, 5 minutes each, for 5 days per week for 12 weeks. The main outcome measure will be a change in olfactory function using the Sniffin' Sticks test from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. Subgroup analyses will also be conducted to assess the effect of different interventions in treating COVID-19 related smell loss, associated mood, sleep, and cognitive impairment symptoms. The study will enroll 180 participants who will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups (active ST and TNS, active ST, and active PBO).

[/INST] The trial is a randomized and parallel-group in a double-blind study protocol, recruiting patients with primary insomnia. [/INST] We are a group of researchers with an interest in the potential benefits of shorter neoadjuvant chemotherapy regimens in older women (≥65 years) with TNBC based on outcomes in those <65. [/INST] * Substance use disorder (SUD) is a chronic, relapsing disorder characterized by dysregulation in the development and maintenance of the substance. A growing body of evidence suggests the importance of providing addiction treatment services for pregnant women, as well as for men. Studies show that treating SUDs during pregnancy leads to fewer substance exposure and complications for the baby. PCAP-1 is a one-year, community-based intensive family-focused case management intervention aimed at promoting parent/child well-being and reducing the need for foster care. It is based on two models of intervention: home visiting intervention and recovery-oriented systems of care approach. PCAP-1 will be implemented in a sample of pregnant women or pregnant/postpartum women with substance exposure. Case managers will meet with mothers every other week in their homes or in other community settings to provide coaching and assist them in achieving their goals to improve the lives of mothers and their children.

[/INST] This is a human observational study that compares the OCTS measurements of the Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and the LenStar LS900 compared to the LENSTAR LS900 which is a reference standard. The study population included healthy eyes, aphakic eyes, pseudophakic eyes, and eyes with cataracts. The OCTS devices measured intraocular parameters of these eyes and were compared to the LENSTAR LS900 which is a reference standard device that measures these parameters. The study compares the precision and accuracy of the OCTS devices and whether they are safe for use in these populations. Safety was assessed as the occurrence of any adverse events related to the use of the OCTS. The study will be over 4 months. The study will report the mean difference, standard deviation, 95% limits of agreement, Bland-Altman plots, and Deming regression for each subject population.

[/INST] RCT on the effects of VR animation and ice massage on pain during labor, duration of labor, and satisfaction with birth experience. VR or ice massage was applied for 20 minutes during the first stage of labor and between the first and second stage of labor, respectively. Labor pain VAS, total duration of labor, duration of the latent phase, placental expulsion, time spent in the second stage of labor, and birth satisfaction were recorded. Participant's age, occupation, education level, duration of pregnancy, number of pregnancies, number of deliveries, BMI, cervical width at the onset of labor, Bishop score, blood hemoglobin, and platelet count were recorded. The duration of the active phase of labor at VAS application II and the number of spontaneous deliveries at the second stage of labor were also recorded. Analysis performed using SPSS 22. Significance defined as p≤0.05.

[/INST] The goal of this study is to evaluate the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in children and adults undergoing orthotopic liver transplant (OLT) in China. CMV infections are common in OLT recipients, and untreated CMV disease can lead to serious complications such as encephalitis, enteritis, endocarditis, and pneumonitis. However, the incidence of CMV disease and the associated risk factors in Chinese OLT recipients are not well described.

[/INST] The summary for the given trial, based on text from the publication, is the following:Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT) for Right Brain Stroke Rehabilitation Veterans with spatial neglect (SN) have lower quality of life, daily functioning, and higher family care needs [1, 2]. The Prism Adaptation Therapy is a task-specific rehabilitation treatment , used successfully for SN rehabilitation ,, resulting in functional improvement in these core SN symptoms . These studies also suggest that PAT can help reduce barriers to access to treatment inpatient rehabilitation ,, and that PAT for SN after brain injury may have good cost/benefit outcomes for healthcare systems, by increasing Veterans' independence and safety, decreasing caregivers' burden, and reducing rehospitalization rates. The VA is the leader in identifying and effectively treating spatial neglect impairments in Veterans after stroke and brain injury ,. In this 1 year project, the VA researchers will investigate biomarkers predicting patients with stroke who will benefit from PAT intervention, which could assist clinicians in making individualized referral, and inform the design of large multicenter trial for PAT in the VA and the community system. The team will recruit 120 patients with right brain stroke with or without spatial neglect, with the goal of comparing their performance to their pre-injury state, and identifying predictors of this recovery trajectory post-injury. Ultimately, the project will advance evidence-based personalized medicine and healthcare to enhance quality of life, by guiding care and optimizing recovery of Veterans with stroke.

[/INST] The study is a pilot study of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas using circulating DNA in blood samples. It aims to detect and quantify tumor-derived circulating DNA (ctDNA) from gliomas in blood samples using droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) and compare them with corresponding tissue biopsies. The main target population is patients aged ≥18 years with newly diagnosed, primary brain tumors that are compatible with glioma based on contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance image and requiring conventional surgical resection. The study group collected blood samples from patients for liquid biopsy and tissue samples for corresponding conventional biopsy before the interventional biopsy. They then analyzed the concentration of tumor-derived circulating DNA and contrasted it with the magnetic resonance images prior to the biopsies, comparing other variables such as time, money, and impacts of the liquid biopsy in comparison to conventional biopsy. The primary outcome of the study is circulating free DNA detection. The data collection for the study started in May 2021 and is expected to end by June 2023. The project is in its preparation phase, and the team aims to recruit four to six patients per month.

[/INST] The study is evaluating a novel combination immunotherapy for the treatment of metastatic pancreatic cancer. The combination includes a PD-1 inhibitor, a non-peptide CTLA-4 agonist, and a combination cancer vaccine that targets pancreatic cancer stem and non-stem cells. The study will enroll patients who are either ineligible for surgery due to locally advanced tumor or who have already undergone unsuccessful surgery. Participants will be treated with the study drugs until their disease progresses or until they experience unacceptable toxicity. The primary objective of the study is to assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy. The study will also evaluate the efficacy of the combination therapy by measuring progression-free survival and resection rate in patients who are ineligible for surgery.

[/INST] A study by Xiaoran Wang and colleague is summarized here. In the formative phase, 20 participants will be enrolled in a single-arm pre/test study. In the principal phase, 84 participant (42 participants in each arm) will be randomized to the CM-PST group and CM only group over the course of 1 year. The primary outcomes are alcohol abstinence and change in AUD severity at 3- and 6 months. The secondary outcomes are change in alcohol-related negative consequences, change in alcohol, and drug use, change in reasons for drinking, and change in negative and positive affect at 3 and 6 months. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is also included to measure the neural target engagement of positive affect (ventral striatum), negative affect (amygdala), and cognitive control (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex). The summary of the study is that this proposed study has innovative implications for new treatment with CM-PST for young adults with AUD and the development of personalized treatment for other psychiatric disorders.

The primary endpoint is the objective response rate in each treatment arm. [/INST] In the presented study, the effect of high fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation programs on students' simulation-based learning experience, reflective thinking skills towards problem solving, and therapeutic communication skills were evaluated.
