[/INST] The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of the center volume-outcome relationship and center effect on mortality in patients undergoing surgery for type A acute aortic dissection. The study is a prospective multicenter observational cohort study. The primary outcome measures are operative mortality, rate of mesenteric ischemia, rate of permanent neurologic deficit, and composite of major adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include rate of perioperative myocardial infarction, rate of acute heart failure, rate of transient neurologic deficit, rate of spinal cord injury, rate of acute kidney injury, rate of perioperative bleeding, rate of reoperation for bleeding, rate of mechanical circulatory support, rate of composite of major adverse pulmonary events, rate of reintervention, and late survival. The study includes 334 patients. The duration of follow-up is up to 18 years.

[/INST] This article describes a randomized controlled trial of a Virtual Reality (VR)-based program to cope with academic stress. The program consists of a 4-weeks program with virtual reality, in which students will visualize a 360º video that simulates the experience of an exam from first person perspective, and a comparative control group of a traditional guided visualization, which is a 30-minutes session on a 30-minutes audio that explains the experience of an exam from the first person perspective. The main outcomes of the study include the between-group and intra-group differences in levels of academic stress and the differences in perceived stress from the last month. The VR-based program shows potential in reducing academic stress in future studies.

[/INST] A clinical trial is being conducted to compare the efficacy and safety of remimazolam and propofol as induction agents for patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in morbidly obese individuals. The objectives of the study are to determine the incidence of hypotension, the rate of hypotension events, the induction time, and the vasopressor (total amount). The study will examine patients admitted for elective LSG at Seoul National University Bundang Hospital who are more than 20 years old and provide written consent. The interventions are the use of remimazolam besylate induction and anesthesia induction with propofol. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction. The secondary outcome measure includes the induction time and the vasopressor (total amount) given for each group. The study is randomized, and the results will be available on 07 Jun 2024. The results of the trial are expected to provide information on the efficacy and safety of propofol and remimazolam besylate for induction agents for morbidly obese patients undergoing LSG.

[/INST] This study is a Phase II clinical trial which aims to describe the symptoms, treatment, and prognosis of patients with recurrent ovarian GCTs. The primary objective of the study is to determine the response rate of the drug combination of darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane as a treatment for recurrent ovarian GCTs. Darolutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist, leuprolide acetate is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogue, and exemestane is an aromatase inhibitor. Patients must have a verified diagnosis of recurrent ovarian GCTs and have previously been treated with leuprolide acetate and one aromatase inhibitor (letrozole, exemestane, or anastrozole). Patients must also have been progression-free from these medications for at least 8 weeks, must have measurable disease, and must have a life expectancy of at least 12 weeks at the onset of therapy. The treatment phase lasts for 28 days and starts 14-28 days after screening. The drug darolutamide is administered 2 weeks before cycle day 1 (day -14 to day -7) and every day of the cycle (days 1-28). Gonadotropin-releasing hormone is administered on day 1 of each cycle. The exemestane is administered within 2 hours of the morning on day 1 of each cycle. Radiologic assessments are done at baseline, every 8 weeks, and at the study ending (9 months after the start or discontinuation of drug). The primary endpoint of the study is objective tumor response rate, which is measured by complete response, partial response, stable disease, and progressive disease according to the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1. The drugs must be taken orally and patients who have any problems must be evaluated to ensure optimal absorption of the drugs.

[/INST] A phase 2 study using chemotherapy with gemcitabine, cisplatin and nivolumab in newly diagnosed nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients by determining the rate of immune related adverse events and estimate the 5-year overall survival

[/INST] The study, "Gut Imaging for Function and Transit in Cystic Fibrosis 3 Junior," aims to evaluate the effects of elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor (ETI) on pediatric (6-11 years old) cystic fibrosis (CF) patients using MRI functional and structural imaging. Healthy participants will act as controls, and liver and lung imaging will be assessed to evaluate ETI's systemic impact. The study will take approximately one year to complete.

[/INST] The study will conduct a randomized controlled study to evaluate the duration of postoperative analgesia following administration of dexamethasone versus methylprednisolone via caudal block in pediatric patients undergoing hypospadias surgery.

[/INST] The study titled "Evaluating the Addition of Hemodiafiltration to EVLP: Impact on the Regeneration of Marginal Donor Lungs: a Prospective Randomized Pilot Study" aims to evaluate the use of hemodiafiltration (HDF) in combination with ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) as a strategy to increase donor lung suitability for transplantation. The study has a randomized, open-label, parallel, parallel-assigned design. The participants are marginal donors who have donated lungs, which would be declined for transplantation by using standard assessment criteria. In this study, HDF is performed during EVLP for one group of donor lungs, and the standard EVLP technique without HDF is performed on the control group of donor lungs. Donor lung perfusion parameters are measured during the initial phase, and lung morphology is assessed after 6 hours of EVLP. The donor lung suitability before and after EVLP for transplantation is assessed using the Lung Ruling Index (LRI) and Pulmonary Hyperflow Index (PHI). The primary outcome measures are lung suitability for transplantation and grade 3 pulmonary gut reaction at 72 hours after lung transplantation. The secondary outcome measures are survival, length of mechanical ventilation, length of intensive care unit stay, and length of hospital stay. This study aims to reduce the number of donor lungs that are unsuitable for transplantation and increase the number of donor lungs used and improve the transplantation success rate.

[/INST] The study “Comparison of the Effectiveness of White Noise and Multisensory Stimulation in Retinopathy Examination” in the PubMed Central database is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of different audio interventions in preterm infants undergoing retinopathy examinations. The retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is an eye disease that premature infants are prone to develop and can result in blindness if left untreated. By introducing white noise and multisensorial stimulation (a combination of visual, tactile, and auditory cues), the researchers aim to improve the overall success rate of retinopathy examinations and potentially prevent blindness in children. The study compared infants who did not receive any intervention with those who received white noise or multisensorial stimulation. They also measured the stress levels of the infants using the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP), a standardized tool for measuring pain in premature babies. The findings of the study will help improve the retinopathy examination process in premature infants, which may reduce the risk of blindness in children due to ROP.

[/INST] The study aims to compare the efficacy of a modified method for measuring MG quality during the assessment of MGDD using a specific formula by assessing the area of the MGs and WTW distance. The participants were randomly divided into two groups based on whether they were diagnosed with MGD using a modified method of MGD measurement or a previous method. They found a positive correlation between the two methods, confirming the accuracy and reliability of the modified method.

[/INST] This is a single-blind, randomized clinical trial to compare the efficacy of zinc gluconate oral spray and sodium bicarbonate oral rinse in preventing oral mucositis in patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiation therapy. The study will have two arms, the zinc gluconate spray arm and the sodium bicarbonate rinse arm. Patients will be treated for 63 days and their experiences will be assessed at one week after the completion of radiation therapy regarding their experience of oral mucositis, time of onset, and severity.

[/INST] The study aims to investigate the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in healthy and periodontally affected subjects. The study consists of a single-site study, recruiting periodontally healthy individuals, individuals with gingivitis, treated periodontitis patients, and periodontitis patients at stages I and II or stages III and IV. Eligible participants undergo clinical data collection and provide blood and saliva samples. The primary outcome is the combination of salivary biomarkers, which includes C-reactive protein, triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1, interleukin-1beta, metalloproteinase-8, interleukin-10, interleukin-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1, macrophage inflammatory protein-1, interferon-gamma, osteoprotegerin, receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa B ligand, and tumor necrosis factor alpha. Biomarkers in saliva are measured using a commercially available multiplex immunoassay kit. Potential influencing factors such as age, gender, body mass index, lifestyle, systemic health status, and oral health status are also evaluated. The sample size is determined to detect at least two or more of the biomarkers with significant differences in healthy periodontal, gingivitis, treated periodontitis, and periodontitis patients. Data analysis includes Mann-Whitney U test, Kruskal-Wallis test, ANOVA, and ROC curve analysis. The limitations and implications for future research are also discussed.

[/INST] This is the first time I have seen a transcription of the data. I think it looks good and provides a nice summary of the clinical trial. Overall, I think this method of presenting clinical data is preferable to having a table and a figure to represent the data. Figure 3 appears to have been replicated in this transcription. I do think the authors should consider including this in the manuscript.

[/INST] The study "The Effect of Music, White Noise, and Heart Sound on Neonatal Pain" is a randomized clinical trial that aims to reduce the pain of infants during heel lancing by playing white noise, heart sounds, or the music that the mother listened to most frequently during her pregnancy. Infants with a gestational age between 28-42 weeks who did not receive sedative or analgesic drugs in the last six hours, did not have perinatal complications or hypoxic-ischemic brain injury, and whose blood could be drawn after the first try were chosen for the study. All subjects received either music, heart sounds, or white noise for ten minutes until heel lancing, during and for twenty minutes after the heel lancing. Infant pain was evaluated by NIAPAS and crying time and was analyzed. The intervention design of the study is randomized, and the results showed that white noise reduced newborn pain.

[/INST] The Caregiver Skills Training (CST) is a program that trains and supports caregivers in learning skills to care for their child with neurodevelopmental difficulties. The CST training will be conducted in person and via telehealth, and the program will monitor the safety of both models. Parents will also complete a social communication questionnaire and two assessments of their child’s development before and after the training course.

[/INST] The goal of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation in the treatment of subacromial pain syndrome by assessing the recovery of subjects' strength. The experimental group will perform exercises to strengthen the rotator cuff and scapular muscles while receiving tDCS, while the control group will perform the same exercises without tDCS. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial in which participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups and evaluated before and after treatment, as well as after a three-week follow-up period. Outcome measures include self-reported shoulder pain, range of motion, pressure pain threshold, active and passive mobility, muscle strength, and subacromial space width. The study will measure strength by using a hand dynamometer, where each participant will perform three tests per hand with a one-minute break between each test.

[/INST] The study retrospectively analyzed the association between hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and verbal scores of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and determined whether there was a difference between verbal scores of ASD children who received HBOT and those who did not. Participants of this study were children aged 2 to 17 years who were previously diagnosed with ASD, had been previously evaluated by the qualified practitioner using the age-appropriate verbal test, had received applied behavioral analysis, and had medical clearance to receive HBOT at the Oxford Recovery Center of Tilje, Norway. The study intervention arm involved ASD children who received 40 sessions of HBOT for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA. The control group comprised ASD children who had not received HBOT but had been previously evaluated using the same age-appropriate verbal test. The primary outcome was the verbal scores for ASD children at 6 months, assessed using the VBMAPP and ABLLS tests. HBOT was found to be safe; however, results showed no significant differences in verbal scores for participants who had received and had not received HBOT.

[/INST] Summary: Study overview: This is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a flexible, multimodal WFPBD educational program for 6 weeks for providers at Stanford in any department. Research Activities: Screening: Interested participants will participate in a Qualtrics survey, which will determine eligibility. Enrollment: If the provider expresses interest in participating, the research team will send an email that explains details about the study. A waiver of consent will be utilized given minimal risk. Intervention: a 6-week multimodal educational intervention program. We will utilize a pre- and post-study survey which will include information on current dietary habits and use of Diet ID (assessment of diet type and quality). We will also assess their mindset for adopting a WFPBD. Finally, we will assess measures of motivation and confidence to adopt a WFPBD and to prescribe a WFPBD to patients. The educational program will include interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities including movies, recipes, and websites.

[/INST] The study titled “Rehabilitation needs in patients with early breast cancer: validation of a questionnaire patient-reported outcome” is a multi-center study that seeks to translate, adapt and validate the questionnaire PRO survivorship concern in patients with early breast cancer. The questionnaire aims to evaluate the problems faced in the process of survival, the level of concern of patients, care, symptom management, family and genetic issues and the fear of recurrence of the disease. PRO Survivorship concern questionnaire is made up of 17 elements to be evaluated on a scale of 0 to 3. To assess the validity of the questionnaire, it will be given twice, and the level of agreement between the two assessments will be assessed using the Interclass Correlation Coefficient.

[/INST] Summary: A Postpartum Adaptation Study of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience Parenting Program is being conducted at Montefiore Medical Center in New York, United States. This study is a pre- and post-treatment design. The target population are postpartum parents experiencing depression, anxiety, and parenting stress symptoms. Participants will be enrolled in a 12-session CARE parenting class. The CARE group is a behavioral intervention that involves a mentalizing-focused approach to improve parent-child relationships. The research aims to examine the feasibility and acceptability of the CARE group program and its effects on parenting stress, parent-child relationship, and parental reflective functioning. The researcher-administered questionnaires and self-administered questionnaires will be used to assess the participant's mental health status, treatment satisfaction, treatment acceptability, and infant behavior. Participants will be recruited from the postpartum clinic at Montefiore Medical Center. The study is expected to start on May 1st, 2023, and the study duration is approximately 7 years.

[/INST] The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the EEG-NFB on the cognitive function among healthy young men. The study will involve a total of 50 healthy male students. The selected subjects will be randomized into two groups, a trained group and a control group. Both groups are tested twice, pre- and post-test, and 3 weeks apart. The pre-test and post-test will be conducted using the cognitive tests, trail making test (TMT), and Stroop test. The TMT is used to assess processing speed and executive function, while the Stroop test is used to assess attention and inhibition. Each group will have to undergo 9 training sessions (3 sessions/week) lasting 30 minutes each. The trained group will be receiving EEG-NFB training, while the control group will be placed in the normal resting state condition. The TBR value will be measured before and after the training.

[/INST] The study examined the effectiveness and safety of intracranial mechanical thrombectomy (MRT) to treat acute basilar artery occlusion via the radial and femoral approaches. The study population included patients over 18 years old with confirmed basilar artery occlusion who received MRT within 24 hours of symptom onset, had baseline NIHSS scores of 10 or higher, and intact hand circulation. Exclusion criteria included contraindications for MRT, a known history of stroke, severe systemic conditions, and poor functional status before the incident stroke. Outcome measures included favorable neurological function (mRS score of ≤ 3) at 90 days post-operation and procedure time. The results indicate that the radial approach is associated with increased successful recanalization, favorable neurological function, and a better safety profile as compared to the femoral approach. The results of the study highlight the importance of radial access as the preferred method for MRT in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial that investigates the impact of a text messaging intervention on adherence to repeat colonoscopy in a population of veterans in the VA healthcare system. This study will also evaluate the participants' satisfaction with the text messaging intervention using a questionnaire designed specifically for the purpose of this study. The primary outcome measure is adherence to repeat colonoscopy, and the secondary outcome measure is participants' satisfaction with the text messaging intervention. The study includes participants who are due for repeat colonoscopy and meet other inclusion and exclusion criteria. Participants will be randomized to one of two groups: an intervention group receiving text messages and a control group receiving no text messages. The text messaging intervention includes instructional and motivational text messages sent from 7 to 14 days before their scheduled colonoscopy appointment until the same day of the appointment. The control group received no text messages. The findings of this study have the potential to contribute to the growing body of literature on the effectiveness of text messaging interventions for improving adherence to healthcare services and reducing related healthcare costs.

[/INST] The trial is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arms, parallel therapeutic clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. Trophoblastic retention is defined as the presence of intrauterine material after successful medical termination of pregnancy.

[/INST] The goal of the study is to use on-line crowdsourcing (i.e., recruiting participants over the internet) to examine different ways that people make decisions based on information stored in memory. Specifically, participants in this study will be asked to predict which jar is more likely to contain a certain substance (e.g., blue balls) using information stored in their working memory and prior knowledge. The task will involve four blocks of trials, where participants will be asked to identify a specific jar or predict the subsequent jar that contains the substance. The study will examine different ways of making decisions through three kinds of tasks: (1) short-term inference where participants will have to try and draw balls until they get the requested substance (e.g., blue balls), without knowing the current jar; (2) long-term inference where participants will have to predict the subsequent jar that contains the substance after a switch between jars; and (3) multi-timescale inference where participants will have to identify the jar and then predict the subsequent jar that contains the substance. The study will also examine how people's choices affect their future decisions. The study will include a total of 7 arms (7 different treatments) and will provide monetary compensation to participants. The study does not include any specific inclusion criteria but will limit participants to those who have high approval ratings and meet other Prolific Academic criteria.

[/INST] Lemborexant is a dual orexin receptor antagonist that blocks the binding of wake-promoting neuropeptides orexin A and orexin B to their receptors orexin 1 receptor (OX1R) and orexin 2 receptor (OX2R), which is thought to suppress wake drive. This is a 257-word summary.

[/INST] Sinomenine or glucocorticoid injection is being studied for knee osteoarthritis treatment. Patients > 40 and < 70, with bilateral knee pain but not Kellgren & Lawrence grade 1 or 4, may take part. One sinomenine or glucocorticoid intra-articular injection per 4 months is allocated. The duration of the trial is 24 months. Primary outcome is measuring total WOMAC scores and tibial cartilage volume.

[/INST] The aim is to investigate the effect of respiratory exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety and quality of life in COPD patients at Ardahan University. The primary outcome measure is dyspnea and the secondary outcome measures include quality of life, anxiety and other physiological outcomes. Patients randomly assigned to the experimental group were in the treatment process for 8 weeks. COPD patients who meet the eligibility criteria were recruited. Informed consent will be obtained from each participant, and they will also be required not to participate in any other interventions. The exercise video will be shot in the first step. After the shooting was completed, a 3D background was made by the developer and prepared for use with virtual reality glasses. Anxiety is measured using the HADS, where lower scores indicate greater anxiety. Dyspnea will be measured with the FVC, FVC, and FVC/FVC% scores test, where higher scores indicated more severe dyspnea. The VR experience is evaluated using a form developed for the use of VR glasses.

[/INST] The purpose of this mobile/wearable device trial is to evaluate the impact of behavioral and physiological data from Black women's daily lives on physiological parameters and vascular markers of cardiovascular health. The trial uses an observational approach and provides an innovative method of collecting vascular data through mobile and wearable devices. All participants will undergo a series of lab-based assessments to measure their vascular health, including measures of blood flow (in neck and in large blood vessels), macrovascular function, microvascular function, augmentation index, arterial stiffness, and cerebral blood flow. In addition, participants' daily activity and physiological data will be collected via a wrist-worn activity tracker and blood pressure monitor bracelet, as well as a smartphone app. The study consists of two groups: an observational group and an intervention group. This trial's primary outcome measures are macrovascular and microvascular function, arterial stiffness, and daily activity levels. The secondary outcome measures are blood pressure, heart rate, peripheral/central blood pressure, cerebral blood flow index, inflammatory markers, and plasma adhesion markers.

[/INST] The project is a retrospective cohort study conducted in the New Zealand's Centre of Post-Pericardiotomy Postoperative Atrial Flutter Syndrome to investigate whether the relationship between Tranexamic acid (TXA) dose and post-operative complications, including delirium. The data was retrieved from the Rutherford Hospital and Wairau Hospital electronic records system. All adult patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting, and coronary artery bypass grafting plus other cardiac procedures under cardiopulmonary bypass from May 2018 to September 2022 at Rutherford Hospital were included. Patients with elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery were included while those patients who underwent the operation involving deep hypothermic circulatory arrest, operations involving thoracic vessels other than the ascending aorta, solid organ transplantation, or mechanical assist device implantation, emergency operations were excluded. All eligible patients are analyzed for demographics, operative data, and pre- and postoperative complications, including delirium risk. They also collect data on all patients' transthoracic echocardiograms to determine left ventricular ejection fraction pre-and postoperatively, and postoperative chest radiography to identify pleural effusion up to 48 hours post-surgery. The primary outcome is delirium risk measured via RASS score up to 48 hours post-surgery while the second outcome is mortality up to 30 days post-surgery. 1200 patients will be recruited and followed up for 30 days postoperatively.

[/INST] The study examines the comparative effects of myofascial decompression (MDT) and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic nonspecific neck pain. The study involves a randomized controlled trial with participants aged 25 to 50 years, with mild to moderate neck pain with an NPRS pain score value of more than 6/10. Both groups will receive the same treatments with suction and heat application for 20 minutes followed by the first treatment. Group A will receive MDT for more than 50 minutes, and group B will receive positional Release therapy for 6 sessions in three weeks, during the 6th week, the patient will be asked to complete a questionnaire. The study is currently ongoing and recruitment is not available. Participants are randomized to receive either MDT or positional Release therapy for chronic nonspecific neck pain. The study is conducted at Hospital Center Valais, Switzerland, which is the third hospital of the Canton of Valais, and the second center for emergency care. The objective of this hospital is to ensure continuous care by offering a broad spectrum of specialized medical care. Myofascial decompression therapy and positional Release therapy were chosen as the interventions. Heat and suction application were chosen together with the interventions as both these methods had been reported to relax tissues, reduce swelling, and increase blood flow to the affected area. The participants will undergo three months of follow-up period to assess the results of the treatment.

[/INST] NOSES study is a comparison of the use of a Dumpling suture method for stoma fixation after rectal resection with conventional methods. In summary, the trial is designed to compare the use of Dumpling sutures to traditional sutures for ileostomy following rectal cancer surgery, in terms of complications, quality of life and pain scores. In addition, a stoma complication severity score (14-item Stoma Discoloration, Erosion and Tissue overgrowth (DET) score) and daily functional quality of life scores are collected during the postoperative follow-up period. The trial is a single-center study, and the study intervention is limited to stoma formation. The primary outcome is the complication rate during a six-week postoperative period. The trial will be conducted in a group of patients who are likely to undergo rectal cancer surgery that requires the formation of an ileostomy. The authors have identified a problem with conventional suturing methods for forming an ileostomy and propose a new method of stoma fixation, known as the Dumpling suture. It involves a progressive reduction of the skin incision for ileostomy. The authors argue that the use of regular sutures for ileostomy formation can lead to wound leakage or other complications due to the skin reduction. The Dumpling method of suturing proposed by the authors can result in a reduction of skin incisions of up to 50% at the start, and a three-step process to reduce the size of the incision further. In the trial, 2 groups of participants will be randomly assigned to conventional suturing or Dumpling suturing. After the ileostomy, the participants will have regular follow up at 1 week intervals up to 6 weeks postoperatively. The trial will compare the two methods of suturing in terms of complications, quality of life and pain scores. According to the authors, the Dumpling suture method has the potential to result in fewer stoma complications due to reduced incision size at the ileostomy site. An analysis of the trial data will provide evidence for the effectiveness of the Dumpling suture method.

[/INST] Amyloid-ß in cerebrospinal fluid as a risk factor for cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson's disease (ABC-PD) study is a observational cohort study, and aims to identify the clinical progression of cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease. The study will recruit people with Parkinson's disease who have been diagnosed according to the United Kingdom Brain Bank criteria, and able to understand and comply with the requirements of the study. To test the clinical progression, a detailed neuropsychological test battery will be applied, and clinical and functional information on activities of daily living will be collected. Progressive cognitive impairment will be determined based on information from cognitive test batteries and functional information on activities of daily living.

[/INST] The provided clinical trial concerns the link between air pollutants and plaque formation within the coronary arteries. Specifically, among patients with stenotic carotid arteries due to atherosclerosis, plaque analysis is proposed to identify the presence of volatile organic compounds and microplastics. These markers will then be compared to a composite composite endpoint consisting of myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular accident and mortality by Cox proportional hazards analysis.

[/INST] Transarterial radioembolization is a medical treatment that involves the injection of radioactive microspheres into the blood supply of the liver tumor. This treatment aims to selectively deliver radiation doses to tumors in the liver that are unable to be surgically removed. The study included 76 patients who had liver metastases from colorectal cancer and underwent transarterial radioembolization with Therasphere. The results of the study showed that 57% of patients had an objective response and 29% had stable disease. In the study, researchers found that the patients who responded to transarterial radioembolization had a mean effective tumor dose of 131 Gy, while the patients who had stable disease had a dose of 100 Gy. The study also found a strong dose-response and dose-toxicity relationship. Overall, the results suggest that transarterial radioembolization is a safe and effective treatment option for patients with liver metastases from colorectal cancer.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate conventionally cured chemically cured conventional glass ionomer after light-emitting diode radiant heat enhancement. Participants aged 21-45 years with vital upper or lower posterior teeth with one or two oclusmosial cavities and a sufficient number of missing antagonists will be included. Patients will receive either a conventional GICs restoration without enhancement (M1 group) or a Ketac Universal Aplicap a conventional GICs restoration enhanced with LED curing light (M2 group) without intervention or restoration on the contralateral side of the restored caries cavity. Follow-ups will be conducted after 6 and 12 months. The clinical performance of biological and functional properties will be evaluated according to the FDI criteria for the duration of the study. The findings of the study can help to improve GIC restoration properties.

[/INST] The FAPO-X trial aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) undergoing cardiac surgery. The study was conducted at InCor, the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo. The trial was divided into six phases: preoperative care, hospitalization, surgical phase, postoperative care, telemonitoring phase, and outpatient visit. Patients in the telemonitoring group used a smartwatch for remote monitoring, while patients in the control group followed standard care protocols. The primary outcome of the trial was rehospitalization rate, while the secondary outcome was technological and treatment adherence. The study sought to utilize the SAMSUNGTM Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for assisted digital telemonitoring with wearables in postoperative patients. The FAPO-X trial was a unique study that utilized advanced technologies for telemonitoring of patients after cardiac surgery. The results of the trial will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of assisted digital telemonitoring in improving patient outcomes after cardiac surgery, potentially leading to the development of new interventions aimed at improving the quality of care for this population.

People aged 18 and older with high blood pressure are eligible to participate in the study. Patients are randomly assigned to one of three groups: a group using a specific digital health platform, a group using a different digital health platform, and a group receiving standard care. The study will collect data on blood pressure and patient satisfaction with the digital health platform.

[/INST] The key message in this study is the results from the phase 1 trial of a new drug, called Bio-008, in the first line setting for treatment-naïve, unresectable metastatic BTC. The trial aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability and anti-tumor activity of Bio-008. The results of this study indicate that Bio-008 monotherapy is well-tolerated and has demonstrated promising anti-tumor activity in combination with gemcitabine as first-line therapy compared with gemcitabine alone. Bio-008 is currently being evaluated in further phase 2/3 clinical trials in patients with BTC. The study results suggest that Bio-008 may be a promising treatment option for patients with metastatic BTC in the future.

[/INST] The Effect of Different Music Listened During Retinopathy of Prematurity Examination on Pain and Comfort Level of Infants: A Randomized Controlled Trial. The trial is a single-blind, randomized controlled trial. The primary objective of this study is to determine the effect of music listening during retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examination on the pain experienced by infants. The trial will be conducted at the Centro Hospitalar Valida, Portugal, and the study population will include term infants. Eligible infants will be randomized into three groups: control, music therapy, and relaxation intervention groups. The control group will receive no intervention. The music therapy group will listen to music, and the relaxation intervention group will undergo relaxation through visualization. The study interventions will be administered during the ROP examination. The main outcome will be pain as measured on a Pain Infant Scale. Other outcomes include heart rate and oxygen saturation during the ROP examination. The data will be collected through observational assessments and physiological parameters measured before, during, and after the ROP examination. The data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics, Pearson correlation, and one-way repeated-measures analysis of variance. The study will evaluate the effect of music listening on pain and comfort during the ROP examination. The results of the study will provide information about the feasibility of music listening as an intervention during the ROP examination.

[/INST] This clinical trial seeks to assess the safety and efficacy of a drug called "sovateltide" in treating patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke. The study will recruit patients aged 18 to 80 years old with a confirmed diagnosis of acute cerebral ischemic stroke within 24 hours of onset of symptoms. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either sovateltide or a placebo. The drug will be administered with a "standard of care" for stroke patients. The primary outcome measure will be the "modified Rankin Scale" (mRS) score at day 90 after randomization. The safety of the drug will also be evaluated. Although the trial concluded with a positive outcome, the pharmaceutical company involved did not further pursue the commercialization of the drug.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of the two interventions in improving patient-centered mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment, as well as to explore the relationship between ASD characteristics and intervention outcomes. The interventions will be delivered through telehealth and will consist of a 12-week program with up to 4 weeks follow-up support. The trial will enroll individuals with ASD and co-occurring depression and/or anxiety, aged 18 years and older, living in North Carolina or Virginia, and able to participate without interfering with current mental health care. The primary outcome measure will be a change in the score on the Patient Health Questionnaire Anxiety-Depression Scale (PHQ-ADS). The overall goal of the study is to improve mental health services for autistic adults by identifying effective interventions to treat comorbid anxiety and depression.

[/INST] Methotrexate for the treatment of immune-related arthritis or arthralgias was the subject of this randomized, single-arm clinical trial. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-dose methotrexate as an alternative treatment option for patients with immune-related arthritis or arthralgias who had not responded to the current standard of care. The study included an intervention phase of 12 weeks, followed by an observation phase of 12 weeks. Patients who completed the induction phase had the option to continue receiving maintenance treatment with low-dose methotrexate (20 mg/week) for an additional 12 weeks. The primary endpoint of the study was the discontinuation of prednisone by 12 weeks without a recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA. Secondary endpoints included total steroid usage, the emergence of irAEs other than irAA, adverse events, and re-treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors. The study did not include a control group or additional interventions. While results were not provided in the input text, the article mentioned that the study will be published in a peer-reviewed journal to report the results. The study completed enrollment in August 2021 and is currently undergoing follow-up. The number of patients enrolled in the study was not reported.

[/INST] The study entitled, “Evaluation of the Therapeutic Effect of Adding Letrozole to the Protocol of Combined Treatment of Cesarean Scar Pregnancy” aimed to determine the effect of letrozole (an aromatase inhibitor) as an add-on treatment to combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancies. The combined treatment includes methotrexate and hysteroscopic curettage. In this study, participants were recruited who had a cesarean scar pregnancy (confirmed by ultrasound) and had increasing human chorionic gonadotropin concentrations. Exclusion criteria included: decreasing β-hCG, heterotopic pregnancy, and decreasing blood count. Women who were selected for this study were given letrozole as an add-on treatment to combined treatment or MTX monotherapy. Before the commencement of the treatment, and after one, four, and seven days, blood count was monitored. Additionally, blood tests for bilirubin, aspartate transaminase, alanine transaminase, gamma-glutamyltransferase, alkaline phosphatase, urea, and creatinine were carried out. After the combined treatment with or without letrozole, hysteroscopic curettage was performed to evacuate the uterus. The study was not placebo-controlled and randomized, and the results were reported from a small sample size of 33 patients. Thus, the level of evidence of this study was class IV. The authors reported a higher decrease in Hb concentration and blood loss during the hysteroscopic evacuation of the uterus in patients who had undergone combined treatment with letrozole. The letrozole treatment also resulted in low birth-weight babies due to the preterm deliveries. Since this study has shortcomings, such as, a small sample size, uncontrolled placebo use, no blinding, and open-label settings, the quality of evidence regarding the beneficial or detrimental effects of the letrozole add-on treatment is controversial. Therefore, further studies are needed to investigate the effects of letrozole as an add-on treatment to the combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancies.

[/INST] The proposed study is a retrospective and prospective cohort study designed to evaluate the safety of the RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination in the context of pregnancy, using follow-up data from prior RSV vaccination studies. The study includes all pregnant women and infants from prior RSV vaccination studies within two years post-vaccination to determine the rate of pregnancy outcomes, pregnancy-related AESIs and infant AESIs during the pregnancy and through 42 days postpartum. A secondary objective of the study is to evaluate pregnancy outcomes, adverse events during pregnancy and rates of preterm birth among mothers vaccinated with RSVPreF3 or control vaccines. The study protocol provides eligibility criteria, enrollment requirements, and a timeline for the study procedures. Overall, the study aims to determine the potential safety signals associated with maternal RSV vaccination among pregnant women in the context of pregnancy and add to the body of evidence on the safety of RSV vaccines.

[/INST] This cross-sectional pilot study aims to study 19F MRI as a tool for assessing lung health in children. We seek to compare healthy children to pediatric patients with mild lung disease, including cystic fibrosis and other conditions. During 19F-MRI of the lungs, study participants will inhale a biologically inert gas, PFP, to improve contrast. The goal of this study is to assess the feasibility of using 19F MRI to evaluate lung health.

[/INST] Experimentation using randomized clinical trial to evaluate the effect of distinct exercise protocols on pain, functionality and balance in athletes who are experiencing patellofemoral pain syndrome (PPSF) is described. Group A will receive open chain kinetic exercises. Group B will be offered closed chain kinetic exercises. A total of 3 sets with 10 reps of each exercise will be carried out by the participants after warm-up and stretching exercises for six weeks. Non-probability convenient sampling method will be used. Participants having an experience of at least 8 months and who are 18-30 years of age, with recurrent knee pain will comprise the sample. The findings will be recorded based on NPRS, LEFS and Y balance test results before and after intervention. SPSS software program will be employed to enter and analyze data. Patellofemoral pain syndrome will be described using both quantitative and qualitative techniques. The study design of open label, randomized clinical trials was discussed in detail.

[/INST] This study will enroll American football players to investigate the effects of a Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay (MIND) diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers. Participants will undergo a 9-week intervention consisting of a MIND diet intervention or a control group. Blood measurements will be taken pre-intervention and post-intervention to assess the biomarkers of interest in each group. The authors propose that a MIND diet intervention may reduce inflammation and oxidative stress levels in American football players, thereby providing an important preventative measure against long-term neurological damage commonly incurred by athletes in contact sports.

[/INST] A clinical trial titled "Left Bundle Branch Area Pacing in Heart Failure Patients With Ejection Fraction Below Normal" evaluated the effects of left bundle branch area pacing in patients with heart failure and mid-range or reduced left ventricular systolic function on various clinical outcomes.

[/INST] The purpose of this study is focused on assessing the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004, a recombinant IgG mAb against fentanyl. The study was designed as a randomized, single-site, single-dose, placebo-controlled study with a cohort of 72 healthy volunteers. Volunteers were sequentially randomized to receive a single subcutaneous injection of CSX-1004 at one of eight escalating single doses ranging from 10 mg to 120 mg. The primary outcome measure was the incidence, intensity, and causality of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), serious AEs, and AEs leading to discontinuation from 0 to 5 months. The primary conclusion of the study was that both single and multiple administrations of CSX-1004 were associated with an acceptable safety profile in this cohort, without interfering with the PK, PD, and safety profiles of the underlying SOC for fentanyl overdose.

[/INST] The study consisted of patients who had symptoms suggestive of prosthesis complications and underwent joint aspiration with analysis. This aspiration was then compared with the perioperative samples analysis to determine the bacteriological concordance. The study was conducted by clinicians of the department of orthopedic surgery of a Swiss hospital. The timeframe of the study is from the date of joint aspiration to the terminal date of perioperative samples bacteriological analysis.

[/INST] Objective: Airway dysfunction assessment in cystic fibrosis (CF) by dynamic inhalation of a non-invasive biomarker (i.e. perfluoropropane gas) in combination with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  Participants: adults ages 18 to 99 years diagnosed with CF by standard criteria.  Inclusion criteria: non-smokers with a history of less than 10 pack-year cigarettes smoked, no clinical evidence of respiratory infection in the past 4 weeks, and baseline (pre-treatment) forced expiratory volume (FEV1) capacity greater than 60% of predicted value.  For data analysis, participants with a minimum of 2 valid and usable dynamic imaging studies were included. Assessment: MRI was used to assess pulmonary and airway structure and function. Lung volume and ventilation defect parameters were measured at baseline and after hyperhydoxia challenge via breath-hold and tidal breathing.  Pulmonary function was measured by standard spirometry before and after bronchodilator therapy. Participants with evidence of a pulmonary exacerbation (pulmonary infection) within the study period also received a scan to evaluate changes in airway defects.  The data collected from this trial was used to develop a quantitative and automated analysis method of MRI to assess pulmonary and airway function in patients with CF.
[/INST] “A Bioequivalence Trial of Fasting Single Oral STI-1558 Capsule in Healthy Chinese Subjects”

[/INST] The aim of this study is to examine the effectiveness of disconnecting the breathing circuit during a change in position from supine to lateral in patients undergoing thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided double-lumen endobronchial tube. Inclusion criteria for the study are ASA I-II elective surgery, thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided double-lumen endobronchial tube, and signed informed consent for the study provided. Exclusion criteria are mouth opening <3 cm, previous history of difficult intubation, diseases affecting the upper respiratory tract and main bronchi, cardiac insufficiency, liver dysfunction, renal insufficient, previous stroke, a severe obstructive ventilatory dysfunction, bronchial asthma or airway hyperresponsiveness, prior participation in other clinical studies in the last 3 months, and an age below 18 and over 65. The double-lumen endobronchial tubes were inserted under general anesthesia by anesthetists involved in the study, and as soon as the patient's position changed from the supine to the lateral, a decision was made to disconnect the breathing circuit (intervention group) or leave the connection intact (control group). The position of the tube's balloon was monitored by an anesthesiologist, and the position of the tube (malposition or position <5 mm) was recorded before the disconnection, immediately after the change in position, and 1 minute after the start of single-lung ventilation. The study was designed to prevent, based on a 19.9% estimated malposition rate in the intervention group compared to an 8.8% malposition rate in the control group, with a desired effect size of 1.17 at a power level of 80% confidence with α=0.05. A total of 30 participants were required for both groups, and after the 59 drop-outs, the study ended. Malposition was defined as a shift of <5 mm from the position specified by the manufacturer, determined by a control check-radiograph. The study found no significant difference between the malposition rates in the groups, with 55% malposition in the intervention group and 40% malposition in the control group. The mean ± SD for the intervention group versus the control group were 2.16 ± 3.77 vs 1.49 ± 2.93, respectively. Of the 64 patients included in the study, 8 received additional adjustment for change in ventilatory settings for left-lung only, and they were excluded from analysis. The study concluded that disconnection of the breathing circuit did not have an effect on the malposition of the double-lumen endobronchial tube, based on the similar post-operative complications as well as the PACU length of stay measured in the intervention and control groups.

[/INST] The clinical trial "Personalized Comprehensive Diabetes Support in Children With Newly Diagnosed Type 1 Diabetes" is a comparative effectiveness trial that examines the efficacy of a 6-month personalized comprehensive diabetes support intervention for children with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The primary outcomes for the study are Diabetes Distress Scale (DDS) and Problem Areas in Diabetes (PAID). Families will be recruited to participate in the study and randomly assigned to either the control arm or the intervention arm. The intervention arm includes a 6-month comprehensive diabetes support program consisting of support classes, home visits, and individualized support calls. This study aims to identify effective interventions that can help families adjust to a new diagnosis of type 1 diabetes.

[/INST] This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial of the efficacy of monitoring and supporting depression patients to prevent relapse after discharge from hospital. The trial investigates whether the usual aftercare, consisting of a single postdischarge psychiatric appointment, can be replaced and/or supplemented by telemedicine monitoring (video consultations with nurse, optional video consultations with psychologist) combined with an online support group. The primary outcome is the treatment response rate after six months, defined as a decrease of at least 50% in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS-Depression) score compared to the baseline. The secondary outcomes include changes in depression severity using the HADS, EuroQol-5D-5L, and Stanford Presenteeism Scale, quality of life, healthcare utilization, medication adherence, integration into a psychiatric or psychological care pathways, feasibility and patient satisfaction with the telemedicine monitoring and online support group. The trial also includes several measures on cost-effectiveness of the telemedicine monitoring and online support group.

[/INST] The study titled "Novel Applications for Sarcoma Assessment" aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm using quantitative MRI to differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses. Participants with soft tissue masses at the multi-disciplinary team meeting who are undergoing an MRI scan are eligible for inclusion in the initial cohort. This cohort will have an additional 10-minute quantitative MRI sequence added to the scan, followed by a second scan after 3 years for a reproducibility study. The objective is to train an AI algorithm to diagnose and classify the lesions, and then assess its accuracy.

[/INST] This is a split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and effectiveness of microneedling alone and in combination with hyaluronic acid on thin gingival phenotype. The trial is conducted by comparing the outcomes of both procedures in the form of gingival thickness, gingival keratinized width, probing depth, and gingival index. The study proposes to utilize HA to improve the efficacy of the procedure in thin gingival phenotype, which is considered to be one of the risk factors for recession. The trial will be conducted in the Department of Periodontics and Oral Implantology, Rohtak, and total 20 patients, 24 months, will be recruited for this study in a split mouth technique. A single blinded RCT will be carried out. In the MN group, microneedling will be done 1 mm below the gingival margin with 30-gauze lancet needles, whereas in the HA with MN group, the selected sites of the gingiva will be injected with cross-linked HA using a 30-gauge microneedle followed by microneedling. The outcome will be assessed at specified time points of 1, 6, and 9 months. The participants will be randomly assigned into either of the group on a 1:1 ratio by the chit system. Randomization will be carried out to assign the participant to one of the parallel groups: either microneedling or microneedling with HA. The study has a few limitations; it is non-blinded, the findings can be affected by the menstrual cycle in female patients, and the number of participants to be enrolled is small. Although the sample size is small, a larger sample size could have given more insight. Another limitation is that the study can be prone to bias as it lacks allocation concealment. Despite these limitations, the study aims to contribute to the body of literature on MN and MN with HA as a minimally invasive option for gingival growth in thin phenotype.

[/INST] The overall objective of this study is to determine the effect of preoperative immunonutrition on surgical site infections, operative outcome, and adipose tissue inflammation in patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind controlled clinical trial involving adults aged 20 to 85 years diagnosed with primary colorectal neoplasms eligible for elective surgery. Participants were randomly assigned to receive oral supplements consisting of three scoops of Oral Impact in 150 ml of water or placebo, three times a day for 10 days before the operation. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of surgical site infection or intra-abdominal abscess, and other secondary outcome measures include the length of hospital stay, grade of inflammatory and fibrotic infiltration in adipose tissue, and the cross-sectional area of adipocytes. The study concluded that preoperative immunonutrition significantly reduced surgical site infections following colorectal surgery.

[/INST] The proposed study aims to evaluate the impact and additional benefits of adding a treatment on the eyeball with manual therapy and specific exercises in patients with migraine who have cervical muscle tension. The study will use a randomized approach and will be evaluated using scales such as the Headache Impact Test, Visual Analog Scale, Migraine Disability Assessment Questionnaire, Patient Health Questionnaire, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia, Pain Catastrophizing Scale, Central Sensitization Inventory, Neck Disability Index, Head Repositioning and the Grimmer Test, Smooth tracking test, Smooth Pursuit Neck Torsion and the Cervical Range of Motion Instrument. The study's target population is individuals who have migraine and cervical muscle tension. It is not specified if participants must be adult patients, as the age range mentioned is between 18 and 65 years old, with the inclusion criterion being age. The study will use both the Spanish and English languages. The study will last 3 months and will collect information from the beginning of the treatment to 3 months after. More details can be found in the trial.

[/INST] The study will evaluate the use of the Cratos™ stent graft in the treatment of descending aorta pathologies, specifically for the 20 patients enrolled in the study. The primary endpoint of the study is all-cause mortality within the first 30 days of the procedure. The Cratos™ stent graft is intended to be used for aortic lesions where the patients have thoracic aortic pathology, such as type B aortic dissection, intramural hemotoma, penetrating aortic ulcer, and others. The study will assess the safety and effectiveness of the Cratos™ stent graft system in treating descending aorta lesions in the patients enrolled in the study.

[/INST] The trial, “Which Approach to Favor for Ultrasound-guided Lumbar Plexus Block (BPLE) Comparative Study,” proposed the comparison of two different ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block techniques: the Trident technique and the Shamrock technique. The trial involved adults above the age of 18 years, and there were no exclusion criteria. In this trial, a lumbar echography was performed with the Trident technique and later the lumbar echography was performed with the Shamrock technique. The depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and the presence of blood vessels were analyzed with both techniques. The primary outcome measure was the projection of line C on the costiform processes. The secondary outcome measures were the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and the presence of blood vessels. The Keywords were: Trident, Lumbar plexus, ultrasound guided, Shamrock.

[/INST] A phase 3, randomized controlled trial was aimed to investigate the efficacy of preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy to minimize stress urinary incontinence (SUI) associated with laser surgery of prostate for treatment of BPH. The proposed study will compare whether group A will be effective in reducing the time of SUI, postoperative urine retention, postvoid residual volume, urine flow, overall urinary symptoms, medical and surgical complications, duration of catheter, and length of hospitalization. Patients who had SUI after prostatectomy surgery to eliminate BPH are included to study. Eligible males have to be under pre-surgical management and have not had any prior pelvic radiation, have normal bladder function, and with no neurological disorders. After surgery, patients have been allocated to two groups, namely Group A (preoperative) and those patients will receive preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy and Group B (postoperative) and receive postoperative physical therapy. The primary outcome measures were time to continence, and the secondary outcomes were urine flow, post void residual volume, overall urinary symptoms, medical and surgical complications, duration of catheter as well as length of hospitalization. This study has been concluded that group A who received preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy have higher recovery rate than group B.

[/INST] DETECT-IP is a study involving older hospitalized patients at risk for adverse drug events (ADEs), namely acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia. It is a multicentre, parallel-group, double-blind, and cluster-randomized control trial. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) in reducing such ADEs by incorporating specific rules and procedures. The CDSS will receive automatic alerts generated by routine care, and the clinical pharmacy team will verify the adequacy, relevance, and appropriateness of the alerts. If appropriate, the alerts will be addressed to the medical team with pharmaceutical interventions proposed. The study's primary outcome measure is the occurrence of such ADEs, with additional measures including clinical pharmacists' intervention, adverse events related to the provided intervention, and adverse reaction prevention/management. The study also aims to assess cost-effectiveness, changes in work processes, and determine the relevant data to the intervention to be integrated into CDSS.

[/INST] This is a prospective study being conducted in Paris, France. The study will compare bacterial communities in the ileal tissue, mesenteric fat, and blood between CD patients who have ileocecal resection and control patients who have ileocecal resection for other causes. The primary outcome measures are the proportions of bacterial taxa in the mesentery, ileal tissue and blood between CD patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The secondary outcome measure is the association analysis of genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients. The participants in the study will be adult CD patients who need ileocecal resection as part of the treatment of Crohn's disease and control patients who need ileocecal resection for other causes. The participants will be excluded if they require ileocecal resection with definitive or transient ileostomy. The study will also exclude participants who have a family history of inflammatory bowel disease. All participants must sign informed consent forms before enrollment in the study.

[/INST] The document describes a clinical study evaluating the effect of injection site on the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 (an investigational drug) in healthy participants with a high body mass index (≥27 to ≤45 kg/m2). The study is randomized and has two arms: participants will receive either a subcutaneous (SC) injection (through the skin, typically into the fatty tissue) or an intravenous (IV) injection (directly into a vein) of LY3437943, and blood will be collected from participants to measure the pharmacokinetics (PK, how the body experiences or metabolizes the drug in the blood) parameters (i.e. area under the plasma concentration versus time curve from zero to infinity (AUC(0-∞)) and maximum concentration of LY3437943 in blood (Cmax)) of LY3437943.

[/INST] This is a study on aggressive pituitary tumors, which will be conducted by a reference center for rare diseases (Centre Hospitalier Valida) in France. The study will involve a registry of patients with aggressive pituitary tumours. The study will assess the molecular and transcriptomic signature of aggressive pituitary tumours, which will be predictive of prognosis up to 3 years.

[/INST] OPTI - DOSE: Optimal Dosing of Oral Anticancer Drugs in Older Adults: A Randomized Pilot Study. Elderly individuals (≥65 years) with cancer and starting treatment with oral anticancer drugs. Randomization: 1:1 ratio. Intervention: lower starting dose with dose escalation followed by the dosing steps from the SmPC every 2 weeks in case of good tolerability. Feasibility of investigating whether a lower starting dose with a dose-escalation approach leads to better overall treatment utility compared to standard dosing. Assessed by investigators and validated with PRO-CTQOL, HADS, EQ-5D-5L, FACT-P, FACT-G, and MDASI-H&N, MDASI-OES18 and MDASI-Breast. Outcomes: feasibility, general treatment utility, quality of life, efficacy, and safety. Pharmacokinetics.

[/INST] Study Title: Preoperative short-course radiation followed by Envafolimab plus CAPEOX for MSS locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma: a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study (PRECAM-R)

[/INST] The clinical trial is titled "A Two-Stage Study of the Pharmacokinetics, Safety, and Efficacy of Levilimab". The study is divided into two stages, with stage 1 conducted in healthy volunteers and stage 2 conducted in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The objectives of stage 1 are to evaluate the safety, immunogenicity, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and tolerability of a single dose of levilimab through a phase I, open-label design; to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of multiple doses of levilimab through a phase Ib open-label study; and to determine the efficacy of different doses of levilimab compared to placebo through a 12-week, randomized, placebo-controlled, phase IIb study. The study design comprises sequential, open-label, randomized controlled trials. Stage 1 of the study will enroll healthy volunteers to receive a single subcutaneous injection or intravenous injection of levilimab. Stage 2 of the study will enroll patients with active rheumatoid arthritis resistant to methotrexate to receive one of four treatments of levilimab or placebo every 4 weeks for 52 weeks. The primary endpoint of stage 1 is safety/toxicity. The primary endpoint of stage 2 is remission. Secondary endpoints include the proportion of patients with low rheumatoid arthritis activity at week 24 of the study, ACR20/50/70, DAS28, HAQ-DI, mTSS, functional assessments, fatigue assessments, quality of life, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and safety/tolerability. The study drug is levilimab, a human monoclonal antibody against the soluble and transmembrane form of interleukin-6 receptor. Data collection methods include laboratory tests, questionnaires, patient or subject diaries, patient interviews, physical examinations, and medical history reports. The study outcomes, which are defined in the study protocol, can be evaluated using a variety of methods and assessments. The study plans to recruit a total of 233 subjects. The study's total duration will be approximately three years.

[/INST] The “Efficacy of White Kidney Bean” clinical trial is a double-blind, randomized study with a crossover design. Participants were healthy adults aged 25-45 years, with a male to female ratio of more than 4:1. The study enrolled and assessed 30 participants, with a dropout rate of 33% at the end of the trial. The study compared the efficacy of a dietary supplement (Phase 1: White Kidney Bean Pressed Candy) versus a placebo, followed by the reversed treatments after a 72-hour washout period (Phase 2: Placebo followed by White Kidney Bean Pressed Candy). Participants received chewable tablets each containing 750mg extract of White Kidney Bean, which was equivalent to 10g total, or 750mg of placebo per day. Blood glucose was recorded via Oral Glucose Tolerance Test before and after interventions.

[/INST] The MIMENTO trial is a multisite, stepped-wedge, cluster-randomized controlled trial aiming to implement the Behavioral Activation Therapy (HAP) to reduce treatment gap for depression in primary health care centers in India. Eligible participants are screened using Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) and are offered HAP by existing healthcare workers.

The abstract provides an overview of the study, including its purpose, design, inclusion and exclusion criteria for participant recruitment, outcome measures, and intervention or treatment plans.
