[/INST] The study will explore the effectiveness and safety of a combination drug regimen consisting of PLX2853, a BET inhibitor, and trametinib, a MAPK inhibitor, in treating advanced uveal melanoma. The primary objective of the study is to determine the recommended dose of this combination regimen based on safety, tolerability, and best response in patients with advanced uveal melanoma. The trial will use Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) to evaluate patients' responses to the drug regimen. The study will also include a phase II trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the regimen in treating advanced uveal melanoma. The secondary objectives of the study are to establish the safety and optimal dose of this regimen based on adverse event profiles, to characterize the safety profile of this regimen, and to investigate the pharmacokinetic profile of the regimen.

[/INST] The study title is "A 2-arm Phase IV, Randomised, Open-label Study to Evaluate the Implementation and Utility of a Primary Care Model in Patients With Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk Equivalents and Elevated LDL-C. It will be conducted in Australia as a Multi-centre Trial. The study protocol aims to evaluate the implementation of a new model of care against usual care for ASCVD in primary care. Patients will be enrolled by clinics that use Medical Director (MD) Clinical software and a list of patients who can qualify for the study will be generated by a query for patients that meet the eligibility criteria. The treatment period will be 365 days from study drug administration. The primary endpoint will be the effect of the new model of care on Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL)-C concentration. The study includes 4 key components in the novel model of care; 1) Education of GPs and their staff on ASCVD management, including lifestyle therapies and pharmacological interventions in line with GDMT 2) EMR alerts to support evidence-based care at the point of prescribing and ordering of tests 3) Pharmacist reviews focusing on adherence and addressing issues with polypharmacy and 4) Nurse-led support calls.

[/INST] The aim of this clinical trial is to compare the analgesic effects of Ultrasound Guided Erector Spinae Block, Thoracic Para-vertebral Block and Quadratus Lamborum Block in patients undergoing Renal Surgery. A single institution, parallel group, inferiority trial was conducted at urology operating theatre, Al-Azhar university hospital. Forty eight (48) Patients scheduled for elective open renal surgeries were included in this study. They were randomized to either a Ultrasound Guided Erector Spinae Block (n=12), Thoracic Paravertebral Block (n=12), Quadratus Lamborum Block (n=12) or a control group that received morphine(n=12). The primary outcome measure was the Total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively.

[/INST] The study entitled "Musculoskeletal Health in Adult Haematological Cancer Survivors" is a mixed methods study aimed at providing a more comprehensive understanding of musculoskeletal health issues and experiences in adult haematological cancer survivors. The specific aim of the quantitative aspect of the study is to describe musculoskeletal health and associated disorders among survivors of childhood haematological cancers, while the aim of the qualitative aspect is to provide a more holistic understanding of survivorship and how musculoskeletal health and disorders impact survivors. The study is innovative as it specifically focuses on adult survivors of paediatric cancer, a population that is often overlooked in cancer research. The study proposes to utilize both qualitative and quantitative methodologies to allow for a more comprehensive understanding of musculoskeletal health and disorders in this population. By describing and understanding patient experiences and perspectives, the study aims to identify areas for improvement and facilitate development of interventions to support musculoskeletal health and reduce the burden of these conditions on childhood cancer survivors. In summary, the study proposes to conduct a mixed methods study to provide a more holistic understanding of musculoskeletal health and related issues in survivors of paediatric haematological cancers.

[/INST] Disitamab vedotin is an ADC comprised of a monoclonal antibody specific for the HER2 receptor, the synthetic marine-derived chemotherapeutic agent monomethyl auristatin E (MMAE), and a protease-resistant maleimidocaproyl linker. A phase 2 basket study was conducted to assess its clinical activity and safety in participants with pre-treated HNSCC, NSCLC, ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. Patients have now completed follow-up and the study is closed. The results of the study have significantly contributed to the knowledge on the use of HER2-targeted treatments in different solid tumors.

[/INST] Driving Rehabilitation and Innovation for Evaluating Risk in Post-Intensive Care Unit Survivors is a research proposal that aims to develop a data-based system to assess and rehabilitate ICU survivors with driving deficits. To test their framework, the authors plan to study a cohort of older (55+ years) adults with risk factors for post-ICU cognitive impairment and a history of delirium during ICU stay. The participants would undergo neurocognitive testing and in-vehicle driving monitoring for a 6-month duration, and the researchers will collect kinematic driving data and analyze the data to study the relationship between neurocognitive tests and driving metrics in older ICU survivors.
[/INST] Study Overview:

[/INST] The title of this clinical trial is “Clinical Research of Drug Holiday Based on MRD Detection in GIST Patients at High Risk of Recurrence”. This one-arm observational clinical study aims to investigate the effects of drug-holiday treatment based on ctDNA MRD detection for advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

[/INST] The study aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study is a randomized, controlled trial, comparing Dohsa hou exercises to standard therapy. The intervention consists of three sets of exercises (a total of 18 sessions) and includes tasks such as bicycle training, soft tissue massage and aerobic exercises. Patients are assigned to the treatment group based on a simple random sampling method. The functional mobility is assessed using the trunk impairment scale and the time up and go test. Children between six and 12 years of age will be included in the study. The primary outcome measures are the trunk impairment scale and time up and go test, which are assessed at the start of the study and six week after the start of the intervention.

[/INST] The purpose of the study is to increase children’s physical activity levels and physical literacy by developing and testing a school-based physical education curriculum with family engagement component called the Rising New York Road Runners program. This is a group randomized controlled trial with four intervention schools and four control schools. Children will wear an Actigraph accelerometer for 7 days at study baseline and completion plus the midpoint to assess their activity levels and fitness. Trained staff will assess children’s performance across 18 different tasks at study baseline and completion using the Physical Literacy Assessment for Youth tool to assess competence in fundamental movement skill domain areas.

[/INST] A Study to Test Whether BI 456906 Helps Japanese People Living With Obesity Disease is a phase III, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, 76-week, efficacy, and safety study of BI 456906 administered subcutaneously versus placebo in patients with obesity in Japan. The primary endpoint is the percentage change in body weight from baseline to week 76.

[/INST] The objective of this trial is to evaluate whether the volume of gastric fluid in pediatric patients undergoing tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy surgery increases the risk of aspiration during operation. To achieve this, a detailed ultrasound examination of gastric volume is planned before and after surgery. Aspiration may pose a potential risk for patients undergoing an operation and can cause serious complications and increased mortality.

[/INST] Cardiac surgery is a common procedure in the treatment of coronary heart disease, heart valve disease, congenital heart disease and other heart diseases. Pituitrin is a vasoactive drug commonly used in cardiac surgery. Pituitrin exerts vascular-strengthening, vasoconstriction and anti-pulmonary vascular permeability effects through its oxytocin and vasopressin components. Studies have shown that use of pituitrin decreases postoperative complications in cardiac surgery patients. Therefore, this study intends to evaluate the effects of pituitrin on prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension who undergo cardiac surgery. The study is a parallel-group, allocating randomized, double-blind placebo-controlled superiority trial. The participants are patients with pulmonary hypertension who are scheduled for elective cardiopulmonary bypass heart surgery. The treatment group will receive pituitrin while the control group will receive normal saline. The primary outcome measure is cardiac mortality or severe complications (including stroke; requirement of mechanical ventilation longer than 48 hours; deep sternal wound infection; reoperation; or acute renal failure) within 30 days after cardiac surgery. The secondary outcome measures include occurrence of postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, time to achieve hemodynamic stability, use of dobutamine or other vasoactive drugs, incidence of digital ischemia, acute mesenteric ischemia, gastrointestinal complications, incidence of acute myocardial infarction, new onset tachyarrhythmia, water poisoning, vasodilative shock, incidence of pulmonary embolism, low cardiac output syndrome, incidence of acute respiratory distress syndrome, peri-operative and post-operative serum antidiuretic hormone levels, need for renal replacement therapy, need for hemodialysis, incidence of readmission to ICU, length of ICU stay, length of hospital stay and levels of copeptin. The measurements of pituitrin as a vasoactive drug, such as vasoconstriction and hemodynamics, as well as the effectiveness and safety of pituitrin under surgery conditions will be determined in this study.

[/INST] Home Initiation of Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation in Children with Medical Complexity is a feasibility study aimed at comparing the standard of care and a novel approach to initiate noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) at home in children with medical complexity. The standard of care involves inpatient initiation of NIPPV using a one-night, in-hospital polysomnography laborartory (PSG) with titration of NIPPV settings. The novel approach involves awaken induction and titration of NIPPV in the home setting, followed by telemonitoring and remote follow-up. The feasibility outcomes include recruitment and retention rates, crossover rates, adherence, and patient/caregiver experience. The trial outcome includes change in self- and caregiver reported quality of life (assessed using KIDSCREEN and MLQ), caregiver reported sense of mastery, home environment and environment capacity, and a qualitative assessment of patient and caregiver experience. Both groups receive standard pediatric NIPPV care. The results may have implications for quality of care for children with medical complexity.

[/INST] The study is a single-blind, randomized clinical trial where 24 female volleyball players were divided into a control group and an intervention group to compare the effects of dry needling on CMJ performance. The control group performed stretching exercises while the intervention group received dry needling on latent trigger points in the muscles. The needling was performed by the principal investigator. The needling technique applied was Hong's protocol, and the principal investigator is a sports physiotherapist with experience in the technique. The treatment of the intervention group and the CMJ were performed by the same person. Baseline measurements of each subject's CMJ were taken before the intervention, immediately after the intervention, three days later and seven days later to compare their performance. The results indicated that intervention group had significantly better CMJ performance than the control group. At 7-day follow-up, the control group significantly increased their CMJ performance compared to the pre-intervention measurement.

[/INST] This trial aims to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP) and examine the effectiveness of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in treating refractory gastrointestinal HSP. The aim is to collect evidence of HSP, a vasculitis disorder, and develop a way of preventing gastrointestinal lesions in HSP from developing into gastrointestinal damage. They would also like to see if any of the symptoms could be resolved by using MMF. The study is an open-label, single-arm, and single intervention trial that recruited pediatric refractory gastrointestinal HSP patients who range from 3 to 18 years old. Patients with gastrointestinal lesions with HSP, which do not respond to the standard treatment, were treated with MMF. The primary outcome for the study is the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools, which were measured by the checklist for 6 months. For the adverse effects of the drug, the patients were closely examined during the 6 months. For the secondary outcome, patients were asked to submit the stool samples to be tested for blood. This trial found that MMF can relieve the gastrointestinal symptoms of HSP and it may help to prevent the gastrointestinal symptoms from developing into gastrointestinal damage. However, the limitation of this study is the short duration of treatment.

[/INST] This is a Phase II/III safety, feasibility, and efficacy study of adjunctive EEG-enhanced rTMS (eTMS) in Veterans with TSRD for six weeks. In the first part of the study, a safety monitoring is conducted with 30 participants. Subsequently, the rest of the participants are randomized. The randomization ratio is unclear. The primary outcome is safety based on number of participants who develop device related serious adverse events. The primary efficacy outcome is treatment completion, based on number of participants who complete at least 80% of eTMS sessions. The secondary outcomes are changes in VR36 mental component scores from baseline to 6 weeks.

[/INST] A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of radiotherapy plus epidermal growth factor receptor-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (EGFR-TKI) for stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer patients. Patients with lung cancer diagnosed by pathology and positive for EGFR mutation were eligible for the study. Combined radiotherapy and targeted therapy with a dose of 54-66 Gy were administered, and the targeted therapy used included gefitinib, erlotinib, erlotinib, oseltinib, and ametinib. These drugs were taken until disease progression or intolerability and progression-free survival (PFS) was assessed as the primary outcome.

[/INST] The aim of this microbiology study is to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute infections in the head and neck region, specifically those of Streptococci. Participants over 18 who reside in Northampton and have been admitted to the hospital for acute head and neck infection and are suffering from Streptococcus are eligible for this study. The study involves measuring the identification of Streptococci species using DNA analysis of RNA genes and biochemical tests, as well as capturing patient characteristics such as age, sex, and site of infection, and clinical outcomes such as the length of hospital stay and antibiotic treatment. The sample size for this study is not provided, however, it is a 4-year study, which gives an indication of the time frame. The study involves measuring the patient's age in years, biological gender, site of infection, length of hospital stay, antibiotic treatment, and diabetic diagnosis.

[/INST] Study Description: Participants between 29 and 49 years of age have complained of stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks, and have given birth and have signed an informed consent form. The study was performed during the period of 7/21/2021-30/10/2021. The study sample size was 48 participants, divided into two groups of 24 individuals each. Group I participants received functional magnetic stimulation for stress urinary incontinence, while group II participants received a pelvic floor muscle training program. Each participant was examined before the intervention. A final examination was performed after 6 weeks. Participants assessed their response to the therapy using a General questionnaire, the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7). Also, perineometry was used to measure the strength and endurance of the individuals' pelvic floor muscles. All the data of each group were analyzed using SPSS-26 statistics software and Microsoft Excel 365. In this study, functional magnetic stimulation for incontinence was compared to the pelvic floor muscle training program.

[/INST] The summary of the article focuses on the Optimization of Psoriatic and Seronegative Rheumatoid Arthritis Patients Selection and Treatment Outcomes of Biologic Therapies study, which aims to analyze biomolecular and cellular mechanisms of skin psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, and PsA in the generation of pus and other manifestations using immunohistological and immunostaining techniques

[/INST] This randomized controlled study, titled "The Use of Artificial Tears to Prevent Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction in Patients Treated With Radioactive Iodine for Thyroid Cancer," is designed to assess the preventive effect of artificial tears on nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). Patients who undergo radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer are randomly assigned to an experimental arm or a no-treatment arm. The participants in the experimental group apply methylcellulose drops to their eyes for four consecutive days after radioactive iodine therapy, while those in the control group do not receive any treatment. The primary outcome of the study is NLDO, which is evaluated by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist. The intervention is not blinded. The aim of the study is to determine the impact of artificial tears on the incidence of NLDO following radioactive iodine treatment. Both arms have a 2-year follow-up period.

[/INST] The trial is a phase II randomized controlled trial that will compare treatment with 80 mg of atorvastatin versus a placebo for high-risk melanoma patients for whom surgery is complete without evidence of recurrence. Participants will be followed for 5 years. The primary objective is to compare the recurrence-free survival between the placebo and atorvastatin arms. The first secondary objective is to compare distant metastasis free survival. The second secondary objective is to compare overall survival.

[/INST] The ACHIEVE Initiative aims to improve maternal health outcomes by increasing recognition and treatment of hypertension in pregnancy. [/INST] The study aimed to use text messages to reduce drinking in older adults. It compared three interventions: gain-framed, loss-framed and gain/loss-framed text messages to reduce drinking. [/INST] The clinical trial described in this document aims to investigate the safety of a new radiotracer called 18F-Fluselenamyl and its ability to image β-amyloid in the human brain. Previous studies have used 11C-PIB to image β-amyloid, but this new radiotracer, 18F-Fluselenamyl, promises to be superior due to its better metabolic stability and lower radiation. The study will also evaluate the sensitivity of this new tracer in patients with Alzheimer's disease or Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). The patients will then undergo a detailed medical examination, receive brain scans, and monitor their side effects for two weeks after the injection.

[/INST] The Long-term Effect of TMS in Primary Progressive Aphasia is a clinical trial that aims to evaluate the long-term effects of theta-burst transcranial magnetic stimulation (active) over the left DLPFC and language therapy on primary progressive aphasia. The trial will enroll 60 participants diagnosed with PPA according to the Gorno-Tempini criteria, who will be randomly assigned to one of two treatment arms: TMS (active) + language therapy or TMS (sham) + language therapy. The trial will use the Words per Minute test, the Mini-Linguistic State Examination test, FDG-PET imaging (SUVr), and Interview for Determination in Daily Living in Dementia (IDDLD) to assess different outcome measures, such as language and executive functioning, every three months for six months.

[/INST] The study is an interventional, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial evaluating the impact of Methylprednisolone, a commonly used oral corticosteroid, on cognitive deficits in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome. The study includes patients aged 18 and above with post-COVID-19 syndrome and ongoing cognitive deficits, which are defined as complaints of significant cognitive impairments in the Memory and MoCA domains. The subjects will be randomly assigned to two parallel groups: the Treatment Group receiving Methylprednisolone and a control group receiving placebo. The patients will receive Methylp-rednisolone (16 mg/kg) orally (PO) once daily or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by a one-week treatment pause. The participants will be examined at baseline, at the end of treatment week at week 8, at week 20 (follow-up visit) and after 52 weeks (telephone follow-up). Outcomes will be assessed at baseline, at week 8 and week 20 follow-up visits. The primary outcome measures include an increase in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire subdomain (MMQ) at 8 weeks post-treatment versus baseline. The trial is expected to begin in June 2023.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of an oral nutritional treatment rich in omega-3 and olive polyphenols in combination with inflammation and physical exercise on the aetiological factors of malnutrition in adults with malnutrition. Participants will be randomly assigned to intervention (treatment with oral nutritional supplement) or control (receiving personalized food advice) groups. The trial will collect data on malnutrition and inflammation markers and bioelectrical impedance to evaluate the effect of treatment on the inflammatory index of malnutrition after 12 and 13 weeks of evaluation. The results of the study could contribute to validating an effective treatment for the aetiological factors of malnutrition.

[/INST] Kaiser Permanente Evaluating Nutritional Interventions in Food-Insecure High-Risk Adults Study is a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of financial incentives and home delivery on decreasing hemoglobin A1c levels in food-insecure patients with HbA1c > 7.5% using diabetes-related quality of life, health care utilization, nutrition security and food security measures.

[/INST] The selected study is a randomized clinical trial on the evaluation of the solvent evaporation time of universal adhesives in the quality of cervical dentin restorations. The study compares the effect of solvent evaporation times of two universal adhesives on the quality of cervical dentin restorations. The study will be conducted with 150 non-carious cervical lesion sites, each site with one individual material tested in random sequence, with 3 sites as a single tooth. The experimental groups are the universal adhesive Scotchbond Universal Plus (water/alcohol-based solvent) and Gluma Universal Bond (acetone-based solvent). The control groups are the same universal adhesives with solvent evaporation time reduced to 5 seconds. The restorations will be examined at baseline, after 6 and 24 months. The results will be assessed using the clinical parameters retention and marginal staining from the FDI World Dental Federation criteria, and marginal adaptation.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a phase II/III randomized, double-blinded, and placebo-controlled trial. The primary objective is to assess the protective efficacy and safety of a new mRNA-based coronavirus vaccine against acute respiratory disease caused by coronaviruses in individuals aged 18 years or older. The vaccine will be tested against a placebo control group. Participants will receive two doses of the vaccine at least three weeks apart and the trial will follow participants for up to six months. The new mRNA-based vaccine is designed to stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies and T cells that target the spike proteins of various coronaviruses, including the novel coronavirus. The vaccine will be administered intramuscularly. Outcome measurements include the seroprofile of antibodies after vaccination, the safety profile, and the protection against acute respiratory illness caused by coronaviruses. The study will use a statistical approach to compare the vaccine efficacy to the placebo group and to assess the overall safety profile. The findings of this study will contribute to the development of effective and safe vaccines against acute respiratory diseases caused by coronaviruses.

[/INST] The Esbjerg Cohort is a single-center, cross-sectional study conducted in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark. The study involves all citizens between 55 and 70 years from the municipality and measures both exposure to ergonomic risk factors such as physical workload, work ability and musculoskeletal pain. The study also includes physical capability tests such as 7-day physical activity data, grip strength, maximal oxygen consumption, muscle strength and balance. Blood samples, urine analysis, and magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbar spine are collected as well. The primary outcome is work ability measured by the Work Ability Index at baseline. The primary objective of this study is to identify the consequences of high physical workload on the musculoskeletal system in the oldest group of workers, with regards to work ability, musculoskeletal pain and physical test results.

[/INST] This is a dose escalation phase I clinical trial of L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells in patients with SCCNPC. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of dose-limiting adverse events, and the secondary outcome measures are overall response rate and progression-free survival. Patients must have been previously treated with platinum-based chemotherapy for SCNPC and have measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 criteria. Patients must have L1CAM(+), CEA(−) and CK(−) tumors confirmed by immunohistochemical staining. Patients must be aged ≥ 18 years and have adequate bone marrow, liver and renal function. Patients who have previously received or have active prior malignancies within the last 3-year period, and patients with active HIV are excluded from the study.

[/INST] The summary of the study, "Most Total Pancreatectomies for Ductal Adenocarcinoma Can Be Replaced by Whipple Over the Splenic Artery: A Before and After Study," is provided below. The study was performed on 40 consecutive patients who underwent WOTSA for PDAC, and their clinicopathological characteristics, survival, and comparison with a historical control group comprising 30 consecutive patients who underwent TP were analyzed.

[/INST] The study "Effects of Melatonin on Sleep Spindles in Children with Autism" is a clinical trial that aims to examine the effects of melatonin on sleep spindle density and sleep quality. The study uses polysomnography that can record during natural sleep conditions and allows the participants to sleep at home to investigate the effect of melatonin on sleep spindle density in children with autism aged 12-18 years. The melatonin used in the study is 5mg of melatonin gummy, which is given 30 minutes before sleep, and the duration of the study is 5 nights of sleep. The sleep spindle density and sleep quality will be measured, and the primary outcome measure is the change in sleep spindle density. The results of the study are expected to contribute to the development of melatonin treatment in children with autism.

[/INST] Summary:  This study protocol describes a cross-sectional observational study to evaluate the etiological factors of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) in children with operated velopalatal cleft (VPC). [/INST] The study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for chronic sinusitis. Patients diagnosed with chronic sinusitis based on Chinese guidelines for diagnosis and treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis will be included. The primary outcome measure is the non-reintervention rate after the subjects undergo functional endoscopic sinus surgery. The subjects will be randomized to receive either a bioabsorbable or a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent implantation. The secondary outcome measures include the Lund-Kennedy score and Lund-Mackay score, VAS score, sinus panty rate, and implantation successful rate. The study is expected to conclude in 2024.

[/INST] Participant Eligibility: This clinical trial is eligible for patients who are at least 18 years old, diagnosed with multiple myeloma, receiving care from a provider within the Division of Oncology at the primary Siteman Cancer Center site, have the ability to read, speak, and understand English, and reside within the catchment area of a Siteman Cancer Center satellite site.

[/INST] Virtual Reality vs Nitrous Oxide in Pediatric Dentistry is a study comparing the effect of nitrous oxide and virtual reality headsets on pain relief in pediatric patients during dental procedures. The study includes a prospective, randomized, interventional crossover design, and behavior, pain scale evaluations. Patients were randomly assigned to either nitrous oxide or a virtual reality headset group as an interventional treatment. The primary outcome measures of the study were the rate of effectiveness of nitrous oxide and virtual reality in reducing pain. The pain scale was measured using the Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying Consolability (FLACC) and WongBaker FACES scales during injection and procedure. The secondary outcome measure was the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality distraction in pain reduction. Patients were observed during the procedure using the Houpt Behavioral Scale and categorized from 0 to 2, with 0 representing relaxed and comfortable and 1-10 representing varying levels of pain. The virtual reality headset was effective in reducing pain in a child population. The study identified VR as a viable option for pain relief in pediatric dental patients.

[/INST] The aim of the study was to determine whether it is possible to use the mutation profile and clinical-pathologic phenotype of colorectal neoplasia to personalize patient treatment plans and determine the best surveillance strategy for detecting metachronous lesions after the index procedure. The study plan involved a combination of genotyping and phenotyping of patients, and follow up over a 5-year period after their index colonoscopy. The primary outcome measure was the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify patients with a risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and personalization of their treatment plans based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype.

[/INST] The SAM Project (Science Against Malnutrition Project) is exploring the pathophysiological mechanisms of malnutrition using a multidisciplinary approach combining advanced molecular technologies such as metabolomics and metagenomics with standard clinical care. The study plans to collect data and samples from people who are affected by malnutrition, using clinical, anamnestic, and lifestyle data and integrating this information with samples analyses. The SAM Project will explore targeted biomarkers for the identification of malnutrition as well as extracellular vesicles, microRNAs, and specific metabolic pathways. The study will identify novel metabolic disturbances associated with different subtypes of malnutrition across different age groups to explore potential new therapeutic strategies.

[/INST] The study protocol describes a 12-month randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effects of three different approaches to supporting physical activity and exercise in people with Parkinson's disease. Participants will be randomized to receive one of three interventions: (1) standard care (control group), (2) written exercise education from the medical team or (3) physical therapy that focuses on exercise and physical activity. Participants will receive a wearable exercise tracker that syncs with the cloud platform to track their exercise levels. They will be asked to log in to the application every 3 months to view their progress and discuss their exercise and physical activity with their medical team during in-person or telehealth visits .

[/INST] The "Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (Cough Assist) in Critically Ill Adults (ACACIA)-a Randomized Clinical Feasibility Trial" is a clinical trial that aims to investigate the efficacy and feasibility of mechanically assisted coughing in critically ill adults. The trial involves two study arms, where one group receives MI-E and the other is randomized to receive standard airway care. The trial is being conducted in eight participating ICUs in a French tertiary care hospital. The intervention is administered twice a day for up to seven days or until extubation. The primary outcome is the proportion of complete sessions of MI-E delivered every calendar day, while the secondary outcomes include incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, severe hypertension, severe hypotension, feasibility of intervention, acceptance of intervention, appropriateness of intervention, use of endotracheal suctioning, manual hyperinflation, and VAP. The study is currently in the recruitment phase, with a planned study completion in September 2023.

[/INST] Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT study) is a multicenter randomized phase III clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of enavogliflozin in patients with tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The study aims to assess the potential of enavogliflozin, the sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitor, for the improvement of heart failure in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The primary endpoint is the first occurrence of cardiovascular event, including cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, or worsening of TR, during the 18-month follow-up.

[/INST] The clinical trial titled "Physical Activity and FVIII Elimination: Relevance to Personalized Therapy in Severe Hemophilia A" will investigate the relationship between physical activity and pharmacokinetics of infused rec-FVIII concentrate. The study will enroll patients with severe HA aged 12-60 years old with severe HA and under FVIII prophylaxis. Patients' physical activity will be monitored using a SenseWear armband or a metabolic Holter. The main outcome measure is the relationship between the area under the curve (AUC) of PK parameters and the mean number of daily steps. The study will use a crossover design to compare the results of the two groups and evaluate whether and how the PK parameters are significantly associated with the mean daily number of steps. The results of the study may contribute to the development of personalized treatment strategies and improve patient quality of life.

[/INST] The summary of the provided clinical trial document titled "Critical Time Window for Rehabilitation After Incomplete Spinal Cord Injury: Early vs Late Locomotor Training" is the following: Spinal cord injury is an injury in which a person loses control over the body and the limbs below the level of injury. Problems such as spasticity, muscle weakness, and decreased joint range of motion may result. While rehabilitation is still in progress, studies show that muscle mass and functional abilities can improve. The trial will test the idea that starting a more intense rehabilitation program as soon as possible after the injury improves the chances of these improvements. The purpose of the research is to determine if initiating early locomotor training in patients with subacute and chronic spinal cord injuries can improve walking speed, walking distance, and the ability to live and function independently. The study plan proposes that participants will be randomly divided into two groups: those receiving a high level of assistance and those receiving no assistance or only a standard amount of assistance if needed.
[/INST] The Effect of Education Given According to the Health Promotion Model on Premenstrual Symptoms, Emotional Eating Behavior and Perceived Stress

[/INST] AMP SCZ® Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC was a multi-stage project that used a consortium of CHR research sites to collect and analyze biomarker and outcome data to help predict trajectories and outcomes in people at high risk for psychosis. The study used an exponential decline nonlinear regression to predict the conversion rate to psychosis and remission in patients with a CHR condition. Additionally, machine learning and logistic regression algorithms were used to predict the likelihood of remission and outcome in CHR patients, taking into account a range of clinical, cognitive, neurophysiologic, neuroimaging, genetic, and biomarker data. The analysis found an association of increased years of education with improved chances of remission in CHR patients. The study also identified a set of biological biomarkers that were predictive of CHR outcome. The AMP SCZ® Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC project was a collaborative effort between an international network of research sites, MGB, and the NIMH Data Archive. It provided valuable insights into the biological and clinical factors that influence the outcomes of people at high risk for psychosis, which can improve diagnosis, treatment, and development of precision medicine interventions for patients with psychosis.

[/INST] The title of the manuscript is “Feasibility and acceptability of Problem Management Plus (PM+) for prisoners in the Netherlands - a pilot RCT”. The study was designed as a single-blind pilot randomized controlled trial. The primary objectives of the study were to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of PM+ adapted for prisoners in the Netherlands. The specific aim of this proposed study was to pilot the first phase of the intervention, Problem Management Plus (PM+). The target number of participants was sixty, who were initially prisoners in Dutch prisons. During the trial, participants received either five sessions of PM+ or treatment as usual. The primary parameters were PM+ fidelity, perceptions about PM+ from the study participants, indicators of intervention delivery, retention rates of PM+ sessions, recruitment, and consent rates. Secondary parameters were symptoms of depression and anxiety and self-identified problems (problem management), daily functioning, and symptoms of trauma and suicidal vulnerability. The results of the study showed that the feasibility and acceptability of the trial was determined; however, the recruitment was low. Furthermore, it was concluded that the pilot RCT would need substantial restructuring.

[/INST] A Phase I Study of ARV-471 in Patients with ER + /HER2- Advanced Breast Cancer in China" is a clinical trial that investigates the safety and efficacy of a new drug, ARV-471, given to postmenopausal women with estrogen receptor positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 negative (ER+/HER2-) advanced breast cancer (ABC) in China. ARV-471 is a novel orally bioavailable selective estrogen receptor degrader (SERD) that induces the degradation of the ERα protein through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. The trial plans to recruit 37 participants to evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety (including safety, tolerability, and dose-limiting toxicity [DLT]), pharmacodynamics, and preliminary efficacy of ARV-471 with or without fulvestrant. The trial will use a combination of serum and plasma samples to measure the pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamics, preliminary efficacy, and safety parameters. The results of the trial will inform the optimization of the regimen and dosing schedule for future clinical trials.

[/INST] This is a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial to assess the safety and efficacy of olaparib and alpelisib. Olaparib is an oral PARPi and alpelisib is an oral inhibitor of the class I PI3K. The PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway regulates cellular growth, proliferation, metabolism and survival. A combination of olaparib with alpelisib may further inhibit cellular survival and cancer progression.

[/INST] TREND-MDD is a randomized controlled clinical trial that will compare schema therapy with treatment as usual, in outpatients meeting criteria for chronic, treatment resistant MDD and reporting clinician-rated moderate-to-high levels of CRT on an integrated measure. The study intends to explore the following aims: The effectiveness of ST on a) symptomatology, b) personal recovery post treatment and c) the expected reduction of treatment costs relative to treatment as usual after 12 and 24 months follow-up. Additional process-oriented outcome measures will be included in order to assess treatment feasibility, acceptability and mechanism of change. The TREND-MDD trial is a partnership between the Department of Applied Psychology, Faculty of Psychology and Education, KU Leuven, the Department of Psychiatry, Psychotherapy and Neuroscience, Centre Hospitalier - Universitaire Val de Marne (CHUV) (France), and the Department of Psychotherapy and Clinical Settings, Department of Clinical and Health Psychology and Psychotherapy, University Hospital Utrecht, Faculty of Medicine (UU), VU University Amsterdam (VU), and the Danish Mental Health Society, (IUP).

[/INST] The study aims to evaluate the role of paramedical protocol care on survival and number of days free of mechanical ventilation in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will be a cluster randomized controlled open trial. Clusters will be intensive care units of hospitals in the western region of France. Each unit will be subjected to interventional steps. The intervention will include a paramedical protocol for ventilatory management of patients with ARDS will be adjusted by nurses. The primary outcome measure of the study will be the composite outcome of 28-day mortality with or without ventilation. The secondary outcomes will include tidal volumes, plateau pressure, positive endexpiratory pressure, oxygenation, ventilation-free days, catecholamine-free days, sedation-free days, mechanical ventilation duration, mortality, pneumothorax, ARDS duration, weaning duration, reintubation, NIV and curative high-flow oxygen therapy use within the 28 days, tracheostomy rate, intensive care and hospital length of stay, and hospital mortality. The study will enroll 1,200 critical care patients with ARDS diagnosis, and will observe the participants for 28 days.

[/INST] Summary Text: Feasibility Trial of Preoperative 5-Day Hypofractionated Radiotherapy for Primary Soft Tissue Sarcoma . Tumors of the soft tissues, such as rhabdomyosarcoma and liposarcoma , can affect various regions of the body, including the limbs, abdomen, and chest wall. These sarcomas can be challenging to manage because they do not respond well to traditional treatment methods, such as chemotherapy. Radiation therapy has often been used as an alternative or adjuvant therapeutic modality, but conventional radiotherapy (CRT) is time-consuming and requires multiple fractions per day over a period of several weeks. This can be especially burdensome for patients with extremity soft tissue sarcomas who must endure daily treatments and their potential side effects . As a result, hypofractionated radiotherapy (HFRT) has been proposed as a more convenient and efficient alternative to CRT. HFRT involves delivering a higher radiation dose per fraction but over a shorter duration than conventional radiotherapy. Studies have shown that it can be as effective as CRT in treating soft tissue sarcomas while minimizing the burden on patients . This clinical trial aims to investigate the feasibility and effectiveness of HFRT in managing soft tissue sarcomas, such as rhabdomyosarcoma and liposarcoma. The study will examine participants' response to HFRT, with the primary outcome being the feasibility rate of HFRT. The secondary outcomes include the proportion of participants with a favorable pathologic response, with low major wound complications, and 1-year local control rate. Overall, this trial could provide valuable insights into the potential benefits and drawbacks of HFRT for the management of soft tissue sarcomas.

The study aims to explore the efficacy of 810-nm, 2.8 W, 200 meV photodiode-pumped solid-state laser therapy for plantar fasciitis in active duty military service members. The study will use a randomized, sham-controlled study design, with participants randomized to either treatment with active laser or a sham laser prior to their baseline visit, follow-up at three weeks, and again six months after initial follow-up. The study's primary outcome will be the ability to walk 6 km in less than 35 minutes, while the secondary outcomes will be pain levels and functional ability. The study aims to enroll 60 participants, with 30 in each group, but may be increased if determined by a data safety monitoring board to be necessary. Ethics approval was obtained for the study. Eligible participants must be active duty military members, at least 18 years old, and have been diagnosed with plantar fasciitis in the past six months, with pain levels of greater than 2 out of 10 on a visual analog scale and have not experienced 15 or more minutes of heel pain upon waking. Ineligible participants will include those that have had an anterior cruciate ligament or infrapatellar ligament repair in the past six months, have a known allergy to latex, or are currently pregnant or trying to get pregnant. Recruitment will involve e-mails, physical flyers, and social media advertisements. No participants will be provided any medication, device, or pay to participate in the study. Participants will be permitted to use anti-inflammatory and pain medication if needed. The intervention will comprise eight laser treatments, each lasting for 10 minutes, of 810nm laser therapy to the plantar fascia. The treatment plan includes one office visit and three additional visits within the following 2 weeks. The study will include three main outcome measures: pain levels at rest, worst pain, and average pain during walking using a visual analog scale, time to walk 1 mile as a sub-item, and 6-km walk test time as the main item. All outcome measurements will be completed prior to, 3 weeks post-intervention, and 6 months post-intervention. The study is a parallel group, single-masked RCT design. It is unclear from the manuscript to what extent the authors will blunt for bias, but there is some evidence of this. For example, the study includes a run-in period of at least 2 weeks to avoid natural or placebo-related improvements from confounding the results. The study also has blinding between the groups and an intention-to-treat analysis, which is important

[/INST] REDOS trial is a randomized clinical trial that compared 4 arms of treatments within 2 groups, one group received pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) procedure either alone or combined with SB, while the other group received either perfluoropropane (PFPP or C3F8) gas or sulfur hexafluoride (SHF6 or SF6) tamponade after PPV procedure . Patients over the age of 18 years diagnosed with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) with a maximum retinal detachment of less than half of the globe and without proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) of grade C3 or higher participated in the trial. Two of 4 arms in each group contained PPV combined with SB, while the other two arms contained PPV with gas tamponade. Patients were enrolled by 28 centres in 5 countries. All participants received some form of vitrectomy procedure and were followed up for at least 5 years. The study's primary endpoint was the single surgery anatomic success, defined as the status of no longer requiring additional surgery due to recurrent RRD. At the completion of the study, it was found that the primary endpoint of anatomic success differed insignificantly in all four arms. The incidence of laser retinopexy was lower in two PPV & Gas Tamponade arms. The quality-of-life (QoL) score was higher in the two PPV & Gas Tamponade groups. No differences were seen in other endpoints such as visual acuity improvement or number of complications.

The P-KIDs CARE is a study in Tanzania that aims to improve delivery of pediatric care by implementing an intervention that includes the WHO's Basic Emergency Care Course and a decision-support tool, and to determine the feasibility, fidelity, and acceptability of the intervention. The P-KIDs CARE intervention will be provided to participating health workers. Follow-up surveys and qualitative interviews will be conducted with participating health workers to understand their experiences with the intervention and to refine it. The P-KIDs CARE intervention will be piloted at two health facilities in the study region. The study will assess the effects of the P-KIDs CARE intervention on patient mortality and morbidity, disposition, and time from injury to definitive care. Additionally, the study will examine the use of the pediatric injury registry and identify research priorities for pediatric injury in the region.

[/INST] Very Short Course Versus Standard Course Antibiotics in Patients With Cholangitis Study is a randomized, multicenter, open-label, non-inferiority clinical trial. Acute cholangitis is a complication of biliary diseases that occurs at a rate of 462 per 100,000 person-years in the Netherlands and most commonly treated by short course antibiotics. However, there is currently no evidence to support the optimal duration of antibiotic therapy for acute cholangitis. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the shorter duration of antibiotic antibiotics on the relapse of infection with a duration of no more than 24 hours, compared to standard (4-7 days) antibiotic treatment. Moreover, this study aims to evaluate the safety of the very short duration of antibiotics compared to the standard duration, including adverse events such as recurrence of infection, worsening of initial infection, and the emergence of antibiotic resistance. The findings of this study could enable the provision of a precise and evidence-based recommendation for the optimal duration of antibiotic therapy for acute cholangitis. The study is scheduled to recruit from 641 to 1004 participants and has a planned end date of February 2026.

[/INST] This clinical trial is a single-center, non-blinded, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of lung recruitment after conventional oxygen insufflation and ultrasound-guided lung recruitment in morbidly obese patients for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The conventional group will receive conventional oxygen insufflation of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds after induction and every hour until the end of surgery, while the ultrasound-guided group will receive ultrasound-guided recruitment using manual pressure of 10 cmH2O for 10 seconds and then increased by 10 cmH2O every 10 seconds until no collapsed areas can be seen on ultrasound with a maximum pressure of 40 cmH2O if the collapsed area is still detectable. The primary outcome measures are change in LUS score and the incidence of atelectasis after lung recruitment. The secondary outcome is the incidence of post-operative oxygen desaturation. The authors conclude that although ultrasound-guided lung recruitment can effectively eliminate atelectasis, more high-quality studies are needed in the future to confirm the results.

[/INST] Trial registration is a process that involves registering scientific studies in a publicly available database. This is done to provide transparent reporting of health research data and to enhance the dissemination of study results. In clinical trials, the primary goal is typically to assess the efficacy and safety of a drug, medical device, or other intervention. Trial registration helps to ensure that the results of these trials are made available to the scientific community and the public at large. Several databases have been established for the purpose of trial registration, including Medline, PubMed, and the World Health Organization's International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (WHO-ICTRP). By making use of these databases, researchers can easily access information about ongoing clinical trials, as well as find relevant studies to use as comparators in their own research.

[/INST] The objective of the protocol is to compare effects between 2 groups of participants with incomplete spinal cord injury (i.e., AIHH + tSCS-paired strength training (intervention) versus SHAM AIHH + SHAM tSCS strength training (control)). The protocol is using a crossover, randomized, controlled, single-blinded design. This protocol assesses the effects of acute intermittent hypercapnic hypoxia (AIHH) and transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) on respiratory and upper extremity functioning in individuals with respiratory dysfunction from incomplete spinal cord injury. The protocol consists of 2 intervention arms: 1) AIHH paired with tSCS-resisted strength training for respiration (intervention 1), and 2) SHAM AIHH paired with SHAM tSCS-resisted strength training for respiration (control). The two interventions aim to compare the effects of AIHH with and without tSCS, as transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) is a novel intervention to reduce deficits in respiratory and upper extremity function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury. The protocol will be implemented in an individual with incomplete spinal cord injury and respiratory dysfunction, who will undergo five sessions of the two interventions separated by a washout period to minimize carry-over effects. The study will assess the effects of the interventions on respiratory function through transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and neurophysiology, airway occlusion pressure (P0.1) and cardiovascular response to hyperoxia exposure via oxygen saturation (SpO2), oximetry, blood pressure (BP), and heart rate (HR), upper extremity functional assessments, as well as quality of life and self-efficacy metrics before and after each intervention.

[/INST] The "Comparing Minimally Invasive Treatments for Pilonidal Disease: LA POPA Trial" study is a comparative trial that evaluates two minimally invasive treatment methods for Pilonidal sinus disease, a chronic dermatological condition. The first method involves pit picking surgery, which involves surgically removing the infected pits and surrounding skin. The second method is a laser assisted closure technique, which is performed after pit picking surgery. The study includes patients aged 12 and older with primary pilonidal sinus disease with an indication for (laparoscopic) excision or tract excision. The active control group received pit picking surgery and the experimental group received pit picking surgery and laser-assisted sinus closure. The primary outcome of the study was the success rate of the treatment, defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year. The study found that the treatment success rate of laser-assisted sinus closure was significantly higher than pit picking surgery at both 1-year follow-up and after > or equal > 3 years. The study concluded that laser-assisted sinus closure is likely to be a superior method of treatment for pilonidal sinus disease when compared to pit-picking surgery.

[/INST] We aimed to use natural language processing (NLP) to extract relevant information from a clinical trial protocol related to PNH. Specifically, we used a pre-trained NLP model known as EHR-NLP on text data obtained from the National Library of Medicine. Additionally, we performed word embedding using TF-IDF to visualize the relatedness of words in the dataset. Word embedding refers to the computational representation of words, where similar words have a similar vector representation . A vector, which can be thought of as an arrow pointing from the origin of a coordinate space, is a 3-digit number (x, y, z) that represents words. To visualize the relationship between words, we plotted the arrows in a 3-dimensional coordinate space, where the x, y, and z values of each arrow (the words) are the values of their corresponding vectors in that space. TF-IDF, which stands for term frequency-inverse document frequency, is a numerical statistic that ranks words based on their frequency of occurrence within a body of text and the frequency with which they occur in other bodies of texts. Conceptually, TF-IDF considers more frequent words to be more relevant than less frequent words within the body of text. To put it simply, the algorithm determines which words are important in a document based on how frequently they occur in that document compared to how frequently they occur in other documents. We visualized the relationships between the words in the dataset using Gephi (https://gephi.org/), a tool for network visualization built in Java using the ForceAtlas2 algorithm. The algorithm is a force-directed model for network layout that arranges nodes in two dimensions. Nodes that are more related to one another are pulled closer together, and those that are less related are pushed further apart. The algorithm uses a gravity-like simulation to minimize the length and curvature of links so that forces push nodes into low-energy states. The result is a visually appealing two-dimensional plan that allows for the detection of complex patterns in high-dimensional data. The ForceAtlas2 algorithm creates a network layout in which all links are minimized, and is effective in handling large amounts of data with relatively few nodes.

[/INST] The STARgraft-3 clinical trial is a single-group evaluation trial that examines the patency and use of the STARgraft-3 biomaterial device as a hemodialysis access for patients with end-stage renal disease. The primary outcome measure is unassisted patency which is the proportion of participants without an occurrence of an access thrombosis or access procedure performed to maintain patency up to 6 months post-implantation. Other outcome measures include assisted patency (the proportion of subjects retaining patency after one or more interventions so long as patency was not lost at any point) and frequency of interventions (procedures that are required to rescue or salvage STARgraft-3 grafts that have lost patency). The graft must be cannulated at least once for hemodialysis to result in positive blood flow data. Ultrasound measurements of blood flow may be used to detect patency trends with time. Other outcome measures are secondary patency (the proportion of subjects without loss of access at the original implant site), cumulative patency (which includes unassisted patency, assisted patency, secondary patency, access thrombosis, and access procedures performed), frequency of interventions, and safety outcomes (frequency and severity of adverse events).

Participants will be randomized to the tirzepatide or placebo arm and will continue their usual T1DM therapy throughout the trial. Additional safety assessments include change from baseline in adverse events, insulin dose and body weight throughout the trial with a focus on severe hypoglycemia episodes, gastrointestinal symptoms, cholecystokinin, thyroid hormones, magnesium, and other metabolic parameters. The main objectives of the trial are to determine the safety and efficacy of tirzepatide in adults with T1DM, BMI ≥ 30 and HbA1c ≤ 10%. The trial is expected to determine the efficacy and safety of tirzepatide in increasing the weight and improving HbA1c, glycemic control, blood pressure, and inflammatory biomarkers of patients with T1DM and obesity.

Primary and secondary endpoints include lymph nodal radicality, tumor free margin, lenght of termianl ileum, anatomical integrity of mesocolon, type of surgical procedure (video-assisted, laparoscopic, robotic), vascular anatomy and number of harvested lymph node and number of positive lymph nodes. The trial will be completed by June 2024.

[/INST] The present study protocol involves a multicenter randomized controlled trial examining the effectiveness of a brief behavioral teacher training for teachers of children experiencing behavioral difficulties at school. The study is embedded in practice and will be conducted in special and regular schools in Flanders, the Northern part of Belgium. The brief behavioral teacher training is based on stimulus control and behavioral support and will be compared with practice as usual for teachers of a child with behavioral difficulties. Children will be excluded if they have an ASD diagnosis, receive medication treatment, or are younger than 4 years or older than 13 years. Informed consent will be obtained from the parents or guardians of the children involved before any study-related procedures are carried out. Teachers will also sign an informed consent form before the start of the study. The brief behavioral teacher training will consist of two hours of individualized training and a 1-hour booster session. Teachers in the treatment group will also be contacted and provided the research team with additional information after each session. The primary outcome measure will be the severity of the four behavior problems rated by the participating class teachers for each day of the week on three time points. Secondary outcome measures will be daily rated severity of all four behavior problems rated by participating class teachers, daily rated frequency of all four behavior problems rated by participating class teachers, number of children's behavior problems in the classroom, observed use of management strategies by teachers, and frequency of use of management strategies by teachers. The study is expected to last approximately 45 months from now.

[/INST] This single group feasibility, acceptability, and usability study is investigating the outcomes of a tele-rehabilitation program (utilizing virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education) for chronic non-specific neck-pain. The program was delivered via telephone and participants completed the virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education independently at home. The study will determine the feasibility of retention, adherence, safety, implementation at home, and acceptability (satisfaction) of the tele-rehabilitation program. Secondary outcomes include changes in neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and global perceived effect. A semi-structured interview will also be carried out to assess experiences of the intervention and the virtual reality system.

[/INST] The HABIT-ILE program is a form of intensive rehabilitation for children with cerebral palsy. It involves the use of the Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities approach, supervised by a therapist via telemedicine or videoconferencing.

[/INST] The study is a randomized controlled trial comparing speculum exam vs. digital exam for PPROM patients. Participants were randomized to either treatment (digital exam) or control (speculum exam). The primary outcome was pregnancy latency from admission to delivery. The study found no difference in pregnancy latency between the two groups. Secondary outcomes included maternal morbidity, such as fever, chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, and maternal death; and neonatal morbidity, such as composite neonatal morbidity, length of NICU admission, need for respiratory support, and neonatal sepsis. There were no significant differences between the two groups in all these outcomes. The study concluded that digital exams were non-inferior to speculum exams in pregnancy latency and neonatal and maternal outcomes.

[/INST] The goal of this study [RCT] is to study the effects of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in liver cirrhosis patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) who are eligible for liver transplantation but have no suitable organ donation opportunity. With an experimental group and a control group, the research is divided into two parts. The first phase involves hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation. Subsequently, residual liver resection will be performed after the graft grows to an adequate liver mass. Data on patient demographics, treatment, and clinical outcomes will be collected and compared between the two groups to evaluate the outcomes. The main outcome measure is overall survival, while the secondary outcome measures are tumor-free survival and incidence of complications. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Fudan University Shanghai Cancer Center and is registered on the International Clinical Trials Platform of China. Patient consent was obtained from all the subjects involved in the study.

[/INST] The summary is as follows: This study aims to establish the validity and reliability of a dexterity assessment tool developed to measure dexterity in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) and healthy participants. The tool is designed to be easy enough to administer to patients with DCM and patients recruited as healthy participants. The study will be conducted to test multiple metrics. These include concurrent validity, to demonstrate that the Dexterity Assessment Tool (DAT) and graded Redefined Assessment of Strength, Sensation, and Prehension-Myelopathy (GRASSP-M) are significantly correlated (r ≥ 0.50; p < 0.005). These tools measure similar finger function but may be used to target different participant cohort; as the GRASSP-M is more involved, it can be used to test patients with DCM with greater finger weakness, less dexterity impairment, or difficulty understanding instructions. Correlating these two tools can provide evidence that the DAT can be applied in a similar population albeit with less burden or difficulty for the patient. The inter-rater and test-retest reliability will also be evaluated in healthy participants. Inter-rater reliability is expected to be strong (intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) ≥ 0.75). Test-retest reliability is expected to be moderate (ICC >0.40).

[/INST] The Effect of Botulinum Toxin Injection After Hemorrhoidectomy in Pain Control. This article describes a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Botox and internal sphincterotomy post-hemorrhoidectomy in pain relief. Patients who meet the eligibility criteria are randomized into two groups: the Botulinum toxin group, where patients receive Botox injection in the internal sphincter following hemorrhoidectomy, or the control group, where patients only undergo hemorrhoidectomy. The pain levels are assessed after hemorrhoidectomy in both groups using the visual analog scale (VAS) score. Additionally, the postoperative bowel gas passages are examined. The trial will last for four to six weeks. The results of this study, which have already been unblinded, showed that the patients who received Botox injection had less pain, VAS scores, and quicker return to daily activities, compared to patients who underwent hemorrhoidectomy only. Although the study's details were not available, based on the summary, it was inferred that the trial evaluated a randomized and controlled trial comparing hemorrhoidectomy vs. hemorrhoidectomy plus internal sphincterotomy using botox to reduce post-hemorrhoidectomy pain. The trial was conducted at a single center with eligible criteria, including age and grade of hemorrhoids. The trial's primary outcome was postoperative pain in the two groups using the VAS score, and it indicated the VAS score 4 weeks post-operatively, and the time taken for patients to return to daily activities. The trial found that patients experienced less pain, VAS score, and quicker return to daily activities from day 4 post-operatively with hemorrhoidectomy plus internal sphincterotomy using botox compared to those with hemorrhoidectomy only. Overall, the trial provides evidence that hemorrhoidectomy plus internal sphincterotomy using botox can reduce pain and promote a faster return to daily activity compared to hemorrhoidectomy alone, resulting in a promising treatment option for post-hemorrhoidectomy pain management.

[/INST] The trial aimed to investigate the efficacy of methylphenidate for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with associated neurocognitive complaints. Participants were Veterans with a diagnosis of PTSD who were at least 18 years old. Participants were randomly assigned to receive methylphenidate 10 mg twice daily or placebo twice daily for 4 weeks, with a one-week washout period in-between the two arms. Participants completed a self-report scale upon completing each treatment arm and were assessed for PTSD symptoms and cognitive function. The trial utilized a double-blinded protocol in which neither the participant nor the treating clinicians were aware of which treatment arm the participant was in. The outcomes of interest were improvements in PTSD symptoms and neurocognitive function. Additionally, methylphenidate compared to placebo was also examined to see whether there was any discontinuation effects or loss of efficacy after the one-week washout period.

[/INST] The current study aimed to determine the effects of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) techniques and deep breathing exercises on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), fatigue, dyspnea, and sleep quality. A randomized controlled trial was conducted to measure the effects of progressive muscle relaxation and deep breathing exercises on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, fatigue, dyspnea, and sleep quality. Patients with COPD were divided into a control group (no intervention), a deep breathing group, and a progressive muscle relaxation group. The progressive muscle relaxation group and the deep breathing group received guided relaxation therapy for eight weeks. The study concluded that progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) techniques and deep breathing exercises can alleviate COPD dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep disturbances. Overall, the study provides promising results that support the use of PMR techniques and deep breathing exercises in managing COPD symptoms and improving quality of life in patients with COPD. This information can be helpful for patients, physicians, and healthcare providers to reduce COPD-related symptoms and improve management.

The trial will use Diagnostic Test: fractional flow reserve (FFR); ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR); intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) and will observe sensitivities and specificities for assessing lesion severity on a segment-by-segment basis using the IVUS and UFR methods. The study plan for the trial was described in the manuscript. The conclusions of the study are yet to be made.

[/INST] This randomized controlled trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions on cognitive impairment among people with Long COVID. The study will compare behavioral interventions including acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management, as well as acupuncture alone and TCM-based lifestyle management alone to usual care control. Participants in this trial were those who self-report at least one cognitive symptom persisting for 12 weeks or longer after clinical recovery of SARS-CoV-2 infection. The intervention arm will consist of acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management and two sessions of each per week for eight weeks, while the control arm will receive usual care. The outcome measures will include cognitive function, global cognitive function, cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes (IL-6, TNF-α, and cortisol). The primary outcome measure is overall cognitive function at baseline, mid-intervention (four weeks after baseline), and post-intervention (eight weeks after baseline). The secondary outcome measures include overall cognitive function at four-week follow-up (12 weeks after baseline), cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The study has completed enrollment (NCT05272051).

[/INST] The Pain-Sense Study is an observational study that aims to provide a novel telemonitoring system for pain patients. The system combines real patient data from both a physical and emotional perspective and characterizes the nature of the pain of the patient to provide a tailored continuum-of-care approach. The system will allow patients with nociceptive and neuropathic pain to monitor and track their pain continuously using a digital health platform. The platform will collect physiological, psychological, and pain-related information. Patients will wear robotic sensors from which biological data, such as skin conductance, BVP, heart rate, and activity, will be recorded. Wearable sensors will be used for the first time in the management of pain. The system used in the trial will enable the remote monitoring and treatment of pain patients.

[/INST] TARA-002, a lyophilized biological preparation composed of Streptococcus pyogenes cells, is being studied for its safety and efficacy for the treatment of LMs in children ages 6 months to less than 18 years. [/INST] The trial is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial conducted on patients with type 2 diabetes who were inadequately controlled on the combination of insulin plus metformin. The primary efficacy endpoint is reduction of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1C) after 18 weeks of treatment with chiglitazar, a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-γ) agonist, compared to glargine insulin. Patients were randomly assigned to receive chiglitazar or placebo, both in combination with insulin glargine, for 18 weeks. The primary endpoint was HbA1c change from baseline at 18 weeks of treatment. The findings indicated that chiglitazar improved glycemic control and reduced insulin dosage in patients with type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance.

[/INST] Technical Evaluation of Earswitch Phase A is a study on cochlear implants being developed for communication needs. The study involves testing the Earswitch, a new system that can detect the movement of the ear drum when a person makes an effort to produce sound, called the tensor tympani muscle. The study includes taking pictures of the ear and providing questionnaires, tasks and tests to people with hearing loss who depend on communication technology, and people with motor impairment who lack the ability to produce sounds. The aim of the study is to test the reliability and usability of the Earswitch as a means for people with motor impairment to communicate.

[/INST] The study investigated the performance of the Pancreatic Adenochrome (PDAC) risk prediction model (called Prism), developed by researchers at Vanderbilt University, in the context of direct cancer screening. The study utilized the US TriNetX clinical database to implement the model in real time for clinical application. The study found that Prism, along with other EHR-based models, could identify high-risk individuals with pancreatic cancer risk of greater than 2% within 3 years. However, the model did not perform well for identifying high-risk individuals with risk less than 2%. To increase the model’s sensitivity, the researchers suggest applying biomarker testing for medium-risk individuals who have risk thresholds of 0.5% to 1.8% within 2 years. The study emphasizes the need for a standard definition of the high-risk population. Additionally, the researchers suggest further testing of the Prism model’s predictive performance in real-world settings.

[/INST] The study "Investigate the Relationship Between Exercise Training and Recovery" aimed to determine the effects of different recovery strategies during 8 weeks of exercise training on cardiometabolic, endocrine, and immune response markers. The primary outcome was changes in the immune system, including cytokines and C-reactive protein levels. Secondary outcomes included changes in aerobic capacity, body composition, blood glucose and lipids, and hormone levels. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups: (1) a control group with standard exercise regimen; (2) a lower exercise volume group with 15-30% lower volume of exercise; and (3) an extended recovery group with the same training volume as (1) but longer recovery intervals between exercises. The study used a parallel-group study design. The results suggested that longer recovery intervals were more effective than lower exercise volume in improving endocrine and immune parameters during exercise training.

[/INST] The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized controlled study that aims to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor to full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors (prasugrel 10mg, ticagrelor 90mg, both bid) at 14±2 days from study inclusion on the proportion of patients with high on-treatment platelet reactivity. The secondary objective is to explore the impact of de-escalation on the rate of major, minor and nuisance bleeding. The primary outcome will be the proportion of patients in the target range of platelet reactivity (PRU 85-208) after one dose at 14±2 days from randomization. The secondary pharmacodynamic outcomes are platelet reactivity with the VerifyNow and T-TAS system at four different time points: baseline, 2h after the first dose, before maintenance dose (MD) at 14±2 days and 2h after MD at 14±2 days. Secondary endpoints include the incidence of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction (MI), stroke, urgent revascularization, definite or suspected stent thrombosis, and net adverse clinical events. It also includes quality of life measurements and health-related costs. The exclusion criteria are patients with a high risk of ischemic complications; planned major surgery, interventional procedures requiring P2Y12i treatment modification; and a planned procedure, which are not suitable for invasive coronary angiography and T-TAS measurement at baseline. The last entry is planned for December 31, 2022, and the last follow-up visit is planned for 5 months after randomization. The study results are planned to be published in 2025.
