[/INST] The study aims to assess the efficacy of operant conditioning of sensory brain responses to reduce phantom limb pain among amputees. The study will involve three experimental groups, including an active control group, with three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Outcomes such as change in SF-McGill Pain scores, change in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency response, and change in impact of pain on quality of life as measured by WHYMPI index will be measured at the baseline, end of training and follow-up time points. The sample size for the study has been determined using a previous study's findings with a power of 80% and a significance level set at 5%. The primary outcome in this study, reduction in pain, will be measured using SF-McGill Pain Scores. This study does not report any additional statistical analysis measures.

[/INST] Intramolecular carbon-carbon multibonds are known to have a major contribution to the molecular structure and electronic structure.1,2 However, their formation in complex hydrocarbon systems is challenging due to the high reactivity and low nucleophilicity of multibonded species. Three well-known reactions for the formation of carbon-carbon multiple bonds are the Diels-Alder 2+4 and hetero-Diels-Alder 4+4 cycloaddition, alkyne σ-vinylogy (σ-V), and α-diamination.1 Among these three reactions, only the σ-V mechanism for the formation of carbon-carbon 2n-membered ring system was demonstrated as a reversible and intramolecular reaction.3 The σ-V of conjugated α,ω‐dienes is based on the reactivity of carbon σ-electrons with vinylogous π-electrons. This interesting reactivity of carbon atoms in dienes has been extensively investigated to control the reaction stereoselectivity and ring size-selectivity using the transition-metal catalyzed and enzyme-catalyzed four-component coupling reactions and cyclization reactions in order to construct valuable and various natural product derivatives.4

[/INST] This study, titled "Imaging on Core Muscles Function in Patients with Visceral Adiposity: A Randomized Control Trial," aimed to assess the impact of a combination of different ultrasound imaging techniques and cores exercises on core muscle strength, in individuals with excess visceral fat. Participants were randomized into three groups: Group 1 received a combination of cavitation and RUSI 2 times per week for 10 weeks, Group 2 received RUSI 2 times per week for 10 weeks and Group 3 received Cavitation-only 2 times per week for 10 weeks. Ultrasound imaging was used to determine the thickness of the transverse abdominal muscle at rest and during contraction, as well as the thickness of visceral fat. The study found that the combination of cavitation and RUSI therapy significantly decreased visceral fat thickness and increased the percentage of TA muscle thickness compared to baseline measurements, but no significant changes were observed in the Cavitation-only or RUSI therapy groups.

[/INST] This study is a pilot prospective study to investigate the impact of the area of atrial fibrosis on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with ischemic stroke of uncertain origin. Patients with ischemic stroke occurring within 7 days qualified for inclusion in this study, as they were required to undergo cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast agent. The primary outcome of the study was to determine the prevalence of AF lasting at least one minute on the implantable loop recorder at the 3-year follow-up. Patients with a history of AF, long-term anticoagulant therapy, renal impairment, hypersensitivity to contrast agents, uncontrolled asthma, or any condition that prevented them from undergoing MRI were excluded from the study. In addition to determining the prevalence of new-onset AF during the 3-year follow-up period, the study aimed to identify the characteristics and distribution of fibrosis and late gadolinium enhancement on cardiac MRI in the enrolled patients. However, the study only included a small number of post-hoc observations. The study was designed to obtain data over a 12-month period. Concerning AF, it was concluded that there was an impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on new AF occurrence in patients with cryptogenic stroke of uncertain origin. Despite their limitations, pilot studies such as these can provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of further research.

[/INST] Phase II, open-label, randomized trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of AKT inhibitor capivasertib with hormonal therapy and immunotherapy in postmenopausal patients with extended ER positive MBC. In Arm 3, capivasertib is combined with hormonal therapy and immunotherapy durvalumab, while in Arm 4, capivasertib is combined with hormonal therapy. Patients in Arm 1 serve as the control group receiving hormonal therapy. The primary endpoint of the study is objective response rate (ORR) of the whole other three arms in comparison to the goserelin/ fulvestrant arm (Arm 1). The secondary endpoints are progression-free survival (PFS) and ORR in different treatment arms. Exploratory endpoints include biomarkers such as tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, PDL1, and hormone receptor status.

[/INST] This is a Phase II, Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Non-Blinded, Fallback Design Clinical Study assessing the transitional care nurse navigator program for patients with high risk of hospital readmission. For interventions in Arm A, the program will be offered to patients randomly selected. For Arm B, the program will not be offered. The primary endpoints include 30-day unplanned hospital readmission rate in the overall study population and in patients that are risk stratified as medium-high risk. Secondary endpoint includes 90-day hospital readmission rate and deaths, 90-day mortality rate, 90-day and 30-day emergency department visits and mortality rate. Results may demonstrate the high need for additional interventions for transitional care of high-risk patients. The study is currently being conducted at the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center.

[/INST] This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR) compared to azelastine nasal spray. AR is a common condition with a global prevalence of approximately 500 million people, which can have a significant impact on quality of life. Nasal congestion is a bothersome symptom in AR that can result in increased severity and duration of AR symptoms, which can require medical intervention such as antihistamines or corticosteroids. Acupuncture is a potential treatment option for AR, but evidence supporting its use is limited. This clinical trial will compare the effects of acupuncture to azelastine nasal spray, which is a standard treatment for AR. The acupuncture protocol will consist of eight treatments over a six-week period, and the primary outcome measure will be the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score for nasal congestion. The findings of this clinical trial may provide evidence for the effectiveness of acupuncture for AR and help to define the role of acupuncture in the treatment of this condition.

The study will measure change in the focal child's auditory comprehension skills and expressive language skills using the Preschool Language Screener (PLS-5), as well as social skills, behavior, and social inclusion using the Teacher-Child Rating Scale (TCRS), Peer Incoming Talk, and Peer Outgoing Talk. [/INST] The study "Comparison of Core Stabilization and Dynamic Stretching Exercises in Primary Dysmenorrhea" is investigating which exercises are more effective for primary dysmenorrhea. The interventions will be implemented over 8 weeks time and the study will assess the change in the Working ability, Location, Intensity, Days of pain (WaLIDD) score, side bridge test results, the McGill Quality of life scale, and the Primary dysmenorrhea symptom (PFSD) scale to evaluate the effect of the study. [/INST] This paper describes a study that aims to investigate cerebral autoregulation during controlled blood pressure variations in patients undergoing surgery. The main objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during the mean arterial pressure (MAP) change. The study will enroll 100 patients over the age of 18 years who are scheduled for surgery and are in general anesthesia. All of them have to be in a hemodynamic challenge for their blood pressure, where it varies between 90% and 70% of baseline value without every going under 60 mmHg for low risk patients and 80 mmHg for high risk patients. The anesthesia will be induced with a target concentration for Orchestra Base Primea intravenous anesthesia. Duration: 1 day.

[/INST] The PediQUEST Response to Pain Of Children With Neurologic Disability Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial is a phase II pilot study examining the feasibility and acceptability of an intervention to mitigate recurrent pain. The study is conducted at Boston Children's Hospital and includes children (≥1 year old) diagnosed with a severe neurologic impairment with recurrent pain and their parent/caregiver. The intervention arm includes the PQ-ResPOND intervention, which incorporates parent-child dyads' weekly PQ-ResPOND surveys to collect NCCPC-R and PediQUEST-Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale adapted for SNI symptom data as well as PQ-ResPOND Feedback Reports for parents/caregivers and PPC team, and PPC team activation through weekly PPC Clinician Check-Ins and quarterly PPC team Consults. The control arm includes usual care and weekly PediQUEST Surveys. Quantitative and qualitative outcomes are assessed, including feasibility, acceptability, recruitment rate, adherence, and intervention effect sizes through validated psychometric scales. All hypotheses and objectives are clearly outlined and the study design is described in detail. The study protocol is approved by the hospital ethics committee and the study was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov. The feasibility and acceptability of implementing the intervention will be examined by conducting interviews with parents/caregivers, PPC clinicians, and PPC psychosocial clinicians. Overall, the study is well-designed and the intervention is promising for children with severe neurologic impairment presenting with recurrent pain. However, a limitation of the study is the lack of blinding of outcome assessors, and the number of patients to be enrolled may be insufficient to draw conclusions regarding effectiveness. To improve the study, a control group comparing treatment as usual and study participants may be beneficial.

[/INST] The aim of this clinical trial is to investigate the effects of intranasal oxytocin on social functioning in youth with autism spectrum disorders (ASD). In this randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study, eligible participants, who are between the ages of 12 and 20, will participate in two sessions administered within a 1-month interval. Each session consists of a familiarization session, an assessment session, and 4-week treatment. In the 4-week treatment period, the participants from the oxytocin arm will receive 24IU of intranasal Oxytocin four times per week, while those in the placebo arm will be administered an identical placebo treatment using a pump-actuated nasal spray. All participants will be blinded to treatment allocations. The primary objectives are to examine treatment effects on social functioning, using the SRS-2 and the RBS-R. The secondary objectives are to assess treatment effects on inflexible behavior, social cognition, repetitive cognition, and physiological (HRV) measures. The inclusion criteria of participants are having an ASD diagnosis, and ages at least of 12 years and no more than 20 years old. The exclusion criteria are having a current nasal disease, surgery, and oxytocin nasal spray dependence. Other exclusion criteria are a history of a clinically significant disease, systemic illness, and allergies or intolerance to the oxytocin. The main findings of this trial are that oxytocin, as an adjunctive treatment, helps to improve social functioning and repetitive behavior in youths with ASD.

[/INST] Empowered Relief Delivered by Nurses is a randomized controlled study intended to reduce pain by improving self-management for participants with persistent pain. A total of 170 participants will be recruited, including adults aged 18 and above years with self- reported or clinically diagnosed persistent pain. Participants will be randomized 1:1 to one of two unblinded study groups: empowered relief (ER) and wait-list control. Participants assigned to the ER group will complete a web-based ER class delivered by an ER-trained nurse. A crossover intervention class will be offered to those patient participants randomized to the WLC once the ER group has completed their class and follow up assessments, estimated at two months post intervention. The primary outcome measure is change in pain catastrophizing and secondary outcomes include change in pain intensity and barriers to care. The ER group will complete surveys to compare with the experimental treatment group. After serving as controls, they will be invited to attend the web-based class. This study will assess the feasibility (participant recruitment, data collection rates, delivery of the intervention, and adherence) and acceptability (of both the intervention and the trial design) of ER for chronic pain. This trial is significant because if effective, it offers a valuable new tool to address disparities in pain care.

[/INST] The protocol paper presents a cross-sectional survey that seeks to gather information on the mental effort associated with pain intensity rating. The survey will be conducted individually with patients with chronic pain and nurses who are trained to assess and evaluate pain. The objective of the study is to determine how mental effort is related to the choice of pain intensity rating scale, pain intensity rating scale scale, recall period scale, and pain location. The survey will also explore how mental effort will impact on the perceived confidence in pain-intensity rating patterns, both in patients and nurses. Furthermore, the survey will identify the pain rating patterns that lead to accurate pain rating. The study's findings will enhance the understanding of how pain assessment and communication may be improved to increase the confidence of patients in the accuracy of pain intensity rating scale and the ease with which they can rate pain intensity.

Overall, the clinical trial results found that using MSCs to treat the complications of allo-HSCT was an effective treatment option.

[/INST] This study was a randomized controlled trial of an Integrated Digital Intervention for Alcohol Use Disorder that included a mobile health app and medication naltrexone versus a control condition with naltrexone and medical management of alcohol use disorder. The interventions included an integrated digital intervention with a mobile health app and medication naltrexone versus a control condition with medication naltrexone and medical management of alcohol use disorder. The study compared the reduction in 30-day alcohol use, the rate of drinking days per week, alcohol use outcome expectancies, and motivation for change. It found that the intervention group had significant improvements in days of alcohol use, heavy drinking days, and days out of role compared to the control group. Overall, the study demonstrated the effectiveness of the integrated digital intervention in reducing alcohol use in participants with moderate-to-severe alcohol use disorder over 12 months compared to a control medication condition.

[/INST] The trial is a three-arm, parallel-design, randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effects of intravenous and inhalational anesthesia on incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery. It will examine the role of anesthesia on postoperative neurocognitive decline, postoperative functional decline, and PROs such as patient satisfaction, sleep, emotion, physical and mental health, and social health. Participation criteria are: being 75 years of age or older, undergoing non-cardiac surgery for at least 120 min, and able to undergo general anesthesia. Participants will be randomized using opaque, sealed, sequentially numbered envelopes to inhalational anesthesia (sevoflurane) or intravenous anesthesia (propofol). The outcomes include postoperative delirium, cognitive dysfunction, delirium duration, and severity, levels of preoperative baseline blood p-tau181 to postoperative day 1, 3 months and 12 months after surgery, incidence of postoperative functional decline using the ADL and FRAIL, and PROMs including PROMIS-29+2 Profile v2.1 (PROPr) patient-reported measures of anxiety, depression, fatigue, pain interference, physical function, sleep disturbance, participation in social activities, pain, and cognition.

[/INST] Congenital heart disease (CHD) is a common congenital defect that affects approximately 8–12 per 1000 live births. Adequate nutritional intake is important for children with CHD, especially those with cyanotic forms, in order to avoid nutritional deficiencies and support proper growth and development. Adequate nutritional intake is essential, as malnutrition can lead to several complications, including an increase in morbidity and mortality, delayed growth and development, as well as poor physical and mental health in adulthood. Congenital heart disease can be detected through a history of birth and the physical examination of the child. However, a normal birth history does not rule out congenital heart disease . Congenital heart disease occurs with the cyanotic form leading to deficiencies in micronutrients and growth impairment, and it is critical to assess nutritional status in children with CHD. Clinicians can screen for nutritional problems using several methods, including anthropomorphic metrics, such as changes in body mass index (BMI), weight-for-height, weight-for-age, and growth velocity. Additional indicators include a weight at the lower limit for age, recent reduction in food intake, and a less-than-per-centile dietary intake . It is important to monitor these children for any clinical complications such as delayed growth, poor feeding, muscle wasting, chronic diarrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. Nutrition plays an important role in supporting optimal growth and development in children with congenital heart disease. Nutritionists are essential members of the CHD care team and must be familiar with the unique needs of these patients. Pediatricians and cardiologists should involve nutritionists in routine screening and ongoing monitoring of infants to help ensure proper nutritional status . Parents are also critical stakeholders in their child's care and can help support adequate nutrition by following the healthcare team's recommendations.

[/INST] Clinical trial titled “Non-invasive Methods for the Diagnosis of Postoperative Complications in Liver Transplant Recipients” is a single-center prospective study aiming to evaluate the efficacy of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of early allograft dysfunction (EAD) in liver transplant patients. The study included liver transplant recipients who were eligible for transplantation according to national and international guidelines. The Olthoff criteria were used to determine the diagnosis of EAD based on laboratory test results, including bilirubin, international normalized ratio (INR) and alanine and aspartate transaminases (ALT/AST). The primary outcome measure was the incidence of EAD detected using the Olthoff criteria during the first 14 days after liver transplantation. The results of this study may contribute to the early identification of patients at high risk for EAD, resulting in appropriate clinical interventions to prevent EAD.

It involves turning these patients sideways, improving aeration of the dorsal region of the lungs, reducing lung collapse, and increasing oxygenation. [/INST] The purpose of this study was to assess the effects of progressive relaxation training on migraine and Tension Type Headache (TTH), comparing the effects of relaxation training on migraine and TTH. Participants in the study were women aged 20 to 45 with a diagnosis of migraine or TTH based on the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-I1), and who expressed an interest in participating in the study. Exclusion criteria for the study included having a pathology involving the cervical region, having received any form of physical therapy targeting the cervical region within the past 3 months, being pregnant or in the menopausal phase, not participating in at least 15% of the training sessions, having a mental disorder, having a chronic neurological or rheumatic disorder, suffering from sinusitis, and being on continuous prophylactic medication for migraine. The intervention consisted of one-hour sessions of progressive relaxation training performed over six weeks, two times per week, with a total of twelve sessions. The training included deep diaphragmatic breathing, progressive muscle contraction and relaxation, and an overall relaxation protocol. Participants were assessed twice, at baseline and after the six-week intervention, using the Occupational Self-Assessment (OSA) scale, the World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule 2 (WHO-DAS 2), and the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS). The results of the study showed that progressive relaxation training can improve activity participation, pain interference, and pain intensity in women with chronic tension-type headaches, as well as reduce activity interference in migraine symptoms. No statistically significant differences were found in pain intensity, frequency, and duration between migraine and TTH. The authors concluded that progressive relaxation training can have beneficial effects on both migraine and TTH and may be a low-cost alternative to non-pharmacological approaches to improving the condition of women with these headache disorders.

[/INST] The objective of this study is to explore the microRNA (miRNA) response to neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS) by examining the miRNAs of infants diagnosed with NOWS. The miRNAs of infants exposed to opioids in-utero will be compared with the miRNAs of infants who do not exhibit any drug exposure or withdrawal symptoms at birth. This will be done using a case-control study where the case subjects are those who have diagnosed with NOWS. The control subjects are infants who do not exhibit any drug exposure or withdrawal symptoms at birth. The miRNA responses will be analyzed through biomarkers that have already been identified, such as miRNA-192, miR-146a, and miR-let 7a. These miRNAs are all up-regulated in NOWS cases, which suggests that they may be biomarkers of neonatal withdrawal from opioids. By examining the miRNAs of infants that are exposed to opioids in-utero, there is a greater understanding of their response to the opioid. This can aid in the development of better clinical interventions for NOWS.

[/INST] The aim of the study is to determine the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedic and traumatology patients. The study included 52 patients in two groups: intervention and control group through simple random sampling. The intervention group received patient education from nursing staff on the day before the operation and the morning of the operation, and the control group received preoperative preparatory information on the morning of the operation. Pain and fear of pain levels were then measured and compared between the two groups. The study found that the intervention group had lower pain and pain fear levels compared to the control group throughout the study period, with the results remaining statistically significant. The researchers concluded that pain education reduced the pain and pain fear scores, and that such education should be included in pre-hospital preparation. The study also found that increasing the intervention group's educational information before the surgery, and in the hospital wards, resulted in significantly lower pain level and intensity compared to the control group. Overall, the study demonstrates the importance of patient education to effectively manage pain and fear in orthopedics and traumatology patients.

[/INST] The Patch BRIDGE Trial is a randomized controlled trial of buprenorphine to treat opioid withdrawal during pregnancy. The study includes pregnant patients who meet criteria for opioid use disorder and have had illicit opioid use within the last 24 hours. The study will randomize participants to receive either a buprenorphine patch or a sham patch to assess induction withdrawal severity, induction success, and treatment adherence. The study includes a follow up period until birth. The study excludes patients already receiving treatment for opioid use disorder, patients in opioid withdrawal, or patients requiring immediate hospitalization.
[/INST] Title: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome: Using Transcutaneous Oximetry to Measure Limb Blood Flow

[/INST] This study is a feasibility study aimed at assessing the feasibility of implementing a mobile healthcare app called SmartCP in the management of chronic pancreatitis. Chronic pancreatitis is a complex disease that requires multidisciplinary care. This study will assess whether using the SmartCP app along with the existing care can improve current care. It also aims to look at the feasibility of recruitment, retention, acceptability, and usability of the SmartCP app. The app will be used by patients over a period of 16 weeks, and a mobile healthcare app will be used to record and manage patient symptoms. The study will evaluate the number of participants recruited and retained, the use and acceptability of the app, and the number of changes in patient hospitalizations, health status, and quality of life.

[/INST] In this study, researchers conducted a cross-sectional investigation of patients who survived COVID-19 that had anal fissures. From September to November 2020, patients experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 from Mansoura University's tertiary hospital were included in the study. Participants who were 20-70 years old, had received COVID-19 treatment, and had survived were included in the study after being discharged. Patients were interviewed and had their medical records examined for demographic information, such as age, gender, co-morbidities, and any anal pain or fissures during or after their treatment. To confirm the diagnosis, telephone interviews were performed with anal fissure patients to track their symptoms and follow-ups. The investigators found a link between Gastrointestinal (GI) issues such as constipation or diarrhea and an increase in the incidence of anal fissure. To summarize, the study demonstrated that anal fissures can occur among COVID-19 survivors, and possible risk factors (GI symptoms) and outcomes (self-resolution, medications, or surgery) were identified.

[/INST] This study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of application of L-PRF (Leukocyte and platelet-rich fibrin) membrane after palatal connective tissue graft harvesting versus no application. The use of L-PRF membrane to cover the palate after tissue graft harvesting is expected to promote healing and reduce graft resorption. Ultrasonography, specifically Doppler ultrasound, is used to assess the thickness and blood-flow velocity of the palatal tissues.

[/INST] ARRC III is a pilot registry of the ARRC, conducted at the Royal Adelaide Hospital, designed to assess the benefits of the ARRC intervention for post-operative subjects. The ARRC incorporates enhanced care in recovery and standardized admission and discharge criteria, aiming to improve outcomes and reduce costs. ARRC is associated with a reduction in post-operative complications, mortality, and costs and is estimated to result in 68 additional days at home per patient and cost $680 per patient in the program. The objective of this registry is to provide a platform for ongoing collection of high-quality data on the ARRC intervention relevant to consumers and hospitals to support maintenance of benefits, future benchmarking, identification of new subgroups that benefit, and hypothesis generation and testing. The database will also be refined to collect new variables of interest to the study and key performance indicators. The registry pilot will inform the ongoing operation of the registry.

[/INST] This is a phase 3b, open-label, randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness and implementation of CAB-LA and oral TDF-FTC/FTC (daily or event-driven) for HIV prevention in mobile men. The study will compare the effectiveness of CAB-LA and oral TDF-FTC/FTC for HIV prevention over 18 months by measuring the effectiveness and implementation of choosing either regimen, remaining in care and HIV-free over 18 months. The study will use a mixed method, multi-setting, multi-country approach. Participants aged 18 years and above will be randomized into two groups who will receive CAB-LA or TDF-FTC/FTC for 9 months, and provided the opportunity to choose either regimen for an additional 9 months. The primary effectiveness and implementation outcomes will be assessed by persistence in PrEP and PrEP uptake or choice at specific study visits. The study aims to assess the effectiveness and implementation of two PrEP options, which will help to facilitate future PrEP options in populations who are mobile for work.

[/INST] The Preliminary Assessment of the Psycho-emotional State of Patients with TMD was a comparative trial that included two groups. All participants completed a questionnaire that had 30 questions on depression, anxiety, and stress. The results were divided into four groups, and the mean values and standard deviations are presented for each group. The results of the study showed that individuals with TMD have an unfavorable psycho-emotional state compared to those without TMD.

[/INST] This is a clinical study examining the safety and efficacy of using non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HSCT) in patients with sickle cell disease before transplantation along with briquilimab and abatacept post-transplantation. The study aims to determine the percentage of patients without acute Grade 3 or higher GVHD or moderate to severe chronic GVHD one year post transplantation and the incidence of autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications post transplantation. The non-myeloablative HSCT and briquilimab and abatacept post-transplantation is expected to reduce graft-vs-host disease (GVHD), decreasing the occurrence of GVHD and reducing transplant-related mortality. This will result in better outcomes for patients with sickle cell disease, especially, those with organ damage.

[/INST] The present study investigates two different methods for sperm preparation, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization. Only the group of women who consented to randomization will be included. Women will be randomly assigned to either the microfluidic or the density gradient centrifugation group. The primary outcome measure of the study is the euploid rate of the embryo. The secondary outcomes include the live birth rate of the first embryo transfer, positive urine pregnancy test rate per the first embryo transfer, clinical pregnancy rate of the first embryo transfer, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, ectopic pregnancy rate, fertilization rate, and embryo vitrification rate.

[/INST] The study titled "Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) single-nucleotide gene polymorphism and nerve growth factor as a risk factor that increases the severity of allergic rhinitis" was a clinical trial conducted in Iran on 112 patients of chronic allergic rhinitis (AR). The study aimed to examine the association between BDNF single-nucleotide gene polymorphism and serum levels of NGF and CRP with the severity of allergic rhinitis. Patients were assessed for the severity of their AR based on a number of parameters, including nasal congestion/obstruction, runny nose, itching, sneezing, postnasal drip, and pruritus. The study involved a number of tests, including clinical examination and laboratory tests. These tests included measuring CRP and IL-1 levels, as well as examining eosinophils, total and differential leukocyte count, IgG, IgG4, IgA, and IgE levels. 5 ml of blood with ethylene diamine tetra acetic (EDT) was drawn, and DNA was extracted. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) real-time was performed to determine the BDNF gene SNP and BDNF mRNA level, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was used to measure BDNF, NGF, and IgE serum levels .

[/INST] SUMMARY [clinical trial] The objective of this study is to assess the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based intervention on mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness in older adults. Pre- and post-intervention cognitive and psychological assessments will be conducted. A change in participants' mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness scores is expected to be observed.

[/INST] The study " Mycoplasma Genitalium Infection and Associated Antimicrobial Resistance Among HIV-infected Male in Hong Kong" aims to recruit 750 HIV-infected male attending HIV specialist clinic in Hong Kong. [/INST] The study is a randomized, Phase 2 clinical trial conducted at a single center. The primary objective of the study is to explore the efficacy of the combination of Dalpiciclib and endocrine therapy in patients with advanced or refractory breast cancer that has progressed after CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment failure. The study will evaluate several measures of efficacy and safety, including progression-free survival (PFS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS). The study will enroll approximately 46 patients who have progressed on their prior CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment and have received < 3 lines of endocrine therapy. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two treatment arms: Arm A will receive Dalpiciclib combined with physician-selected endocrine therapy (Letrozole, Anastrozole, Exemestane, Fulvestrant, or Tamoxifen), while Arm B will receive physician-selected chemotherapy. Patients will receive treatment until they experience progression, have an unacceptable toxicity, or voluntarily withdraw from the study.

[/INST] This study will test a prosocial incentive (earning meals donated to Feeding America) and a personal incentive (earning gift cards) for increasing daily step count in older adults. [/INST] The intervention group comprising newborns admitted to the 4 neonatal subunits where neoGuard (a wearable vital signs monitor) was installed and the comparison group comprising those 4 subunits where neoGuard was not installed will serve as study arms with the standard of care (manual monitoring or conventional care). Nurse’s response time to patients in distress, percentage of actionable alarms, incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality and frequency of key interventions will be determined. The study will assess whether neoGuard (the wearable device) improves nurse’s response time and the percentage of actionable alarms, and whether it reduces incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality and frequency of key interventions. A month-to-month difference in newborn complication rates and treatment outcomes between the intervention and comparison group will provide evidence that this novel device improves neonatal care, particularly in LMICs in East Africa.

[/INST] The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a pre-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy (RT) followed by surgical treatment compared to the same treatment performed post-operatively in elderly or fragile patients with extremity or trunk soft tissue sarcomas (STS).

[/INST] This study, performed in the Army Hospital of Nepal, is a retrospective study that aims to profile head and neck cancers (HNC) among patients referred to the ENT and Head Neck Surgery Department over the past year. The main source of data was from patient medical records, and data collected included demographic details, diagnosis, subsite-specific HNCs, treatment modalities, and histopathology. The data was analyzed using SPSS 22, and Pearson's chi-square test was applied. The age-wise distribution of HNCs showed that the majority of HNC cases were among patients between the ages of 40–59. The distribution of HNCs according to subsite showed that the majority of HNCs were diagnosed from the oral cavity, followed by the Oropharynx and then the Larynx. Histopathology of HNCs was seen predominantly in squamous cell carcinoma. Tumor, Nodes, Metastasis (TNM) staging of HNC was conducted, which showed that the majority of patients were diagnosed in Stage IV. The treatment provided to HNC patients included a combination of surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy.

[/INST] This trial's primary objective is to examine the impact of a health communication message designed to educate parents about their child's bedtime symptoms on increasing the number of children identified and treated for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The health communication message was tested against usual care alone on the proportion of children who were referred to sleep medicine specialist and referred to polysomnogram (PSG) within the following month for their symptoms of snoring, snorting, breathing cessations. Intervention: Parents were randomly assigned to receive health communication messages targeting parents with children who had completed OSA screenings. It comprised a brief description of symptoms and consequences of OSA in children, as well as instructions to discuss their concern with the provider during the visit. Primary/Secondary Objectives: To assess whether receiving the health communication message before the doctor's visit will increase the number of children who received sleep-disordered breathing referrals or evaluations, compared to receiving no message. A 2-tiered definition is used: Tier 1 children who were referred and completed one referral type (ENT or sleep specialist). Tier 2 children who either 1) were referred and received at least one follow-up type of referral evaluation, e.g., completing an empirical trial of CPAP before progressing to PSG, or 2) referred and no direct referrals were made, but child was diagnosed and treated for sleep-disordered breathing. Study Design: Randomized, parallel group. The participants were parents whose children required OSA screening, were assigned to either the health communication message intervention or to no message control groups. The primary outcome was the proportion of children who had completed OSA-screening tools and were referred to a specialist or had one form of documented, evidence-based follow-up evaluation. The secondary outcome was the proportion of children who successfully completed 1) their OSA referral, and 2) Tier 2-level of OSA evaluation. All study participants were randomized into two groups. The group that included parents who received the health communication message before the doctor's visit was termed as intervention, while the parents who were scheduled to see the doctor for a routine visit, without any message, was termed as the control group. Eligibility Criteria: Parents whose children aged 2-13 years were required to complete OSA-screening tools; if there was a positive screen, parents will be randomized to either health communication message or usual care. Data Source: Data on demographics, medical history, and the outcomes were obtained from the medical records of the study participants. Data analysis was performed using statistical software.

[/INST] A real-world clinical trial of upadacitinib, a prescription-only drug for RA patients that has the effects of inhibiting cytokines and relieving joint pain in RA patients. The proposed trial aim is to evaluate its speed and endurance compared to other traditional anti-tumor necrosis factor-alpha antibodies. The trial includes participants with recurrent CD and will investigate whether continuous administration of upadacitinib can maintain remission and improve intestinal diseases. During the study, it will be observed how long it takes to start remission and whether symptoms relapse, recur, or worsen. In addition, it will be measured using PRO2 and HBI-CR, which evaluate the degree of improvement.

[/INST] The provided document is a clinical trial protocol for testing the online version of the QAPS tool which assesses pre-writing skills in children from the ages of 3 to 7 years. The study aims to recruit 15 children at each age group from 3-7 years old with sample sizes of 15 for each age group. The study will involve administration of three tests: online version of the QAPS, B-VMI, and a hand function test. The tests will be used to collect data on the fine motor and pre-writing skills of children, their handwriting and scissor skills, and their caregiver's responses to pre-defined survey questionnaires. The study will be conducted in English at the University of Southern California in the US.

[/INST] The Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI) is proposed for individuals with serious psychiatric disorders, discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities. The intervention is delivered by Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) and Peer Support Workers (PSWs). The approach focuses on connecting discharged individuals in contact with the services of their choice over 9 months, developing a community support network within this time period, and helping the individuals to overcome a critical period of inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities. The intervention will be carried out according to a CTI model, based on a detailed manual, and with ongoing CMHW and PSW training.

[/INST] Vascular trauma and follow-up examinations registry aimed to prospectively included consecutive patients aged 18 years or older with vascular trauma due to closed or open trauma in Centre Hospitalier Valencia between 2012-2018. Primary outcomes were patency of graft/vessel measured by ultrasound or computed tomography/magnetic resonance imaging.
[/INST] Title: Effects of blood flow restriction rehabilitation after ORIF of distal radius fractures: A pilot study on promoting soft tissue recovery and strength training outcomes.

[/INST] Workplace Intervention to Reduce Sitting Time: a Randomized Clinical Trial is a study that evaluates the intervention Stand up for your Health®. This intervention is implemented through a behavioral computer prompt that aims to reduce prolonged sitting during working hours with low levels of physical activity. The intervention is compared to a control group that receives information through a leaflet. The study also evaluates the effect of the intervention and measures such as sedentary behaviour, cardiometabolic markers, and musculoskeletal symptoms. This study will be conducted on office workers over 18 years of age and will involve four assessments at baseline, three months, and six months.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial testing the effects of blood flow restriction and creatine supplementation in women. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two intervention groups: no intervention or creatine and blood flow restriction exercise. The duration of the study is estimated at 10 weeks, with 27 visits in total. The primary outcome is to test the effects of creatine and blood flow restriction exercise on strength, body composition percentage, neuromuscular function, muscle endothelium function, and mood states.

[/INST] The aim of this study is to investigate whether altered protein levels in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of anorexia nervosa (AN) patients can be used to identify new treatment targets for AN. The study will measure the protein levels of Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15), Neurofilament light chain (Nfl), and Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) in the blood and CSF of both AN patients and healthy controls. In addition, the study will be used to collect samples and evaluate the outcome of existing drugs, which could be a target for drug repurposing. This will provide the necessary information and help in developing targeted therapeutic options and personalized treatments. Ultimately, this study aims to find out if the identified proteins can help to understand the biological mechanisms of AN and enable the development of new targeted therapies. Overall, this study has the potential to lead to more effective and personalized treatment of AN in the future.

PROSPECT is extendable to non-specialist centres to achieve similar reporting standards, mirroring current standards in other areas such as surgery.

[/INST] The study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial involving patients with cerebral hemorrhage in the stage of 6-24 hours after onset. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of different doses of edaravone dexborneol injection combined with conventional medical treatment in the treatment of cerebral hemorrhage. The study consists of two stages, A and B.

[/INST] This study, titled " Manzhi Guben granules improve exercise tolerance and safety in convalescent patients with COVID-19 " aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules for improving exercise tolerance and promoting body recovery in convalescent patients with COVID-19. Participants included in the study were middle-aged and elderly outpatients aged 50-80 with COVID-19 in the convalescence phase. The main clinical manifestations of the convalescent patients were fatigue, shortness of breath, cough (satisfying two main symptoms), and the results of 6-minute walking test were less than 80% of the predicted value (about 450-500 m). The diagnostic criteria for convalescence-phase COVID-19 patients and other inclusion criteria were also specified. The study was a multicentre, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, clinical study. The intervention group received Manzi Guben granules while the control group received placebo. The study outcome measures were 6-minute walking test, arterial blood oxygen saturation, lactate clearance, pulmonary ventilation function, and exercise tolerance test. The study period was 28 days, with the intervention provided for 14 and 28 days, respectively. It was expected that the study would find that Manzi Guben granules can significantly improve the 6-minute walking test index, increase lactate clearance, increase the percentage of time of more than 80% of the predicted value in 6PWT, and improve exercise tolerance compared to patients who did not receive drugs. The study aims to provide clinical evidence to support the application of Manzi Guben granules in convalescent patients with COVID-19.

[/INST] The present study is a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study designed to assess the relationship between decision-making and executive skills, as well as their neural underpinnings, in 150 healthy individuals aged 18-60 years. Healthy participants will undergo a behavioral assessment with the aim to measure their performance in decision-making and executive tasks, such as loss aversion, Stroop Task, and Stop-Signal-Task. Neuroimaging data will be acquired to determine performance-related brain activity, brain structure, and brain structural connectivity. The aim of the study is to provide novel insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, as well as their alterations related to ageing, which can be used as a baseline for investigating these cognitive deficits in various diseases.

[/INST] Neutrocheck Usability Study aims to explore the usability of Neutrocheck, focusing on participant perceptions and user experiences, to assess product safety and user satisfaction using paper instruction manuals and an app. Task completion rates and user-satisfaction will be compared between the two study groups, along with responses to a questionnaire containing multiple choice questions about user experiences and perceptions.

[/INST] This study is from a clinical trial called Promoting BEST (Better, Faster, Longer, Stronger Walking) for people with Parkinson's and their objective is to find ways to help patients walk better. They found that when people with Parkinson's use a smartphone and walk, a "Heel2Toe" sensor can provide real-time information that encourages them to take a step forward. The clinical trial is using sensors that provide auditory feedback when a person walks with the correct step and practice the step frequently to improve. The study aims to test the sensor in a group of patients and see how they walk over time. A participant will be recruited if they meet some technology readiness criteria and can do a long or short task. Some tests will be done, and the results will be compared and looked at for 3 months, 6 months, and a year. These tests measure how a person walks, how comfortable they are, and how well their steps and activity can help their walking. The sensor may help people with Parkinson's to "learn by doing" how to get better at using their steps to help them walk better.

[/INST] The study tested the effectiveness of a Laughter Yoga program among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school. The Laughter Yoga program consisted of laughter exercises, hand and body movements, and mimicking sounds for eight sessions over four weeks. A pilot randomized controlled trial design was used, with pre- and post-intervention measures. The outcomes of the study were mood, anxiety, and loneliness, as self-reported by adolescents using validated questionnaires. The study recruited 40 adolescents from a special school in Kowloon, Hong Kong, who met the study inclusion criteria. Adolescents were randomized to either the intervention group or the control group, which received usual care. The primary outcome was the mood of the adolescents, which was measured using the Mood Scale, and the secondary outcomes were anxiety and loneliness, which were measured using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory and the UCLA Loneliness Scale, respectively. The study found that the Laughter Yoga program significantly improved the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of the adolescents. The duration of the program was short, and the results need to be confirmed in future trials. This study contributes to the current knowledge of non-pharmacological approaches to improving the mental health of individuals with intellectual and physical disabilities and provides evidence for the effectiveness of Laughter Yoga.

[/INST] The Clinical Trial "Effects of Decision Aids on the Participation of South Asian Women in Cervical Cancer Screening: A Randomised Controlled Trial" was summarized. The study was designed with three arms (control, printed decision aid, and mobile decision aid) and a primary outcome of Decisional Conflict at 2 weeks post-intervention measured by Decisional Conflict Scale and cervical cancer screening uptake at 3 months post-intervention. The study was completed in Hong Kong and participants were South Asian Chinese female between the ages of 25 and 64 who consented to receive a smartphone and understood English, Hindi, Urdu, or Nepali, had no history of cervical cancer or total hysterectomy, had a history of sexual activity, and had not had a Pap/HPV test in the past 3 years. Data were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach. Effects of decision aids on participants was measured through assessments of Decisional Conflict, Risk Perception, Screening Decision, and Cervical Cancer Screening Uptake. The study provided three key results: 1) compared to the control group, the printed decision aid was non-significantly related to decreased decisional conflict while the mobile decision aid was associated with decreased decisional conflict; 2) compared to the control group, the printed and mobile decision aids non-significantly affected risk perception, choice predisposition, and choice question; and 3) the decision aids were successful at increasing cervical cancer screening uptake 3 months post-intervention.

[/INST] This is a single centre, randomized controlled trial comparing three groups of participants. All participants are diagnosed with myogenic TMD and forward head posture with craniocervical (CVA) angle < 50. The first group receives a combination of conservative management and cervical traction using the Denneroll. The second group receives conservative management only, whilst the third group receives cervical traction only. The craniocervical angle (CVA) is measured using a photographic method at baseline, 3rd and 7th weeks. The primary outcome measure is reduction in CVA. Additionally, there will be a pain assessment using an anamnestic questionnaire by Fonseca; pain-free mouth opening by using Bolley Gauge; pain using visual analogue scale (VAS); mouth opening measured with digital caliper and digital stadiometer. The study is concluded within 7 weeks with a follow-up session 3 weeks after the 7 weeks of treatment.

[/INST] "Comparison of the Efficacy of Clindamycin and Dapsone Gel in the Treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris"  In this study, two antibiotic and anti-inflammatory gels, Clindamycin and Dapsone, were compared in adults aged 20-50 with moderate acne vulgaris over three months to determine which was better at reducing acne symptom severity. Efficacy was determined by measuring the severity of acne before and after treatment on a 1-18 (mild), 19-30 (moderate), and 31-38 (severe) point scale. The gels contained the antibiotic Clindamycin and the anti-inflammatory agent dapsone, which differs in the concentration of its ingredients. Dapsone contained a higher percentage of dapsone than clindamycin which is a micro particle in its delivery system. Both treatments were effective in the reduction of acne but clindamycin was more effective in reducing the severity of acne than Dapsone.

The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of a sustainable nutrition protocol versus hospital standards on malnutrition in the elderly. The study uses a multi-centre randomized clinical trial design and includes measurements of anthropometric markers, quality of life assessments, and nutritional education. The duration of the study is 24 months, with 6 months of nutrition intervention and follow-up. The primary endpoint is improvement of nutritional status, with secondary endpoints including changes in blood biomarkers, dietary habits, and locomotion. The study follows 170 KTRs receiving Tacolimus/Mycophenolate Mofetil/Prednisone as immunosuppressive agents, and the study measures the TTV load, the infection and complication events, the development of de novo donor specific antibodies, and the development of a TTV load. [/INST] This is a paired non-randomized clinical trial study, where group one received vitamin B3 supplements and group two received vitamin B12 supplements. The treatment was administered over a one-year period, and participants underwent neurobehavioral testing at 3 weeks and 1 year following treatment. Gait analysis and testing of cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and various tests were conducted. The purpose is to investigate the effects of vitamin B3 and vitamin B12 supplements on nerve regeneration and functional recovery in pediatric patients with a brain injury. Participants included were children aged 6 to 15 years old with severe traumatic brain injury. The participants were of both genders, and all were included. The exclusion criteria were mild injury and those who were not willing to consent, and the healthy subjects also did not participate in the study. The intervention was open-label as the participants and physicians were aware of the administered drug. Both vitamin B3 and vitamin B12 were given orally, and the dosage of vitamin B3 was 16 mg/day, while the vitamin B12 dose ranged from 250 mcg to 125 mcg per day for participants weighing above 50 kg and those below 50 kg, respectively. The primary outcome of the study was the improvement in the Stair Climb Test. The secondary outcomes were the tests for cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and various other tests. The duration of the study was one year, and the participants underwent follow-up after 3 weeks and one year from the drug administration. The results of the study have not been made available. The sample size of the study was 300 participants.

[/INST] The study titled "Pyrotinib in Women With High-risk in Early Stage Breast Cancer" is a phase II, open-label study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pyrotinib in high-risk patients with early or locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer. Patients who have undergone standard-of-care treatment with surgery, radiotherapy, and systemic chemotherapy, including trastuzumab (HER2 monoclonal antibody) and pertuzumab (HER2 monoclonal antibody) or T-DM1 (antibody drug conjugate) combined with pertuzumab, but failed to achieve disease-free pathology, could also participate in the trial. The study's primary outcome is invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at 2 years, which is defined as the time from enrollment to the first instance of disease recurrence or death from any cause during 2-year follow-up, from enrollment to the first instance of distant recurrence or death from any cause. The major secondary outcome is disease-free survival (DFS) at 2 years, which is defined as the time from enrollment to the first instance of disease recurrence or death from any cause. Other outcomes include overall survival (OS), invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at 5 years, and safety.

[/INST] The Impact of Timing of Pasta Consumption on Health is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the impact of consuming pasta in the morning or evening on sleep, anthropometric, cardiovascular risk, gut microbiota, circadian rhythm and inflammation parameters in volunteers with normal body weight.

[/INST] The title of the text is "18F-Fluciclovine PET/CT in Multiple Myeloma" and the study is a phase II trial that aims to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma. Participants must have a documented diagnosis of multiple myeloma defined by the International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) Criteria. Participants must meet both the 18F-fluciclovine injection and 18F-FDG PET/CT procedure requirements. Participants must be eligible in one of two cohorts: newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) or relapsed and refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) with at least one prior line of therapy. All subjects must have measurable disease as defined by any one of the following: monoclonal bone marrow plasma cells >5% serum monoclonal protein ≥0.2 g/dl urine monoclonal protein >200 mg/24 hr serum immunoglobulin free light chain >10 mg/dL.

The study population consists of patients diagnosed with MS within the last 30 days who do not have any orthopedic, neurological, or vestibular conditions. The intervention included the evaluation of the arm swing using a Kinovea video player to assess its amplitude in the flexion and extension direction, and various functional tests to measure step speed, 2MWT, TUG, and T25FW. Measurements were performed at baseline and every 3 months until the end of the study.

[/INST] This is a clinical trial aiming to assess the effects of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to promote sleep quality in critically ill patients. The protocol is composed of the implementation of nursing interventions on sleep promotion and the use of hypnotics in case of failed sleep at night. The primary endpoint of this study is a better sleep quality in critical patients measured by the Richards Campbell Sleep Quality Score before and one month after the implementation of the protocol. The secondary endpoints consist of a better perception of factors influencing sleep and less delirium in critically ill patients, family satisfaction, ICU team satisfaction, and the perception of the effects of the protocol by the ICU team at ICU discharge and multidisciplinary knowledge of sleep. The changes in sleep quality measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and Epworth Sleepiness Scale are also evaluated three and six months after hospital discharge.

[/INST] The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial conducted in community pharmacies. The objective is to evaluate the feasibility and the potential to expand, of a program for community pharmacists to provide specialized care to women newly diagnosed with breast cancer. The pharmacist-led program provides specialized care to women receiving adjuvant endocrine therapy shortly after the end of their breast cancer treatment. The program addresses the women’s needs for information, behavior change and skills, by motivating them to continue the adjuvant endocrine therapy. Feasibility outcomes included recruitment, fidelity, study retention, feasibility of the intervention. Study endpoints included the women’s or the pharmacists’ point of view on the applicability, and their understanding of the program’s objectives and intervention modalities. Data were collected at baseline and at the end of the 6-month follow-up. There were two study groups: the intervention group, which received the pharmacist program in addition to the usual pharmacist care, and the control group, which received usual care. The sample consisted of 10 women and 5 pharmacists in each group. Adjuvant endocrine therapy intention to adhere scores was statistically greater in both groups over time. The results showed that the specialized care program seems to be a beneficial and promising program that could increase access to care and support among women with breast cancer receiving adjuvant endocrine therapy. This program could offer a model for a large-scale study on a representative sample.

[/INST] Melissa Officialis extract has been studied regarding its ability to improve sleep dynamics and overall quality of sleep. Specifically, the effectiveness of an extract formulated in phytosome technology has been assessed. Participants were asked to take the supplement for 14 days and to use a wearable sleep monitoring device to monitor the quantity and quality of their sleep. The quality of life scores, perceived anxiety, and sleep state measures were also used to collect quantitative data. This study aimed to reduce the number of participants using prescription and addictive over-the-counter medication products that negatively affect sleep patterns and potentially have harmful physical or psychological outcomes. Participants were randomly assigned to either treatment group 1, which started using Placebo for fourteen days and then switched to the phytosome-formulated supplement for seventeen days, or treatment group 2, which started using the phytosome-formulated extract for fourteen days and then switched to a placebo for fifteen days. Overall, the study concluded that Melissa Officialis phytosome extract positively impacted sleep characteristics by improving sleep latency, enhancing the sleep quality, maintaining regular sleep and wake patterns, and optimizing sleep phase quality, particularly the deep and light sleep phases. Moreover, the phytosome-formulated extract was found to be safe, and no severe adverse effects were reported in either treatment group. The authors believed that the enhanced bioavailability provided by the phytosome technology is responsible for the positive outcomes observed. However, the authors also recognized that the study could benefit from a more heterogeneous sample, including participants with various chronic health issues and medications, which would further support the study's findings.

The study is expected to result in a clearer understanding of the efficacy and safety of two transdermal gels of higher estradiol doses, which can help doctors choose more effective hormone replacement therapies for POI patients. The results of the study will also provide insights into long-term menopausal hormone therapies, which can help in the identification of new and effective treatments for women with POI.

[/INST] The study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of an activity wristband-based intermittent teaching unit (ITU) in physical education (PE) on students' physical activity and its psychological mediators. Two groups of students participated in this study: the intermittent group (IG) and the control group (CG). During the intervention, the IG students were given an activity wristband and participated in an intermittent teaching unit (ITU) that lasted eight weeks. The teaching unit was performed twice a week before, during, and after intervention. The CG students carried out the physical education lessons two times a week. They did not use a physical activity tracker nor receive any behavioral strategy modifications at the end of the teaching units. Measurements of students' physical activity and psychological outcomes were obtained before the intervention, immediately after, and at the six-week follow-up. The measures included perceived teacher autonomy support, basic psychological needs, self-determined and physical activity motivation, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity. The results of the study showed that the IG group had higher satisfaction with the perceived teacher's autonomy support and positive basic psychological needs than the CG group. Both the IG and CG groups had similar motivation levels, similar intention to participate in physical activity in their spare time, and similar habitual physical activity.

[/INST] The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and effects of pTTL (Personalized tumor-trained lymphocytes), a novel personalized cancer cell therapy in a cohort of adult patients with advanced CRC. Part I is a non-randomized first-in human dose escalation trial to determine the maximum feasible dose and safety of pTTL treatment in humans, as well as the best manufacturing practice for pTTL production. The production of pTTL begins with surgical removal of RLNs, which are then cryopreserved to allow time to initiate lymphodepletion-based cancer immunotherapy. Peripheral blood is collected from patients 2 to 4 weeks later, when leukocytes in lymphodepleted patients are predicted to maximally proliferate in response to stimulation via T cell receptors of tumor-derived neoepitopes contained in biopsied RLN tissue. T cells expanded from patient RLNs under these conditions are called pTTL. pTTL doses are administered to patients, and monitored for efficacy and adverse events. In addition to evaluating the maximum feasible pTTL dose, the study aims to investigate neoepitopes used to stimulate lymphodepleted patients' T cells, and establish the most reliable method of harvesting T cells for pTTL therapy. The manufacturing method established in this study could be a first step towards large scale production of pTTL for treatment of patients with advanced CRC.

[/INST] The role of Serum Amyloid A (SAA) in intrathoracic sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a multi-organ inflammatory disease with unknown etiology. Objective: to establish whether there is a correlation between serum concentrations of SAA in patients newly diagnosed with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and healthy controls. Methods: Intrathoracic sarcoidosis cohort containing 69 patients with confirmed sarcoidosis, according to ERS/WASOG criteria. Healthy control group of 20. Serum SAA concentrations are measured, using Immunoturbidimetric method. Results: The mean serum concentration of SAA was higher in patients than in controls. It was also significantly higher in patients with stage 1 and 2 and 5 stages than in healthy controls. A statistically significant correlation was found between mean SAA concentrations and Scadding staging system in 0-4 stages. Further studies are planned. Discussion: The results suggest the possibility of using SAA serum concentration measurement in clinical practice as an initial biomarker in patients with suspected sarcoidosis. The main limitation of the study is the small number of participants and a lack of a control group of patients with other non-sarcoid granulomatous pathologies.

Blood samples were analyzed several times and patients were followed up for 28 days. The primary outcome of the study was the time it took for paroxetine to discontinue vasopressor treatments. The following were secondary outcomes: the cumulative dose of vasopressors administered within the first 48 h of treatment, variation in the cardiovascular component of the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, cumulative dose of vasopressors provided within the first 120 hours, the variation of the SOFA score from 24 to 120 hours, and length of stay and mortality rates in the intensive care unit following admission.

[/INST] The summary of the clinical trial title "A Study to Learn About Tafamidis in Patients With Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India" is designed using two different models, the first one is summarizing the study title using pre-defined phrases like "what”, “where” etc. and the second one is extracting specific information from the study title by using noun phrases. The first model follows a similar text summarization approach to generate a summary for the clinical trial title. The summary generated using this model can be further improved by replacing the phrases "what” “where” etc. with pre-defined word sequences for each field, for example, in our case, we replaced "what” and "study” with “a study.” This could give rise to a high-quality summary. The second model gives rise to a concise summary by extracting the noun phrases from the sentence. The summary from this model can also be improved by replacing noun phrases with predefined noun phrases for the respective fields, i.e., in this case, the phrase "this Tafamidis Capsule" could be replaced with the phrase "the VyndaMx Ⓡ capsules" as it is more commonly used in studies.

[/INST] Tocopherol Acetate Vaginal Application in Pre-peri and Postmenopausal Women, is a study on the safety and efficacy of vaginal administration of tocopherol (Vitamin E) in pre-peri and postmenopausal women through tocoacetate vaginal filaments. The study aims at evaluating the effect of tocopherol on the vaginal pH, mucosal dryness, mucosal integrity, mucosal pallor, vaginal discharge, whiff test, lactobacillus grade according to Ison-Hay classification, number of colonies of the bacteria grouped in the Broad Group, and the evaluation of the flora on the basis of the percentage of molecular sequencing classes/genera based on NGS method. The study also aims to evaluate serum vitamin B12, estradiol and cortisol levels, uterine echogenicity and follicular diameter. Moreover, the study evaluates other aspects such as medical history, medical examination, laboratory tests, serious device effects, serious adverse events, adverse device effects, and concomitant treatments. The duration of the study is determined by the period in which the symptoms are present. The outcome measures of the study are acidosis of the vaginal mucosa, vaginal mucus dryness, vaginal mucosa pallor, vaginal discharge, whiff test, lactobacillus grade according to Ison-Hay classification, number of colonies of the bacteria grouped in the Broad Group, vaginal folloir diameter, ovarian follicle diameter, uterine echogenicity, serum estradiol, serum vitamin B12 and serum cortisol levels.

[/INST] The study is titled Hematocrit to Hemoglobin Ratio and Red Blood Cell Distribution Width in Polycythemia Vera and Secondary Erythrocytosis. It will include both patients with Polycythemia Vera (PV) and patients with Secondary Erythrocytosis as controls. To be eligible for the study, PV patients must be adults aged 18 and older who were newly diagnosed with PV in the Department of Internal Medicine at Sohag University Hospital. Participants will be excluded if their disease is not newly diagnosed or if they have chronic, acute myeloid leukemia, or other myeloid neoplasms. Control participants will be included if they have secondary erythrocytosis and will be recruited from the Chest and internal medicine departments of Sohag University Hospital. The study plan will collect data on participants' clinical manifestations, medical history, and investigations, including a complete blood picture with hematocrit, hemoglobin level, serum uric acid, mutation status, and bone marrow specimens. The primary outcome of the study will be the hematocrit-to-hemoglobin ratio of polycythemia vera and secondary erythrocytosis, while the secondary outcome will be red blood cell distribution width. The study will collect data from December 2022 to September 2023.

[/INST] The article is about the study entitled "Emergency Classification According To Fingertip Circulation". The article summarizes the use of devices to measure patients' oxygen perfusion index while triaging patients with dyspnea and how these devices affect emergency triage.

[/INST] The Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in Palliative Care study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled clinical trial. This study's objective is to confirm the therapeutic effects of LSD on patients with end-stage illnesses in a palliative setting. These effects include state anxiety, pain levels, spiritual well-being, demoralization, and caregiver burden. The study will compare the therapeutic effects of a single LSD dose in a terminal patient cohort to the effects of active placebo treatment. The secondary objective is to compare the effects of the active placebo treatment to the effects of two LSD doses in a crossover setting. The study will recruit 120 patients with end-stage illness along with their 240 caregivers. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive a single treatment consisting of a single dose of LSD (100 or 200 μg) or active placebo. LSD and active placebos will be administered by orally. The researchers will conduct psychometric assessments, including validated scales and scales specifically designed to measure end-of-life issues, at several points in time to measure the effects of LSD. The primary outcomes of the study are: the change in state anxiety (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, STAI-S) compared with the active placebo, the change in pain levels (numerical rating scale, NRS) compared with the active placebo, the change in opioids (opioid-equivalent doses) compared with the active placebo, the change in spiritual well-being (FACIT-Sp-12, Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy - Spiritual Well-Being) compared with the active placebo, and the change in demoralization (D17, Demoralization) compared with the active placebo. The data will enable investigators to determine whether treating patients with active placebo, LSD, or LSD in a crossover design is both safe and feasible, and whether LSD can elicit clinical and end-of-life experiences that improve patients' condition, resulting in desirable therapeutic effects.

[/INST] SmartMom is a randomized controlled trial that aims to improve maternal health and maternity outcomes by promoting healthy behaviors during pregnancy. This can include weight gain during pregnancy, prenatal care visits, health knowledge, health literacy, anxiety, depression, birth plan, tobacco use, alcohol use, marijuana use, drug use, breastfeeding status, and adverse pregnancy outcome. The study will compare pregnant individuals who receive SmartMom text messaging and those who receive control text messaging. The study will provide preliminary evidence of the potential benefits of using text messaging to promote healthy pregnancy and birth outcomes. The study will also contribute to the development of a mobile application that can be used for research and education for antenatal and postnatal care and for clinical and public health practice.
